questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents to your primary health center with complaints of lethargy, easy fatiguability after heavy menses of 6 months duration. She looks visibly pale. On examination, her palmar creases are lighter than the surrounding skin on hyperextension of the hand. She is presumed to be anemic and iron supplements started. What could be her possible hemoglobin level based on the current clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Given scenario points towards a diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia. If the palmar crease is lighter than surrounding skin on the hyperextended hand, hemoglobin is likely to be < 8 g/dl.

Primary symptoms of iron-deficiency anemia include easy fatigability, tachycardia, palpitations, and tachypnea on exertion.

Severe deficiency causes skin and mucosal changes:

  • A smooth tongue
  • Brittle nails
  • Spooning of nails (koilonychia)
  • Cheilosis

Dysphagia because of the formation of esophageal webs (Plummer–Vinson syndrome) may occur in severe iron deficiency.

Pica (cravings for specific foods like ice chips, hair, paper, which are often not rich in iron) may occur in iron deficient patients.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are correct with respect to the structures marked in state A and state B in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows histone modification by methylation (in state A) and acetylation (in state B).

In state A methylation of DNA and Histones causes nucleosomes to tight pack together. Transcription factors cannot bind the DNA, therefore the genes will not be expressed.

In state B, histone acetylation results in loose packing of the nucleosomes. The target gene is accessible and transcription factors can bind to the DNA and genes are expressed.

The organizational unit of the soluble chromatin is the nucleosome. Nucleosomes contain DNA and histone. Four major types of histones: H2A, H2B, H3, and H4 are tightly bound while H1 histones are the ones least tightly bound to chromatin. These give chromatin a repeating “beads-on-a-string” appearance when examined by electron microscopy.

These four core histones are subject to at least six types of covalent modification or posttranslational modifications (PTMs): acetylation, methylation, phosphorylation, ADP-ribosylation, monoubiquitylation, and sumoylation. These histone modifications play important roles in chromatin structure and function.

Roles of modified histones:

  • Acetylation of H3 and H4 is associated with the activation or inactivation of gene transcription.
  • Acetylation of core histones is associated with chromosomal assembly during DNA replication.
  • Methylation of histones is correlated with activation and repression of gene transcription
  • ADP-ribosylation of histones is associated with DNA repair.
  • Phosphorylation of histone H1 is associated with the condensation of chromosomes during the replication cycle.
  • Monoubiquitylation is associated with gene activation, repression, and heterochromatic gene silencing.

questions.text: A child presents with chronic diarrhea,  weight loss, and fatigue. On examination, he was pale, with decreased height for age score. The life cycle of the causative organism is given in the image below. Which of the following is not a known complication of this disease?
questions.solution:
The life cycle given above denoting adult worms in the large intestine with them having a slender anterior end and a 'whip-like' thick posterior end is suggestive of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm). Focal seizures or cerebral involvement is not a known complication of trichuriasis. 

Trichuriasis is caused by T. trichiura (whipworm), which inhabits the cecum and ascending colon.

Clinical features include chronic dysentery, anemia, poor growth, and developmental defects. The disease may result either due to the mechanical effect of the worms or an allergic reaction to the parasite.

Trichuris trichiura causes rectal prolapse in children (characteristic feature) because the rectum loses its internal support as the worms bury their thin heads into the intestinal lining, loosening the elastic epithelium, and weakening the surrounding muscles; also, there is rectal edema because of the infection. All these factors finally lead to rectal prolapse. In heavy infection with T. trichiura, sigmoidoscopy may show white bodies of worms hanging from the inflamed mucosa, the so-called coconut cake rectum. 

Other complications include dysentery, diarrhea, tenesmus, iron deficiency anemia, and poor growth. The poor growth is typically secondary to poor nutrition and consequently causes cognitive delay.

Fecal smears show a barrel-shaped ovum of T. trichiura. The eggs of T. trichiura do not have a terminal spine. They are barrel-shaped and have mucus plugs at both ends. They get bile-stained and float in the saturated salt solution. An image showing the egg of trichuris is given below.

 

Albendazole 400 mg orally for 3 days is the drug of choice.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with steatorrhea, hemolytic anemia, and ataxia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given below. Which vitamin can particularly prevent early death in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette mentioning steatorrhea, hemolytic anemia, and ataxia along with acanthocytes seen in the peripheral blood smear is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia. Administration of large doses of particularly Vitamin E can prevent early death in this condition.

Abetalipoproteinemia is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to loss of function mutation in the gene encoding microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP). MTP transfers lipids to nascent chylomicrons in the intestine and VLDLs in the liver. Therefore, when the MTP gene is mutated, chylomicrons, VLDL, and LDL are not produced.

Vitamin E and retinyl esters are normally transported from enterocytes to the liver by chylomicrons. Vitamin E is also dependent on VLDL for transport out of the liver and into circulation. Because of the inability of these patients to secrete apoB-containing particles, patients with abetalipoproteinemia are markedly deficient in vitamin E. 

Features of abetalipoproteinemia include diarrhea, failure to thrive, neurological features like loss of deep tendon reflexes, dysmetria, ataxia, spastic gait, etc, hypolipidemia, and progressive pigmented retinopathy which may progress to near-blindness.

Treatment of this condition includes the administration of large doses of Vitamin E. They are also mild to moderately deficient in vitamins A and K, those vitamins need to be administrated as well.

Note: It is necessary to initiate Vitamin E therapy as early as possible to prevent the development of neurologic sequelae which may warrant even higher doses of vitamin E.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with back pain, lethargy, weakness, depression, and confusion. On examination, he has pallor and bony tenderness. X-ray of his skull is shown below. Which of the following laboratory parameters is consistent with the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR is consistent with the suspected diagnosis of Multiple Myeloma as per this case scenario.

The patient has anemia, bony tenderness and lytic bone lesions on skull X-ray. The most likely diagnosis is multiple myeloma.

The skull demonstrates the typical “punched out” lesions characteristic of multiple myeloma. The lesion represents a purely osteolytic lesion with little or no osteoblastic activity. Hence Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is normal.

* Note: The most common site of lytic lesion in multiple Myeloma is: Vertebral column.

Related Pearl: International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

β2 microglobulin (mg/dL) and albumin (g/dL) level Stage Median survival months

β2M < 3.5

alb ≥3.5

 I 62

β2M < 3.5, alb < 3.5

or β2M = 3.5-5.5

 II 44
β2M > 5.5 III 29

ISS is the most widely used method of assesing prognosis in multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with abdominal masses and flank pain. His abdominal radiological imaging is given below. Which of the following are true regarding the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Options 1,2,4 and 5 are true.

Adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)

Inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with a mutation in the genes PKD1 (chromosome 16p, produces a protein called polycystin1) and PKD2 (chromosome 4q, polycystin 2).

Clinical features: The disease does not usually manifest before the age of 30 years, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed.

  • Hypertension (most common)
  • Irregular upper quadrant mass
  • Loin pain
  • Hematuria
  • Infection
  • Uremia

Extrarenal manifestation: Cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, and spleen. Berry aneurysm (Intracranial aneurysms), colonic diverticuli may also occur.

Rupture of cerebral aneurysms is an important cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with adult polycystic kidney disease (PKD).

The prevalence of intracranial aneurysms in patients with PKD is 40%. Screening cerebral angiography is strongly considered in all patients with PKD and a family history of cerebral aneurysm or subarachnoid haemorrhage.

Mitral valve prolapse is seen in up to 25% of patients with ADPKD.

ADPKD is an important cause of renal failure, affecting 10-15% of the patients who receive haemodialysis.

Note: 

Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD):

  • ARPKD is secondary to a mutation of the PKHD1 gene (encodes a protein called fibrocystin) on chromosome 6p.
  • The severe form manifests in utero or in infancy; milder cases can manifest later in childhood.
  • All affected individuals have some degree of congenital hepatic fibrosis.
  • 50% of affected newborns die in the first few days of life.

 

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: A person who was in deep sleep with arms under his head after alcohol-intoxication now presents with Saturday night palsy. Which of the following sensations would remain relatively intact in him?
questions.solution:
Pain sensations would remain relatively intact in persons with Saturday night palsy. 

Sleeping for a long period with the arms under the head puts pressure on a nerve, leading to the loss of conduction in large-diameter motor, touch, and pressure fibers, while pain sensation remains relatively intact.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty following an RTA with the limb in position as shown in the below image. Knowing that the right lower limb is the one affected, which of the following options are correct regarding the most likely diagnosis in the given patient?
questions.solution:
In the above image, the affected leg is in the state of flexion, adduction, and internal rotation (FADIR). Hence the most likely diagnosis is posterior dislocation of the hip. Options 1,4, and 5 are correct with respect to posterior hip dislocation.

Posterior dislocation of the hip joint commonly occurs with the dashboard injury. It is more common than anterior hip dislocation. Shortening of limb is seen in posterior type.

As the sciatic nerve lies behind the posterior wall of the acetabulum, it usually gets damaged with posterior dislocation of the hip.

X-ray findings in Posterior dislocation of the hip joint:

  • The femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally to the acetabulum
  • The femoral head appears slightly smaller than the normal
  • The limb is adducted and internally rotated, and hence the lesser trochanter is often obscured/less prominent on AP view.

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

  Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation
Prevalence Less common Most common
Type of injury Deceleration injury/ Fall from height Dashboard injury
Attitude of the limb Flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER) Flexion, adduction, internal rotation (FADIR)
Length of the limb Lengthened Shortened
Radiological findings
  • Femoral head may be seen inferior to the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualised
Nerve injured  Femoral nerve  Sciatic nerve

questions.text: The given blood smear shows a characteristic cell type. It is most likely  seen in infection with which of the following viruses?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is adult T cell leukemia/lymphoma caused by human T cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). The peripheral smear given above shows tumor cells with multilobulated nuclei (“cloverleaf” or “flower” cells) which is characteristic of Adult T-Cell Leukemia/Lymphoma.

Adult T-Cell Leukemia/Lymphoma (CD4+):

  • It is observed in adults infected by human T cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1)
  • It is characterised by skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, peripheral blood lymphocytosis, and hypercalcemia.
  • Peripheral smear shows cells with multilobulated nuclei (“cloverleaf” or “flower” cells)
  • A rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is/are correct regarding the alpha-helical protein structure shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Alpha helix is stabilized primarily by intra-chain hydrogen bonds. Alpha helix is the most common and stable secondary structure. A complete turn of the helix contains an average of 3.6 aminoacyl residues.

Large numbers of charged amino acids (glutamate, aspartate, histidine, lysine, and arginine) disrupt the helix by forming ionic bonds or by electrostatically repelling each other.

The most common and stable conformation for a polypeptide chain is alpha helix.

Examples of proteins whose major 2° structure is alpha helix:

  • Hemoglobin
  • Myoglobin

Proline does not participate in the formation of an alpha helix. 

The stability of an alpha helix arises primarily from hydrogen bonds formed between the oxygen of the peptide bond carbonyl and the hydrogen atom of the peptide bond nitrogen of the fourth residue down the polypeptide chain.

Since the peptide bond nitrogen of proline lacks a hydrogen atom, it is incapable of forming a hydrogen bond with carbonyl oxygen.

Glycine induces bends within a helix, because of its small size.

questions.text: A woman with a tumor in the left cerebral hemisphere underwent surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Biopsy of the tumor specimen showed a circumscribed, gelatinous, gray mass with calcification. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario (tumor in the cerebral hemisphere) and the gross pathology (circumscribed, gelatinous, gray mass with calcification) of the tumor in a female is most likely oligodendroglioma.

Oligodendrogliomas account for 5 to 15% of all gliomas and most commonly are detected in the fourth and fifth decades of life. Patients may have had several years of antecedent neurologic complaints, often including seizures. The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, mainly in the frontal or temporal lobes.

The tumors are composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm giving a fried egg appearance. Tumor cells infiltrating the cerebral cortex often collect around neurons (perineuronal satellitosis).

The image below shows the fried egg appearance on histopathology:


The combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy yields an average survival of 10 to 20 years for well-differentiated (WHO grade II) oligodendroglioma or 5 to 10 years for anaplastic (WHO grade III) oligodendroglioma.

Other options:

Option A: Meningiomas are non-glial in origin and arise from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges, mostly seen outside the brain parenchyma, and can occur anywhere meninges are found.

Option B: Ependymomas most often arise next to the ependyma-lined ventricular system, including the central canal of the spinal cord. In the first 2 decades of life, they typically occur near the fourth ventricle and constitute 5% to 10% of the primary brain tumors in this age group. In adults, the spinal cord is their most common location; tumors in this site are particularly frequent in the setting of neurofibromatosis type 2.

Option D: Pilocytic astrocytoma is a low-grade tumor. It is the most common type of astrocytoma in children. It typi­cally occurs in children and young adults. The classic sites of pilocytic astrocytoma are the cerebellum (infratentorial) and optic pathway region.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a phagocytic defect?
questions.solution:
Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis is an example of T cell defects or cellular immunodeficiency.

It is characterized by deficient cell-mediated immunity to candida, which is usually due to defects in IL-17.

Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis:

  • Patients develop severe chronic candidiasis of the mucosa, skin, and nails. They are unable to mount an effective Th17 response to Candida.
  • They do not show increased susceptibility to other infections but often have endocrinopathies.
  • Delayed hypersensitivity to candida antigens is absent but circulating antibodies to them are present in high titers. 
  • Transfer factor therapy and Amphotericin B have been reported to be effective for the treatment of chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis

Other options:

Chediak Higashi syndrome, chronic granulomatous disease, leukocyte glucose-6-phosphate deficiency, and Tuftsin deficiency are disorders of phagocytosis.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with 16 weeks of gestation presents with cramping abdominal pain followed by the passage of fleshy mass per vaginum but the pain subsided following the expulsion. On examination, the uterus appears smaller, os is closed and the bleeding was found to be stopped. Ultrasound reveals an empty uterine cavity. This is a case of ____________ miscarriage.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of complete miscarriage.

Expulsion of products of conception, en masse, is called a complete miscarriage.

Features:

  • Subsidence of abdominal pain
  • Decreased or absent vaginal bleeding
  • Uterus is smaller
  • The cervical os is closed
  • Examination of the expelled fleshy mass is found complete.
  • USG - empty uterine cavity

Abortion is the expulsion or extraction from the mother of an embryo or fetus weighing 500 g or less when it is not capable of independent survival.

Classification of abortion:

 

In threatened miscarriage, the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • Uterus and cervix feel soft
  • Well-formed gestation ring
  • Fetal cardiac motion
  • Blighted ovum

In inevitable miscarriage, the changes have progressed to a state from where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.

Features:

  • Increased vaginal bleeding
  • Aggravation of pain in the lower abdomen which may be colicky in nature
  • Dilated internal os
  • Rupture of the membranes

In incomplete miscarriage, entire products of conception are not expelled, instead, a part of it is left inside the uterine cavity

  • Pain in the lower abdomen
  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Uterus smaller than the period of amenorrhea
  • Patulous cervical os
  • Echogenic material (products of conception) within the cavity

In missed miscarriage, the fetus is dead and retained inside the uterus for a variable period

Features: The patient usually presents with features of threatened miscarriage followed by

  • Persistence of brownish vaginal discharge
  • Subsidence of pregnancy symptoms
  • Retrogression of breast changes
  • Cessation of uterine growth
  • Nonaudibility of the fetal heart sound
  • Cervix feels firm
  • Negative immunological test for pregnancy
  • Empty sac

In septic abortion, there will be clinical evidence of infection of the uterus and its contents

Features:

  • Rise of the temperature of at least 100.4 F for 24 hours or more
  • Offensive or purulent vaginal discharge
  • Other evidence of pelvic infection such as lower abdominal pain and tenderness.

Related Pearl: Clinical classification of Spontaneous Abortion

questions.text: The incidence of Hodgkin's lymphoma was plotted to measure the age-wise distribution. It was found that there were two peaks, with the initial peak at 25 years and the later peak starting at age of 50. Which of the following is not true regarding such distributions?

choices.text: Such a distribution indicates that the study material is not homogenous
Such a distribution indicates 2 distinct sets of casual factors might be operative
Large numbers of observations are a frequent source of Such a distribution
A similar distribution is also seen in female breast cancer

questions.solution:
The graph shows the bimodal distribution and small numbers of observations are a frequent source of bimodality, which makes their interpretation difficult.

Bimodal distribution refers to the occurrence of two separate peaks. It usually indicates that the study material was not homogenous, and two causative factors might be in effect. Absence of bimodality doesn't indicate that the study is homogenous

Hodgkin's lymphoma, leukaemia and female breast cancer show a bimodal curve with double peaks.

 

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: Shweta came to donate blood for the first time on her 30th birthday. After an adequate history and baseline tests, blood donation was started along with the monitoring of her pulse and BP. She developed sweating,  bradycardia, hypotension, and fainted transiently. Which of the following should not be done?

choices.text: Help the patient to stand up on her feet
Give her fluids to drink orally
Avoid investigation for cause of fainting

questions.solution:
Helping the patient to stand on her feet should not be done.

The given scenario describes precipitation of vasovagal syncope. It might be due to anxiety in first time donor, a hot and humid environment in the donation room, or due to hypoglycemia, lack of sleep in the donor. Signs and symptoms are seen as pallor or sweating, slow pulse, drop in blood pressure, vomiting, loss of consciousness, or very rarely convulsions due to anoxia. 

What should be done in this situation?

• Discontinue donation
• Recline chair
• Loosen clothes
• Monitor BP and pulse
• Reassure the patient
• Give fluids to drink (recovery is usually rapid)

Since the patient underwent basic investigations, monitoring of the vitals before the procedure and she would recover immediately from vasovagal syncope, investigations for the cause of fainting are not necessary and can be avoided.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the ER with headache, fever, and vomiting for the past 5 hours. A CT image is shown below. Physical examination shows positive Kernig’s and Brudzinski’s signs. Vitals: Temp - 101 F, BP - 120/88 mmHg, PR - 110 beats/min, pupils reactive. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and the treatment of choice for this condition is surgical clipping. 

CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space, which is suggestive of SAH. Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at this location.

SAH can present with fever, positive Kernig’s sign, and Brudzinski’s sign, as well as mimic meningitis or encephalitis.

Treatment with the calcium channel antagonist nimodipine (60 mg PO every 4 h) improves outcome, by preventing ischemic injury.

Option A: Vancomycin + ceftriaxone is the recommended therapy for bacterial meningitis. Meningitis does not show hyper-attenuated subarachnoid space.

Option B: IV Tenecteplase is used for ischemic stroke without bleeding complications.

questions.text: A 16-year-old footballer presents with the features of gigantism. He is being evaluated for excess growth hormone secretion in the body. The following factors would contribute to stimulating the growth hormone secretion:
questions.solution:
Options 1, 3, and 4 are correct.

Factors that stimulate or inhibit the secretion of growth hormone:

Stimuli that Increase Secretion Stimuli that Decrease Secretion
  •  Exercise
  • Deep sleep
  • Fasting/ Hypoglycemia
  • Stressful stimuli (including various psychological stresses)
  • Protein deficiency
  • Glucagon
  • Estrogens and androgens
  • Ghrelin
  • Increased blood Glucose
  • Increased blood FFA
  • Somatostatin
  • Exogenous Growth hormone
  • IGF/ Somatomedins
  • Aging
  • Obesity

 

The image depicts the fluctuations of secretion of growth hormone throughout the day. 

  • Growth hormone is found at relatively low levels during the day unless specific triggers such as strenuous exercise are present.
  • During sleep, on the other hand, large pulsatile bursts of growth hormone secretion occur.

questions.text: An elderly female presents to you with complaints of pain, swelling, and early morning stiffness in the wrist joint along with MCP joint and PIP joint for 8 weeks. On examination, no other joints were involved. Her laboratory reports reveal a High-positive Rheumatoid factor level with elevated CRP levels. A clinical diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis is made in this patient with the help of  ACR-EULAR classification criteria. Identify the correct statement regarding the scores assigned to this patient?
questions.solution:
Option 3, 4, and 5 are correct

The clinical diagnosis of Rheumatoid Arthritis is largely based on signs and symptoms of chronic inflammatory arthritis, with laboratory and radiographic results.

ACR-EULAR classification criteria help in early diagnosis of RA and thereby early introduction of disease-modifying therapy in these patients.

Joint Involvement

1 large joint

0

 

2-10 large joints

1

 

1-3 small joints

2 (As in the given case)

 

4-10 small joints

3

 

>10 small joints

5

SEROLOGY

Negative RF and negative anti-CCP

0

 

Low positive RF or anti-CCP

2

 

High positive RF or anti-CCP

3 (As in given case)

ACUTE PHASE REACTANTS

normal CRP and ESR

0

 

Abnormal CRP or ESR

1 (As in given case)

DURATION OF SYMPTOMS

<6 WEEKS

0

 

>6 WEEKS

 

1 (As in given case)

The total score in the given clinical scenario is 7

Remember: A score of ≥6 fulfills requirements for definite RA.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with a swelling in the lower lid that is gradually increasing in size. O/E, a nontender nodule was noted away from the lower lid margin, which was firm to hard on palpation. Histopathology showed extracellular fat deposits surrounded by lipid-laden epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathology are suggestive of Chalazion.

Chalazion: 

  • It is also called a tarsal or meibomian cyst 
  • It is a chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation of the Meibomian gland
  • Presents as a painless swelling of the eyelid
  • The upper lid is involved more commonly than the lower lid probably because the upper lid contains more meibomian glands than the lower lid
  • Secondary infection may lead to the formation of hordeolum internum.
  • Recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathology because of possible malignant change into Meibomian gland adenocarcinoma / sebaceous cell carcinoma.

Treatment:

  • Conservative treatment by hot fomentation
  • Incision and curettage
  • Intralesional injection of triamcinolone acetate causes the resolution of small and soft chalazion.

Note:

Hordeolum internum is an acute suppurative inflammation of the meibomian gland, associated with blockage of the duct.

Hordeolum externum or stye is the staphylococcal infection of hair follicle/Zeis gland/Moll gland

questions.text: You are posted as an intern in the Medicine ward where your consultant asks you to make a list of all the patients who require strict therapeutic drug monitoring as they are on specific drugs. The following patients will be included in your list:
questions.solution:
Patient with Bipolar disorder on Lithium therapy, the child with steroid-resistant Nephrotic syndrome on Cyclosporine and the patient on Carbamazepine therapy for focal seizures require therapeutic drug monitoring

Therapeutic drug monitoring refers to a process where the plasma concentration of a drug is measured and its dose is adjusted accordingly. It is done for:

 

  • Drugs that exhibit a good correlation between serum level and drug response or toxicity.
  • Drugs having a wide variation in pharmacokinetics both intra and inter-individual.
  • Drugs having low therapeutic index like digitalis, lithium, antiepileptics, antiarrhythmics, TCAs, etc.

It is not done for:

  •  Drugs whose effect can be easily measured like antidiabetics, antihypertensive, anticoagulants.        
  •  Drugs which are activated in the body or produce active metabolites

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

questions.text:
Mark the following statements as true/false regarding spinal cord:
  1. The spinal cord consists of inner core of grey matter and an outer layer of white matter
  2. The amount of grey and white matter is largest in cervical and lumbar enlargements of the spinal cord
  3. The amount of white matter is largest in the cervical level and gradually decreases as it reaches the lower levels of the spinal cord
  4. The central canal of the spinal cord is lined by squamous epithelium
  5. Rostrally, the central canal opens into the fourth ventricle
questions.solution:
Statements b and d are false, while the other statements are true.

  • The spinal cord consists of an outer layer of white matter and the inner core of grey matter.
  • The grey matter consists of cell bodies of the neurons. The amount of grey matter is largest in the cervical and lumbar enlargements of the spinal cord, which consists of the cell bodies of neurons that innervate the limbs.
  • The white matter of the spinal cord consists of ascending and descending tracts. The amount of white matter is largest in the cervical level, and gradually decreases as it reaches the lower levels of the cord. This is because the descending tracts give off the fibres as they descend, while the ascending tracts accumulate the fibres as they ascend.
  • The centre of the spinal cord consists of a canal, which contains the CSF. The central canal of the spinal cord is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium.
  • Rostrally, the central canal of the spinal cord opens into the fourth ventricle.

questions.text: A Microbiologist in a lab was found to be handling Mycobacterium tuberculosis within a  biological safety cabinet as shown in the image below. The bio-safety level (BSL) being followed in the given scenario is_______
questions.solution:
The given biosafety level is 3.

BSL-3 laboratory has:

  • A. Appropriate PPE and respirators might be required.
  • B. All work performed within BSC(biosafety cabinet).
  • C. Entrance is through 2 sets of self-closing and locking doors.

Eg: when dealing with Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Other options:

BSL-1: Work can be done on an open bench or table and PPE needed. Eg: Non-pathogenic E.coli.

BSL-2: Work to be done in the biosafety cabinet with PPE. Eg: Staphylococcus aureus.

BSL-4: This is the highest level of biological safety, where containment of microbes is done, which are fatal without treatment and vaccines. Eg: Ebola and Marburg viruses.

questions.text: The following are systems/campaigns related to Hansen's disease:
questions.solution:
Sparsh leprosy awareness campaign and the Nikusth system are related to Hansen's disease/Leprosy.

"Sparsh Leprosy Awareness Campaign" (SLAC) was introduced in 2017 on the occasion of Anti-Leprosy day (observed on last Sunday of January) to promote awareness. NLEP introduced this campaign in order to address the issue of the high level of stigma attached to leprosy and to increase awareness about various aspects of leprosy.

Nikusth: A web-based system for data management for leprosy cases.

Other options:

  • Nikshay is a web-based solution for monitoring of TB patients.
  • Axshya is the project that works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between government and civil society.
  • Nischay is a pregnancy test kit introduced by the government.

questions.text: You would advise on-site chemical pre-treatment before incineration for all of the following biomedical waste except ____
questions.solution:
Urine bags do not have to undergo on-site chemical pre-treatment to sterilize before handing them over for incineration.

As per NACO or WHO guidelines, laboratory waste, microbiological waste, blood samples, blood bags should be sterilized with non-chlorinated chemicals on-site. After this, it should be handed over to the common bio-medical waste treatment and disposal facility for incineration.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male has been admitted to the Medicine department with anasarca, nephrotic range proteinuria, and mild hepatomegaly. His BP is 140/90 mm Hg, but he is not diabetic. A section of the liver stained with Congo red reveals pink-red deposits as shown in the below image, which also gives apple-green birefringence when observed with a polarizing microscope. Which of the following statements is/are incorrect regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Options 1,3 and 5 are incorrect. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of systemic Amyloidosis.

Amyloid appears first in the space of Disse in the liver followed by deposition on adjacent hepatic parenchymal cells and sinusoids.

Amyloidosis refers to extracellular deposits of fibrillar proteins. Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind a wide variety of proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

The most common and the most serious form of organ involvement in AL amyloidosis is renal tissue. Kidneys are the most frequently involved organ and are affected in 70–80% of patients.

The heart is the second most commonly affected organ (50–60% of patients), and cardiac involvement is the leading cause of death from AL amyloidosis. The deposits start as focal subendocardial accumulations and within the myocardium between the muscle fibers.

Renal amyloidosis usually manifests as proteinuria, often in the nephrotic range, and is associated with hypoalbuminemia, secondary hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and edema or anasarca.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman in the first trimester comes with increased vomiting. Beta HCG levels are increased and her USG is given below. Which among the following clinical features is unlikely to be associated with the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a snowstorm appearance, therefore it is a molar pregnancy. Quickening is absent in these cases.

Molar pregnancy may present with bleeding per vaginum or an acute discharge of vesicular mass per vaginum. On examination, the uterine size is more than the corresponding period of amenorrhea. It shows a characteristic snowstorm appearance on USG. They may have thyrotoxic features, attributable to chorionic thyrotropin and breathlessness due to the pulmonary embolism of trophoblastic cells. History of quickening is absent. Vaginal bleeding is the commonest presentation.

The definitive management after diagnosis is suction and evacuation, after making the cervix favorable. 

Hysterectomy is indicated only if:

  • age of patient over 35 years
  • completed family irrespective of age
  • uncontrolled hemorrhage or perforation during the surgical evacuation

The given images show the development of hydatiform mole.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: You have been asked to present a case on homicidal deaths by asphyxia, with pictorial representation of the mechanism of attack. You added the following images in your presentation which show death by ________.
questions.solution:
The image shows smothering, which involves the blockage of the external air passages or obstructing the nasal and oral cavities, usually by a hand or soft fabric/ pillow. 

Death occurs due to reflex cardiac arrest rather than due to hypoxia. Examination reveals pallor around the nose and mouth when external pressure is applied using a pillow. Smothering material may yield mucus and respiratory epithelium of the victim. Bruising of the inner surface of the lips and gums may be seen if more force is applied during smothering.

Other options - 

Mugging is a method of strangulation wherein the neck of the victim is caught in the bend of the assailant's elbow. Pressure is usually applied either in front of the larynx or at one or both sides of the neck.

In garroting, the victim is attacked by grasping the throat or by tightening the ligature around the neck from behind.

Throttling is a method of manual compression of the neck by human hands. The cause of death is carotid artery occlusion on both sides. 

Related Pearl: Difference between strangulation by Ligature and Hanging

Trait

Hanging

Strangulation by ligature

Nature of death

Mostly suicidal

Mostly homicidal

Face

Usually pale and petechiae are rare

Congested, livid, and marked with petechiae

Tongue

Swelling and protrusion is less marked

Swelling and protrusion is more marked

Bleeding

Bleeding from the nose, mouth, and ears is not common

Bleeding from the nose, mouth, and ears may be found

Saliva

Often dribbles out of the mouth

Dribbling of saliva is very rare

Ligature mark

Oblique, non-continuous, placed high up in the neck between the chin and the larynx. 

The subcutaneous tissue underneath the mark is usually hard, white, and glistening

Horizontal or transverse, continuous around the neck, low down in the neck below or across the thyroid.   

Subcutaneous tissue underneath may be ecchymosed

Abrasions and

ecchymoses

Rare

Common

Injury to muscles of

neck

Rare

Common

Carotid arteries

Internal coats are usually ruptured in violent cases of a long drop (Amussat's sign)

Damage to the internal coat is rare

Hyoid bone fracture

Less common

Less common (common in manual strangulation)

Thyroid cartilage fracture

Less common

More common

Cervical vertebrae fracture or dislocation

Common in judicial hanging

Rare

questions.text: A farmer from sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of the prick. Histology of the lesion is given in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely a case of chromoblastomycosis with sclerotic bodies seen on histopathology examination

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genus Fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutters and farmers. It appears as sclerotic bodies on histopathology examination and copper penny bodies on KOH mount. Treatment with antifungals are given.

Points in favor:

  • Sub-Himalayan belt farmer with thorn prick injury
  • Verrucous growth
  • Histology showing "Medlar bodies"(sclerotic bodies)

 

  Chromoblastomycosis Sporotrichosis
Cause Pigmented fungi-Phialophora and Fonsecaea species Dimorphic fungi-Sporothrix schenckii
Presentation Warty, cauliflower-like growth at the site of the prick A linear chain of ulcerating nodules and sinuses along the lymphatics
Histology Medlar bodies/sclerotic bodies Asteroid bodies

Other options:

Mycetoma:

  • It is caused by various types of fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (Actinomycetes).
  • It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form, which break down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

Image: Mycetoma of foot

Sporotrichosis: Nodules generally develop along the draining lymphatics

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that causes cryptococcosis. It is an oval, budding yeast with a prominent polysaccharide capsule, which is very apparent in India ink staining. It forms smooth, mucoid, cream-colored colonies on Sabouraud agar.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A cardiovascular surgeon posts a 56-year-old male for coronary artery bypass surgery. As the junior resident, you join the care team who explain to the patient regarding the options and their pros and cons. Which of the following options represents the correct order of graft patency among the various conduits available for the CABG?

choices.text: Left internal mammary artery > Radial artery > Greater saphenous vein
Greater saphenous vein > Left internal mammary artery > Radial artery
Left internal mammary artery  > Greater saphenous vein > Radial artery
Greater saphenous vein  > Radial artery  > Left internal mammary artery

questions.solution:
Left internal mammary artery > Radial artery > Greater saphenous vein represents the correct order of graft patency in a patient undergoing CABG procedure.

Bypass Conduit Selection: 

  • The most important criterion in conduit selection is graft patency. The conduit with the highest patency rate is the Left internal mammary artery or internal thoracic artery.
  • The Left Internal Mammary Artery (LIMA) or Internal thoracic artery has become the conduit of choice for the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery.
  • The greater saphenous vein can be harvested using an open or endoscopic technique. This conduit provides good length and is easy to handle.
  • The radial artery is another frequently used conduit. Studies showed that Radial artery grafts have better patency than saphenous vein graft on 5-year angiographic follow-up.

Other conduits:

The gastroepiploic artery is rarely used today. Studies  suggests that the saphenous vein has better early (6-month) and midterm (3-year) graft patency than the right gastroepiploic artery when it is used for right coronary artery revascularization.

Alternative vein conduits include the short saphenous vein or cephalic vein; however, these grafts are associated with poorer long-term patency rates.

questions.text: Contraceptive failure occurs in a 32-year-old woman who is taking an oral contraceptive pill (OCP) and tetracycline simultaneously. What is the mechanism causing OCP failure in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Broad-spectrum antibiotics like tetracyclines suppress the intestinal flora and interfere with the enterohepatic circulation of estrogen, leading to a lowering of plasma estrogen levels and resulting in contraceptive failure.

Enzyme inhibitors like verapamil, fluconazole, erythromycins inhibit the degradation of OCPs. OCPs thus have a longer duration of action and less incidence of contraceptive failure with these.

However, most other antiepileptic drugs are enzyme inducers, causing increased degradation of OCPs and hence leading to contraceptive failure. Eg: carbamazepine, phenytoin, efavirenz, primidone, nevirapine, rifampicin.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman diagnosed with breast carcinoma have been posted for modified radical mastectomy procedure. Identify the true statements regarding various modifications of this surgery?
questions.solution:
Modified radical mastectomy(MRM) preserves the pectoralis major muscle. Various modifications of MRM includes,

Auchincloss procedure: Here pectoralis minor is only retracted and not removed.

Patey and Dyson’s technique: It includes removal of the breast tissue and axillary lymph nodes along with the removal of pectoralis minor muscle, but pectoralis major is preserved.

Scanlon’s procedure: Here pectoralis minor muscle is divided but not removed.

Note: While performing this surgery, Long thoracic nerve of Bell is identified and preserved because it supplies serratus anterior muscle and Denervation of the serratus anterior muscle results in permanent disability with a winged scapula and shoulder weakness.

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese woman on combined oral contraceptive pills is diagnosed with cholelithiasis for which an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy is planned. What would you advise her about the usage of these pills before the surgery?

choices.text: Stop using pills 2 weeks before surgery
Stop using pills one day before surgery
Stop using pills 4 weeks before surgery

questions.solution:
Usage of combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) can be continued to the day of surgery and in the peri-operative period.

Estrogens are found to increase thromoembolic risk in patients. But modern oral contraceptives contain low amounts of estrogen. In this scenario, the risk of accidental pregnancy outweighs the significance of not taking the contraceptives prior to surgery. So, oral contraceptives can be continued. Estrogens must be discontinued only if the patient is deemed high risk for post operative venous thromboembolism. 

Barrier methods can be used during this period to prevent unwanted pregnancies. In case of emergency surgeries in patients on combined OCPs or hormone replacement therapy, perioperative thromboprophylaxis should be started.

Contraindications of COCPs:

  • Cardiac disease, hypertension, smoker over 35 years.
  • Diabetes.
  • History of thrombosis, myocardial infarct, sickle cell anemia, severe migraine.
  • Chronic liver diseases such as cholestatic jaundice of pregnancy, cirrhosis of the liver, adenoma, porphyrias.
  • Breast cancer, gall bladder disease.
  • Patient on enzyme-inducing drugs like rifampicin, and antiepileptic except sodium valproate.
  • Lactating woman.
  • Monilial vaginitis.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male has been diagnosed with chronic congestive heart failure and beta-blockers have been started. His symptoms fail to improve despite being on medication. His BP is 132/80 mm Hg and the heart rate is 84/minute. He was started on a drug which is a selective inhibitor of cardiac pacemaker channels. Which of the following statements are correct regarding this drug?
questions.solution:
Ivabradine is a a selective inhibitor of cardiac pacemaker channels (HCNs) or funny current If inhibitor of SA node indicated in specific chronic congestive heart failure patients approved who are not tolerating β blockers or having heart rate > 75 under β blockers.

Ivabradine is used as a therapeutic target to control heart rate. Unlike other heart rate-lowering agents such as β blockers, it reduces heart rate without affecting myocardial contractility, ventricular repolarization, or intracardiac conduction. The antianginal effect is mainly by reduction of heart rate and thereby decreasing O2 demand of the myocardium.

Side effects are bradycardia, QT prolongation, atrial fibrillation, and phosphenes ( a transient enhanced lightness in restricted areas of the visual field that are explained by effects on retinal HCN channels).

It is contraindicated in combination with diltiazem or verapamil.

questions.text: Symptoms should be present for at least > 6 months to diagnose the following disorders:
questions.solution:
Options 3, 4 and 5 are correct.

Presence of symptoms at least 6 months is required for the diagnosis of Phobia, Hypochondriasis and Chronic fatigue syndrome.

Presence of symptoms at least 3 months is required for the diagnosis of Bulimia nervosa and symptoms for 2 years are required for the diagnosis of dysthymia.

Related Pearl: Timeline in psychiatry

Condition Duration
Manic episode At least 1 week
Hypomania At least 4 consecutive days
Major depressive disorder

Lasts 6 to12 months with episodes for 2 or more weeks
Cyclothymia At least 2 years
Dysthymia At least 2 years
Maternal blues Starts 2–3 days after delivery and usually resolves within 10 days
Postpartum mood disturbances Onset within 4 weeks of delivery
Brief psychotic disorder Lasts < 1 month, usually stress-related
Schizophreniform disorder Lasts 1-6 months
Schizophrenia Lasts > 6 months
Schizoaffective disorder Lasts > 2 weeks
Delusional disorder Lasts > 1 month
Panic disorder An episode followed by 1 month of concern of additional attacks 
Specific phobia Lasts > 6 months
Generalized anxiety disorder Lasts > 6 months 
Acute stress disorder Lasts between 3 days and 1 month 
PTSD Lasts > 1 month 
Adjustment disorder

Symptoms occur within 3 months of the stressor and last < 6 months

May last > 6 months in presence of chronic stressor
Bulimia nervosa At least 3 months
Somatic symptom disorder Lasts > 6 months
Separation anxiety disorder Common onset at 7–9 years 
Tourette syndrome

Onset < age 18 years

Tics that persist for > 1 year 
ADHD Symptoms for > 6 months

questions.text: After giving a neuraxial block to a patent in an OT, the senior resident tells you to assess the quality of the motor block as per the modified Bromage scale. On examination, You grade the motor block in this patient as stage 2, as this patient was ________

choices.text: Unable to flex knee but was able to move feet
Unable to flex knee and was not able to move feet
Unable to raise extended leg, but was able to move knees and feet
Unable to raise extended leg and move knee but was able to move feet

questions.solution:
Inability to raise extended leg and move knees but being able to move feet, after a neuraxial block is graded as stage 2 as per modified bromage scale.

Modified bromage scale is the most common method used for assessment of motor block following neuraxial anesthesia but this scale assess the adequacy of the block of lumbosacral motor fibers only.

Electromyography and pulmonary function tests (spirometry) have been used to measure abdominal and thoracic motor function, but these are neither practical nor specific.

Related Pearl: Modified Bromage scale

0: No motor block

1: Inability to raise the extended leg; Able to move knees and feet

2: Inability to raise the extended leg and move knee; Able to move feet

3: Complete block of motor limb

questions.text: A patient with a history of broken sleep at night was evaluated, and during his evaluation, it was noted that the appearance of REM sleep occurred within 10 minutes of sleep-onset. He was diagnosed with the classic form of Narcolepsy. Its characteristics tetrad include:
questions.solution:
Options 1,2 and 3 are correct.

Narcolepsy is characterized by the tetrad of: 

  • Excessive daytime sleepiness
  • Cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone)
  • Hypnagogic hallucinations
  • Sleep paralysis

The hallmark of narcolepsy is decreased REM latency, i.e. decreased latent period before the first REM period occurs. Normal REM latency is 90-100 minutes. In narcolepsy, REM-sleep usually occurs within 10 minutes of the onset of sleep (Sleep onset REM).

Treatment: 

  • Sleep hygiene
  • Scheduled naps
  • Avoidance of alcohol and drugs that cause drowsiness
  • Drugs: 
    • Modafinil (wakefulness-promoting drug) is the drug of choice.
    • Amphetamines
    • Methylphenidate

Note: Catalepsy is the passive induction of posture held against gravity.

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

questions.text: You notice the following test is performed in an infant during your orthopedic postings. This test is useful in diagnosing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given test is the Plumb line test that helps to detect tibial torsion which is seen in CTEV.

The child is made to sit on a table with both the lower limbs hanging from the edge. A line is drawn from the center of the patella to the tibial tubercle when extended down should cut the foot at the first or second inter-metatarsal space normally. This is called as plumb line.

In CTEV, with medial rotation of the tibia plumb line cuts the fourth or fifth inter-metatarsal space.

A dorsiflexion test is done in the screening of clubfoot.

 

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: An organism was cultured on the nutrient agar and it produces the following colonies shown in the image with a golden yellow pigment . Which of the following options regarding the development of antibiotic resistance is incorrect for this organism?

choices.text: Methicillin resistance in MRSA- Chromosome mediated
Nafcillin resistance in MRSA- Bacteriophage mediated

questions.solution:
The characteristic colony appearance is shown by Staphylococcus aureus and methicillin, nafcillin resistance on MRSA is chromosome mediated by the mecA (SCCmecA-Staphylococcal Cassette Chromosome mecA)  gene.

The mechanism of vancomycin resistance in staphylococcus aureus is the acquisition of van-A genes which is transposon-mediated. Vancomycin-resistant staphylococcus aureus (VRSA) strains (MICs ≥ 16 μg/mL) is a major concern worldwide now. The vancomycin resistance gene (vanA) is likely derived from enterococci.

 

Characteristics of Staphylococcus growth on nutrient agar:

  • Golden yellow pigmentation on nutrient agar is due to β-carotene.
  • Pigment production occurs optimally at 22°C.
  • On nutrient agar slope, the confluent growth presents a characteristic “oil-paint appearance.”
  • Pigment production is enhanced when 1% of glycerol or milk is incorporated in the medium.

questions.text: You have been asked to evaluate a 32-year-old HIV positive female who presented with headache and nuchal stiffness to the Emergency Medicine department. You have sent samples for routine investigations as well as a CSF sample for microscopic examination with India-ink staining. The life cycle of the causative organism is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of torulosis or Cryptococcosis which is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. It is an opportunistic fungus that is found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings.

It may cause infection in immune-competent persons, resulting in a flu-like illness with complete recovery.

Infection of persons with T cell immune suppression, such as AIDS patients or patients with hematological malignancies, most commonly leads to meningoencephalitis.

 The given life cycle is of Cryptococcus species – Cryptococcus neoformans (common) and Cryptococcus gattii.

Clinical correlate:

  • In immunocompromised patients, both species cause cryptococcosis by inhalation of yeast cells or spores. From the lungs, these yeasts migrate to the CNS and other organs.
  • Cryptococcal meningitis is an AIDS-defining opportunistic fungal CNS infection that generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.
  • The CSF profile may show modest elevations in WBC or protein levels and a decrease in glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated.
  • The diagnosis is made by the identification of yeast cells in CSF with India ink stain or by the detection of Cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination(CrAg).

Treatment:

  • Induction: IV or Liposomal Amphotericin B with Flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative.
  • Maintenance: Oral Fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/μL for 6 months in response to cART.
  • Primary prophylaxis: Oral Fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/μL.

Other options:

Primary amoebic meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri, which is a Facultative parasite. The infection usually follows swimming in the freshwater rivers or ponds. Naegleria fowleri invades the nasal mucosa and passes through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges.

Tularemia is transmitted by hard ticks.

questions.text:
A mother brings her infant expressing concern that the baby turns blue whenever he cries. With respect to Nadas' criteria, all of the following findings are used in diagnosing congenital heart disease, except:

ABG - Arterial blood gas
ECG - Electrocardiogram
questions.solution:
Abnormal ABG finding is not included in Nadas' criteria.

Nadas' criteria are used to diagnose congenital heart disease in children clinically. The presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria indicates congenital heart disease.

The major criteria include:

  • Systolic murmur grade 3 or more
  • Any diastolic murmur
  • Cyanosis
  • Congestive cardiac failure

The minor criteria include:

  • Systolic murmur of grade 1 or 2
  • Abnormal second heart sound
  • Abnormal ECG
  • Abnormal chest X-ray findings
  • Abnormal blood pressure

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman was rushed to the casualty of a maternity hospital due to imminent delivery. It resulted in a stillborn baby as shown in the picture below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an occipital bone defect with retroflexion of the neck and trunk, which is typical of iniencephaly. Inion is the tip of the external occipital protuberance and this defect comes under the spectrum of neural tube defects.

Diastematomyelia (Option A)  is a congenital disorder in which a part of the spinal cord is split, usually at the level of the upper lumbar vertebra.

Craniorachischisis  (Option B) is the anencephaly associated with a continuous bony defect of the spine and exposure of neural tissue.

Holoprosencephaly (Option D) occurs when the procencephalon fails to develop into two hemispheres.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical signs are correctly matched with their respective descriptions?
questions.solution:
Pulsations in the lateral fornix due to the increased vascularity - Osiander Sign

The bluish hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall seen in the first trimester of pregnancy - Jacquiemer's Sign/ Chadwick's sign

Regular rhythmic contractions of uterus felt as early as 6-8 weeks - Palmer's Sign

Marked softening of the cervix in contrast to a non-pregnant state - Goodell Sign

Asymmetric growth occurs in the uterus in the initial stages of pregnancy due to the lateral implantation of the blastocyst. The area of implantation feels soft compared to the other parts - Piskacek’s Sign - 

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida in the third trimester comes with erythematous pruritic papules, plaques, vesicles, and bullae on the abdomen and the extremities arousing suspicion of pemphigoid gestationis. Which of the following are true about it?
questions.solution:
Options 3, 4, and 5 are true.

Pemphigoid gestationis is an autoimmune, bullous disorder that presents mainly during late pregnancy and immediate postpartum. In this disease IgG1 antibodies are produced against BP‐180 or bullous pemphigoid antigen 2, in the hemidesmosomes of the dermo-epidermal junction, leading to tissue damage and blister formation. It was previously called Herpes gestationis, but it is not related to Herpes infection.

Initially, patients present with intense pruritus later manifest skin lesions like plaque and papule characteristically around the periumbilical region but may spread to the entire skin. 

Direct immunofluorescence of perilesional skin is the gold standard in the diagnosis of herpes gestationis which shows linear C3 deposition along the dermo-epidermal junction.

Adverse effects include preterm birth and fetal growth restriction. After the delivery, the maternal lesions resolve without scarring. Most cases manifest in the first pregnancy and the subsequent pregnancies are also mostly affected with the lesions appearing earlier and with a higher severity.

questions.text:
The basis of which of the following processes is depicted in the image below?

DNA- Deoxyribonucleic acid

RNA- Ribonucleic acid

mRNA- messenger RNA
questions.solution:
The process in the given image is RNA editing. 

RNA editing is the process by which the coding sequence of the mRNA is changed before translation by post-transcriptional modification.  

As a result, the mRNA template differs from the DNA from which it was transcribed. This leads to the formation of a different protein. This occurs by the insertion of additional uracils at the 3’ end of the mRNA and proceeds in the 3’ to 5’ direction.

The process of apolipoprotein B48 synthesis involves RNA editing.

RNA editing in apoB synthesis:
  • In the liver, the apoB gene is transcribed to mRNA, which is then translated to apoB-100.
  • In the intestine, the same apoB gene is transcribed to the same mRNA. But now, the mRNA undergoes editing by an enzyme cytidine deaminase, which converts the CAA codon in the mRNA to UAA at a single specific site. This edited mRNA translates to apoB-48.

The production of apolipoprotein (apo) B-48 in the intestine and apoB-100 in the liver is the result of RNA editing in the intestine. Here, a sense codon is changed to a nonsense codon by posttranscriptional deamination of cytosine to uracil.

DNA rearrangement, transposition, and alternate splicing also alter the gene expression but are not the basis of apoB-48 tissue-specific production.

questions.text: The given image shows the x-ray findings of a patient with osteitis deformans. In which phase of the disease are these findings seen?
questions.solution:
The image above shows a blade of grass/ flame-shaped lesion on the x-ray. It is seen in the osteolytic phase of osteitis deformans.

Osteitis deformans is also called Paget's disease of the bone. It is a chronic disease of increased bone turnover in localized areas, resulting in enlarged and thickened bones. There is a significant increase in osteoclastic and osteoblastic activity.

It is usually asymptomatic but can present with dull aching pain unless the disease is severe. Bowing of leg bones may occur. There is an increased risk of pathological fractures and osteosarcoma. 

Paget's disease of the bone is divided into 3 phases:

Phases Pathophysiology X-ray findings
Osteolytic phase Bone resorption and marked hypervascularization An advancing lytic wedge or blade of grass, or flame-shaped lesion.
Mixed phase Very active bone formation and resorption that replaces normal lamellar bone with haphazard (woven) bone.
  • Picture frame vertebra
  • Ivory vertebra
  • Cotton wool skull
Sclerotic phase

Bone resorption declines progressively and leads to a hard, dense, less vascular pagetic or mosaic bone, which represents the so-called burned-out phase of Paget’s disease.

 Tam o' Shanter skull/diploic swelling (thickening of the skull)

Serum alkaline phosphate levels may be raised or maybe normal. Treatment is done using intravenous zoledronate given as a single infusion of 4–5 mg.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female has been diagnosed with a brain tumor after being evaluated for headache and visual symptoms for the past 6 months. After surgery, the cut section of the tumor was sent for histopathological examination, which showed the following findings. Which of the following is not true regarding the body seen in this slide?

choices.text: Can be seen in benign conditions
It is a product of metastatic calcification
Formed by calcification of intralymphatic tumor thrombi

questions.solution:
The above histopathological slide shows a Psammoma body. They are a product of dystrophic (not metastatic) calcification or of a biologically active process that aims at limiting the growth and spread of a tumor.

Psammoma bodies are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by

  1. Infarction and calcification of papillae tips
  2. Calcification of intralymphatic tumor thrombi

Psammoma bodies in Tumors:

  1. Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  2. Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  3. Ovarian papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma
  4. Endometrial adenocarcinoma (Papillary Serous Carcinoma)
  5. Meningiomas
  6. Mesothelioma
  7. Somatostatinoma
  8. Prolactinoma

Psammoma bodies in Benign Conditions:

  1. Endosalpingiosis
  2. Psammomatous melanotic schwannoma
  3. Melanocytic nevus
