questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presented with a complaint of lower backache. The MRI of her lumbosacral spine is given below. Her bone mineral density is measured, and her T-score is -2.8. She is given oral drugs, but she develops esophagitis. Which of the following intravenous treatment plans would be useful in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray depicts the ballooning of disc spaces, leading to the biconcave shape of the vertebral body, which is known as the ‘codfish' appearance. Along with a T-score of -2.8, it is diagnostic of postmenopausal osteoporosis. Zoledronate 5 mg intravenous annually is used in the management of postmenopausal osteoporosis. It belongs to a class of drugs called bisphosphonates.

Bisphosphonates inhibit bone resorption and thus are very effective for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis. They get concentrated at sites of active remodeling and remain in the matrix until the bone is remodeled. Then, they are released in the acid environment of the resorption lacunae and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts.

Routes of administration - Certain bisphosphonates like etidronate, alendronate, risedronate, and tiludronate may be administered orally, while others like zoledronate, ibandronate, and pamidronate can be given intravenously. Intravenous formulations are given when oral formulations cannot be taken due to side effects like esophagitis.

Zoledronate: It can be administered via intravenous infusion for over 15 minutes. It is given once a year, and the dose given is 5 mg for osteoporosis in postmenopausal females. A single 5-mg infusion of zoledronate is also used for the treatment of Paget disease, lowering bone turnover markers for 6 months without losing its therapeutic impact. For patients with hormone-treated prostate and breast cancer, zoledronate is frequently given to prevent osteoporosis. Both vertebral and nonvertebral fractures are decreased by it. For the treatment of multiple myeloma, bone metastases from solid tumors, or hypercalcemia of malignancy, a 4-mg formulation is offered for intravenous administration. 

Other options:

Options A and B - Teriparatide is a recombinant parathormone analog that has an anabolic effect on bone homeostasis when given intermittently. It acts by increasing osteoblastic activity. It increases bone mineral density and decreases the risk of fractures in postmenopausal women. It is administered as a subcutaneous injection of 20 μg once daily.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for osteoporosis:

Risk factor for osteoporosis
Low BMI
Family history of osteoporosis
Old age
Previous fragility fracture
Chronic use of glucocorticoids
Family history of hip fractures
Smoking and alcohol intake
Drugs like anticonvulsants, anticoagulants and thyroid replacement therapy
Hyperparathyroidism, multiple myeloma, and malabsorption syndrome

questions.text: You are studying the pathophysiology of neoplasia associated with strong genetic and chromosomal components. Which of the following tumors are correctly matched with their respective  chromosomal rearrangement?
questions.solution:
Options 1,2 and 3 are correct.

t(8;14) - Seen in Burkitt lymphoma

t(14;18) - Seen in follicular lymphoma

t(14;18)- Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma 

 Chromosomal rearrangement by translocation is shown in the given image.

Burkitt lymphoma

  • It is also known as small non-cleaved-cell lymphoma, is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by the translocation and deregulation of the c-myc gene on chromosome 8.
  • The classic t(8;14)(q24;q32) reciprocal translocation results in the transposition of the c-myc proto-oncogene on chromosome 8 with one of the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH) genes on chromosome 14, which results in activation of the c-myc gene and is considered responsible for tumor proliferation.

 Follicular lymphoma

  • Arises from germinal center B cells
  • Usually, presents in the middle age.
  • (14;18) translocation
  • bcl-2 is the inhibitor of apoptosis and causes promotion of the follicular lymphoma cell.

 

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is molecularly heterogenous and can show all of the given common pathogenic abnormalities are as follows:

  • BCL6 overexpression is most common
  • 10 to 20% cases have t(14;18) leading to overexpresssion of BCL2 (like follicular lymphoma)
  • 5% are associated with MYC translocations (like Burkitts lymphoma)
  • Mutations in gene encoding histone acetyltransferases

DLBCL vs. Follicular lymphoma:

Both are positive for CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6 (germinal-center B-cell origin), while BCL2 is positive in >90% of the cases of follicular lymphoma, it can also be positive in DLBCL. To differentiate them, ki67 index is used. If ki67 >40%, i.e. high, it suggests DLBCL.

 

 

Image: Types of Chromosomal Rearrangement.

questions.text: You are researching about cardioplegic agents that can be delivered through coronary sinus during interventional cardiac surgeries. The drugs which are given in the coronary sinus can reach the myocardium during surgeries through which of the following tributaries?
questions.solution:
Options 2,3 and 4 are correct.

Tributaries of coronary sinus include the following:

  • Great cardiac vein
  • Middle cardiac vein
  • Small cardiac vein
  • Posterior vein of the left ventricle
  • Oblique vein(of Marshall) of the left atrium 

Thebsian vein/venae cordis minimae, anterior cardiac veins, and the right marginal vein drain directly into the right atrium.

questions.text: An ophthalmic surgeon while performing a surgery removes all the contents of an eyeball and leaves only a 3 mm frill of the sclera around the optic nerve. Which of the following is not an indication for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The surgery, which is being performed here is frill evisceration operation which is indicated in all the above conditions except Retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is an indication for enucleation.

Evisceration operation:

It is the removal of the contents of the eyeball leaving behind the sclera. Frill evisceration is preferred over simple evisceration. In this, only about 3mm frill of the sclera is left around the optic nerve.

Indications of evisceration

  • Panophthalmitis
  • Expulsive choroidal haemorrhage
  • Bleeding anterior staphyloma

Enucleation operation: It is the complete excision of an eyeball.

Absolute indications are:

  • Retinoblastoma
  • Malignant melanoma

Note: Indication for eye donation: Removal of eyes from the cadaver is presently the most common indication for enucleation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male was brought to the Emergency department following a road traffic accident. His radiological investigations revealed complete transection of the spinal cord below the level of medulla with intact vagus, what is the expected breathing pattern in this case?

choices.text: Regular breathing continues but depth of inspiration increases

questions.solution:
Complete transection below medulla causes cessation of spontaneous respiration irrespective of vagi status.

  • Complete transection above the pons with vagi intact would result in the continuation of regular breathing.
  • A section at the mid pontine level with vagi intact would result in the continuation of regular breathing and apneusis would result only when the vagi are cut.
  • Transection midway between pons and medulla with intact vagi causes irregular but rhythmic respiration.
  • Transection midway between pons and medulla with cut vagi causes irregular but rhythmic respiration.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old female patient with psoriasis is undergoing the therapeutic modality shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this therapy?

Ultraviolet A - UVA

Ultraviolet B - UVB

Psoralen with Ultraviolet A - PUVA

choices.text: The UVB  spectrum is between 280 and 320 nm
The UVA  spectrum is between 320 and 400 nm
PUVA has a lesser skin cancer risk than UVB
Can be used to treat cutaneous T-cell lymphoma

questions.solution:
The given image shows phototherapy being used as a treatment modality. UVB is generally preferred over PUVA as it has a lesser skin cancer risk than PUVA. It is also easier to administer and its exposure time is shorter. 

Phototherapy is a form of treatment where nonionizing radiations, commonly ultraviolet radiations are used in a controlled manner over the skin. 

Ultraviolet radiation is divided into three groups based on its wavelength- UVA (320-400nm), UVB (280-320nm), and UVC (<280nm).

UVB- Ultraviolet B rays are the rays that have wavelengths between 280 and 320 nm. If all these wavelengths are used it is called a full spectrum. If only 311–313 nm is used, then it is called narrow-band UVB.  It has anti‐inflammatory, immunosuppressive, and cytotoxic properties.

UVA is used in combination with oral or topical psoralen photosensitizer. This combination treatment is termed as PUVA (psoralen with UVA). This leads to crosslinking of DNA with psoralen leading to inhibition of replication, depletion of Langerhans cells, immunosuppression, and restoration of the Th17/regulatory T cell imbalance. 

Phototherapy is used to treat psoriasis, atopic eczema, cutaneous T cell lymphoma, vitiligo, and polymorphic light eruption. 

Phototherapy is contraindicated in dysplastic nevus syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, dermatomyositis, genetic cancer syndrome, bloom syndrome, and medically unfit and uncompliant patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female at 36 weeks of gestation presents with seizures. Her blood pressure is 170/106 mmHg and proteinuria measured via a dipstick test is 3+.  The senior consultant asks you to start the MgSO4 according to Zuspan/Sibai regimen. Which of the following are correct regarding the doses you would administer?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is that of a patient with eclampsia.

MgSO4 regimens: 

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10 g (5O%), deep IM
(5 gm in each buttock)		 5 g (5O%) IM 4th hourly in the alternate buttock
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2 g/h IV infusion

 

The standard management procedure for a patient with eclampsia is:
 

  • Call for extra help (Communication)
  • To put the patient in a left lateral recumbent position
  • Maintain oral airway
  • O2 inhalation – non-breather mask; 10 L/minute
  • Commence IV lines; 1 or 2 wide bore cannulas
  • Foley catheter with a urometer
  • To monitor O2 saturation; pulse oximeter (SPO2 > 95%)
  • Control of seizures: MgSO4, (IV/IM regimens)
  • To monitor vitals; fetal status and magnesium toxicity
  • Control of hypertension: Labetalol, Hydralazine
  • Fluids: Crystalloids (saline) or colloids (albumin/blood) <125 mL/h
  • Suction: oropharyngeal
  • Diuretics: pulmonary edema
  • Investigations to organize: Blood: CBC, AST, ALT, LDH,
  • Creatinine, Uric Acid, Urine analysis - protein

questions.text: The body of a one-year-old boy is brought to the forensics department for examination. To confirm the age, you do an X-ray of the wrist. Which of the following carpal bones will you find ossified for his age?
questions.solution:
Options 2 and 4 are correct.

Capitate and Hamate would appear ossified.

At the end of 1 year, 2 carpal bones are seen in the X-ray of the wrist. Between 2 to 6 years the number of carpal bones present on X-ray roughly indicates the approximate age in years. 

Ossification Centres of Carpal Bones:

  • Capitate: 1-3 months
  • Hamate:  2-4 months
  • Triquetrum: 2-3 years
  • Lunate: 2-4 years
  • Scaphoid: 4-6 years
  • Trapezium: 4-6 years
  • Trapezoid: 4-6 years
  • Pisiform: 8-12 years

The pisiform is the last carpal bone to ossify.

The capitate is the first one to ossify.

questions.text: When you are working as an intern in ENT postings, a child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On examination, you notice a biphasic stridor in the child. This type of stridor is seen in which of the following lesions?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Laryngeal papilloma and subglottic stenosis result in Biphasic stridor.

Stridor is a noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis

questions.text: You notice the following finding in a child during the ophthalmology postings of your internship. This is seen in all of the following conditions except
questions.solution:
The above image shows white reflex in the pupillary area seen in leukocoria and it is NOT seen in congenital glaucoma; In congenital glaucoma, buphthalmos may be seen.

Leukokoria or white pupillary reflex warrants immediate ophthalmologic evaluation and is seen in a variety of pathologic conditions including:

  • Congenital Cataract
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Retinopathy of prematurity ( Retrolental fibroplasia)
  • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous
  • Coats Disease
  • Toxocara endophthalmitis

Note:

Signs of glaucoma include:

  • Corneal edema
  • Corneal and ocular enlargement
  • Conjunctival injection

questions.text: A 30-year-old African farmer presents with a Winterbottom sign. Which of the following is not true regarding the associated disease?

choices.text: It is hemolymphatic disease followed by meningoencephalitis
A vector born disease caused by Trypanosoma brucei
The sign is due to the involvement of anterior cervical nodes
It is transmitted through the bite of a Tsetse fly

questions.solution:
Winterbottom’s sign is due to the involvement of posterior cervical nodes. Winterbottom's sign is the posterior cervical lymphadenopathy seen in African trypanosomiasis.

African trypanosomiasis is a vector born disease caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense/rhodesiense. It is transmitted through the bite of a Tsetse fly.

The clinical syndrome includes hemolymphatic disease with associated Winterbottom's sign and a maculopapular rash primarily involving the trunk. At a later stage, the patient can present with features suggestive of meningoencephalitis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with postmenopausal vasomotor symptoms. She is currently on treatment for hypertension and Alzheimer's disease. She is a known smoker, and her previous ultrasound reports indicate the presence of uterine fibroids.  Which among the following is a contraindication in her for starting hormone replacement therapy?
questions.solution:
The presence of uterine fibroids is a contraindication for HRT, as it may lead to a further increase in the size of the fibroids.

Indication for HRT is as follows:

  • Symptomatic women who suffer from estrogen deficiency
  • High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, Alzheimer’s disease, and colonic cancer
  • Premature menopause following hysterectomy, tubectomy, 
  • Menopause caused by radiotherapy, chemotherapy

Contraindications:

  • Breast cancer, uterine cancer, or family history of cancer
  • Previous history of the thromboembolic episode
  • Liver and gall bladder diseases
  • Uterine fibroids—the fibroids may enlarge in size

Diabetes, hypertension, or smoking are not contraindications for HRT, as long as they are regularly monitored.

Risks of HRT:

  • Endometrial cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Thromboembolism
  • Lipid profile dysfunction
  • Gall stones, liver dysfunction

questions.text: A 48-year-old female, who is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis came with complaints of mild irritation in her left eye. There was no history of pain. The ocular examination showed the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is Scleromalacia perforans, which is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation.

It is typically seen in elderly women with longstanding rheumatoid arthritis. Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Overall, 50% of cases of scleritis are associated with systemic diseases; the most common being connective tissue diseases. About 0.5% of patients suffering from seropositive rheumatoid arthritis develop scleritis.

Other associated collagen disorders are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis

questions.text: A patient delusionally believes that his wife has been replaced by an impostor. Which of the following are variants of this delusion?
questions.solution:
Options 2 and 3 are correct.

A patient that delusionally believes that his wife has been replaced by an impostor is suffering from Capgras syndrome. 

The variants of this delusion include Fregoli syndrome, and Intermetamorphosis.

Misidentification Syndromes:

Capgras syndrome: The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter.

Fregoli’s syndrome: Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people/strangers are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Syndrome of intermetamorphosis: A very rare delusion that familiar persons can change themselves into other persons at will.

Doppelganger syndrome: A person feels he has his own impostor(duplicate) – Delusion of subjective doubles.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A patient is admitted to the ICU with fever, cough with expectoration, and confusion for the past one week. He is diagnosed with an MRSA infection. Which of the following drugs is/are suitable for treating his condition?
questions.solution:
Among the given cephalosporins, Ceftaroline and Ceftobiprole have activity against Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). They are are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

Drug Class Antibacterial spectrum

First generation :

Cefazolin,cephalexin, cefadroxil,cephradine

 Streptococci; Staphylococcus aureus, some Proteus, E. coli, Klebsiella. 

Second generation :

Cefuroxime

Cefuroxime axetil

Cefprozil

Cefoxitin

Cefotetan

Cefmetazole 

 Escherichia coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis. Not as active against gram-positive organisms as first-generation agents.   Inferior activity against S. aureus compared to cefuroxime but with added activity against Bacteroides fragilis and other Bacteroides spp. 

Third generation

Cefotaxime

Ceftriaxone

Cefdinir

Cefditoren pivoxil

Ceftibuten

Cefpodoxime proxetil

Ceftizoxime 

 Escherichia coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis, Citrobacter, Enterobacter; Serratia; Neisseria gonorrhoeae;  Activity for S. aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Streptococcus pyogenes comparable to first-generation agents.  Activity against Bacteroides spp. inferior to that of cefoxitin and cefotetan. 

Antipseudomonal

Cephalosporins 

Ceftazidime  

Ceftazidime/avibactam   

Ceftolozane/tazobactam

Cefepime 

   Gram-negative activity similar to third-generation with the addition of activity against Pseudomonas; poor activity vs. gram-positive organisms.   Expands ceftazidime’s activity against Pseudomonas and multidrug-resistant Enterobacteriaceae, but not against gram-positives.   Similar to ceftazidime, with enhanced activity against Pseudomonas and extended-spectrum β-lactamase-producing Enterobacteriaceae.   Comparable to third-generation but more resistant to some β-lactamases (especially those of Pseudomonas and Enterobacter); gram-positive activity similar to cefotaxime. 

Anti-MRSA Cephalosporins 

Ceftaroline

Ceftobiprole 

    Similar activity to 3rd generation but with activity against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus 

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: A 40-year-old villager presents with ataxia, hallucinations, and convulsions. On further inquiry, it is found that his staple food had the following unusual appearance. Which of the given statements are true regarding the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
The given image contains ergot on wheat, and he is likely to be suffering from ergotism. options 2, 3 and 5 are true about it.

 Ergotism: Ergot alkaloids exert their primary CNS effects by stimulating adrenergic receptors, both centrally and peripherally. They directly stimulate muscle fibres. Ergot is commonly used as an abortifacient.

Clinical features

  • Acute poisoning:
    • GI - Nausea, Vomiting, Diarrhoea
    • CNS Effects - Headache, Giddiness
    • Respiratory - Chest Tightness, Difficulty in Breathing
    • Musculoskeletal - Weakness, exhaustion, tingling, numbness, paraesthesia 
  • Chronic poisoning:
    • Tingling & Numbness
    • Dry Gangrene due to vasomotor disturbance
    • Tactile hallucination - Formication

questions.text: A young man was brought dead following deliberate consumption of the given plant. All of the aspects of this plant are true, except ______.

choices.text: Smoke from burning plant carries the toxic material
Can be detected even from the burnt dead body

questions.solution:
The given plant is Nerium odorum, all parts of the plant are poisonous, except the roots.

Oleanders: They are of two varieties - 

  • Nerium odorum or white oleander -
    • Bears with white or pink flowers
    • All parts of the plant are poisonous except the roots
    • They contain cardiac glycosides - primarily oleandroside (oleandrin) and nerioside (nerin)
    • The nectar of the flower yields poisonous honey
  • Cerbera thevetia or yellow oleander -
    • All parts of the plant are poisonous
    • All active principles are glycosides

The manifestations of Nerium odorum poisoning includes contact dermatitis, headache, dizziness, respiratory difficulty and nausea. Ingestion may lead to vomiting, abdominal pain, frothy salivation and diarrhea. Initially, there is bradycardia followed by tachycardia and again weak pulses. Other changes include hypotension, fibrillation, AV block, mydriasis, tetanic spasms, lock-jaw, drowsiness, and coma. Death is usually from cardiac failure. 

The manifestation of Cerbera thevetia poisoning include burning sensation in the mouth, tingling of the tongue, dryness of the throat, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, dilated pupils, irregular action of the heart followed by drowsiness, coma, collapse, and death.

Postmortem appearances: Organs appear congested. The Nerium resists heat, therefore can be detected even from the burnt dead body.

Medicolegal aspects: Suicide with this is common among villagers, accidental poisoning can also be seen, but homicide is rare. It is also used as cattle poison. Smoke from burning plants carries toxic material.

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

questions.text: The dense granules of platelets contain___
questions.solution:
Options 3 and 4 are correct. Dense (or δ) granules of platelets contain ionized calcium and serotonin.

Platelets have two types of cytoplasmic granules:

  • Alpha
  • Delta (dense)

Dense (or δ) granules contain:

  • Adenosine triphosphate
  • Adenosine diphosphate (adp)
  • Ionized calcium
  • Serotonin

α-Granules contain :

  • Adhesion molecule p­-selectin on their membranes
  • Proteins involved in coagulation
    • Fibrinogen
    • Coagulation factor V
    • vWF
  • Protein factors involved in wound healing
    • Fibronectin
    • Platelet factor 4 (a heparin­ binding chemokine)
    • Platelet ­derived growth factor (PDGF)
    • Transforming growth factor­ β

questions.text: The table shows the examination findings of various psychiatric emergencies presenting with fever and altered sensorium. Which of the following is corresponding to the findings seen in serotonin syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option (B) i.e. row 2 has findings corresponding to Serotonin syndrome.  

Serotonin syndrome is a serious condition occurring due to serotonin overstimulation. Clinical features include diarrhea, restlessness, agitation, hyperreflexia, autonomic instability with fluctuations in vital signs, myoclonus, seizures, hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, rigidity, delirium, coma, status epilepticus, cardiovascular collapse, and death. 

It can occur with any drug that increases serum serotonin levels like MAOIs (monoamine oxidase inhibitors), SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants), tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA (amphetamine), dextromethorphan, etc.

It is treated with cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist). 

Other options-

Option (A): Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a rare condition that occurs on administration of neuroleptic (antipsychotic) drugs. It presents with autonomic instability, hyperpyrrexia, rigidity, and delirium. Sustained rigidity leads to muscle breakdown and elevated creatinine kinase levels. NMS will not show the hyperreflexia and clonus seen in serotonin syndrome. The causative drug should be stopped immediately and treatment can be started with dantrolene and bromocriptine.

Option (C): Anticholinergic syndrome can occur due to concurrent use or use of higher doses of strong anticholinergic drugs like cyproheptadine or diphenhydramine. It will present with anticholinergic symptoms like blurring of vision, dry mouth, constipation, etc. Hyperreflexia and hypertonia would not be seen in this condition. 

Option (D): Malignant hyperthermia is seen in the setting of neuromuscular blockade administration in the operating room, such as succinylcholine. It presents with elevated body temperature, muscle rigidity, hypotension, muscle breakdown, etc. The drug of choice to treat this condition is intravenous dantrolene.

 

Related Pearl: Psychiatric emergency: Fever with altered mental status

In a clinical setting of fever with altered mental status, it is important to differentiate between the following.

 Syndrome
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Serotonin syndrome
Anticholinergic syndrome
Malignant hyperthermia
 Cause
Dysregulation of dopaminergic pathways
Co-prescription of MAO-I and SSRIs leading to increased serotonin and norepinephrine levels
Anticholinergic intoxication
Halogenated anesthetics and succinylcholine leading to a
hypermetabolic response causing an increased intracellular calcium level

Stop antipsychotic;
give dantrolene, bromocriptine and monitor CPK levels

questions.text: A patient is undergoing nephrectomy of the right kidney for a benign disease through a posterior surgical approach. You are a junior resident assisting in this surgery, and your senior asks you to mention the posterior relations of this kidney, you would say:
questions.solution:
Options 1,3 and 5 are the posterior relations of the right kidney.

The posterior relations of the kidneys are as follows:

  • Vessels (1): Subcostal vessels
  • Ligaments (2): Medial and Lateral Arcuate ligaments
  • Nerves (3): Subcostal, Iliohypogastric, and Ilioinguinal nerves
  • Muscles (4): Diaphragm, Psoas major, Quadratus lumborum, and Transverses abdominis.
  • The right kidney is related to the 12th rib and the left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th ribs

The anterior relations of the right kidney include:

  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Second/descending part of the duodenum
  • Liver
  • Hepatic flexure of the colon
  • Small intestine

The anterior relations of the left kidney include:

  • Left suprarenal gland 
  • Stomach
  • Pancreas
  • Jejunum
  • Spleen
  • Splenic vessels
  • Splenic flexure and the beginning of the descending colon

questions.text: During the dermatology postings, you came across a few patients who presented with the complaints of appearance of new skin lesions in a previously normal skin that has been subjected to trauma. In which of the following conditions, this type of true response/phenomenon is seen?
questions.solution:
Koebner’s phenomenon, which is shown by Vitiligo, Lichen Planus, and Psoriasis.

Koebner’s phenomenon/ isomorphic response is the development of lesions in previously normal skin that has been subjected to trauma.

Any of the following can elicit an isomorphic response: physical trauma, including friction, pressure, incision and laceration, skin grafting, bites, vaccination skin tests, burns, freezing, and ultraviolet (UV) and ionizing radiation.

It is seen commonly associated with psoriasis, lichen planus, and vitiligo.

Note:

If the same response is seen from the spread of an infective agent ( like molluscum contagiosum, viral warts), it's called pseudo-koebner’s phenomenon.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: A 48-year-old factory worker was brought to the emergency department due to the splash of the chemical reagent in his right eye. On examination, the cornea looks hazy, the iris details are visible, and less than one-third of the limbus is found ischaemic. What is the grade of chemical injury according to Roper-Hall classification?
questions.solution:
The patient is having grade 2 chemical injury according to Roper-Hall classification. It is used to assess the severity of chemical injuries.

Chemical injuries to the eye:

  • Alkali burns are twice as common as acid burns.
  • Alkalis tend to penetrate more deeply than acids, as the latter coagulate surface proteins, forming a protective barrier.
  • Most commonly involved alkalis are ammonia, sodium hydroxide, and lime.
  • Grading of severity (Roper–Hall system)
    • On the basis of corneal clarity and severity of limbal ischemia
      • Grade 1  is characterized by a clear cornea (epithelial damage only) and no limbal ischemia (excellent prognosis).
      • Grade 2 shows a hazy cornea but with visible iris detail and less than one-third of the limbus being ischemic (good prognosis).
      • Grade 3 manifests as a total loss of the corneal epithelium, stromal haze obscuring iris detail, and between one-third and half of the limbus showing ischemia (guarded prognosis).
      • Grade 4 manifests with an opaque cornea and more than 50% of the limbus showing ischemia (poor prognosis).

questions.text: A 62-year-old Caucasian man had a fever, malaise, myalgia, and diarrhoea for 3-4 days. Following this, he developed tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension and was admitted to the emergency. He gave a history of rodent infestation in his apartment, and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary edema. Which of the following can be the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome caused by the Hanta virus.

Transmission of Hantavirus occurs by inhalation of the virus contained in dried excreta of rodents. Hantaviruses are natural pathogens of rodents like mice, rats, and voles. 

Patients may initially have symptoms like fatigue, fever, myalgia, and GI symptoms for 3-4 days. This may then progress to pulmonary edema. Tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension can develop in severe cases. This is known as Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome. 

Hantavirus infection can also present as hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS). 

Hantavirus is a bioterrorism category C agent. Hanta and Nipah viruses are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future because of availability, ease of production, dissemination, the potential for high morbidity and mortality rates, and major health impact.

Other options:

Option A: Legionella causes Pontiac fever and Legionnaire's disease. Legionnaire's disease presents with fever, non-productive cough, and dyspnea, which rapidly progresses to pneumonia if left untreated. Diarrhea and encephalopathy are also common. It is often included in the differential diagnosis of atypical pneumonia. Pontiac fever presents with a mild influenza-like illness. Infection is typically caused by inhalation of aerosols produced by cooling towers, air conditioners, and showerheads, which act as disseminators. No animal reservoirs exist, no human-to-human transmission occurs, and no carrier state is established.

Option C: Bunyavirus infection causes encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, and fever. Most bunyaviruses are mosquito-borne.

Option D: Leptospira can cause Weil's disease. A history of fever with liver (icterus) and kidney(hematuria) involvement should arouse suspicion of leptospirosis (Weil's disease). Hemorrhages (petechiae and purpura) can also be seen. Rats are the most important reservoir of leptospira.

Note- The family Bunyaviridae contains four medically important genera- Bunyavirus, Phlebovirus, Nairovirus, and Hantavirus. They are RNA viruses that are mostly arthropod-borne. Hantavirus is rodent-borne.

Related Pearl: Bioterrorism Agents

questions.text: A 70-year old diabetic female complains of frequent urination, but no pain or burning micturition. She has an urgency to pass the urine but passes urine before reaching the lavatory.  Which of the following drugs is not indicated in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of urge incontinence or overactive bladder and Duloxetine is not useful in this case.

Duloxetine is not useful in detrusor instability. It is a selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor that is indicated in depression, fibromyalgia, and neuropathic pain.

Muscarinic antagonists increase bladder capacity by blocking M3 receptors on detrusor. This results in the relaxation of the bladder. M3 receptor selectivity is shown by solifenacin and darifenacin. Tolterodine also shows a preference for muscarinic receptors on the bladder.

The effects of muscarinic antagonists on the bladder are:

  • Lowering of intravesicular pressure
  • Increases bladder capacity
  • Lower the frequency of bladder contractions
  • Alter bladder sensation during filling

Related Pearl: Muscarinic antagonists indicated for detrusor instability/overactive bladder

Mechanism/Feature Drug
Direct smooth muscle relaxant  

Flavoxate

Oxybutynin
Bladder selective  

Tolterodine

Fesoterodine (prodrug)
Only quaternary compound   Trospium
M3 selective  

Darifenacin

Solifenacin

questions.text: A 35-year-old man had a little stooped posture as shown on the right, and he was advised to exercise the following action(on the left) at the scapula to correct his posture. The advised exercise is facilitated by the muscles:
questions.solution:
The given action is the retraction of the scapula, and it is facilitated mainly by Trapezius and Rhomboids muscles.

The trapezius is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI). It causes retraction of scapula, shrugging of the shoulder and overhead abduction (along with serratus anterior). Paralysis of trapezius causes drooping of the shoulder and slight winging of the scapula (the superior angle of scapula becomes more prominent).

Rhomboids minor and major are also prime movers of the scapula in retraction.

Movements:

  • Protraction: Serratus anterior
  • Retraction: Middle trapezius, Rhomboids
  • Elevation: Upper trapezius, Levator scapulae
  • Depression: Lower trapezius

questions.text: The histology slide of cartilage is given below.  Which of the following statements is incorrect about this type of cartilage?

choices.text: It predominantly consists of type II collagen

questions.solution:
The given image shows fibrocartilage. The incorrect statement about this cartilage is that it mainly contains type 2 collagen. A fibrocartilage contains both type 1 and 2 collagen but is predominantly made of type I collagen.

Fibrocartilage contains a mixture of white fibrous tissue and cartilaginous tissue. This mix of fibrous and cartilaginous components makes this tissue extremely tough and resilient. It consists of bundles of collagen fibres (both type I and II) with rows of chondrocytes present between the bundles. They are not covered by perichondrium.

On microscopy, fibrocartilage can be identified by the presence of chondrocytes and the matrix containing abundant collagen fibres. 

Fibrocartilage is found in:

  • Intervertebral discs
  • Pubic symphysis
  • Manubriosternal joint
  • Menisci of the knee
  • Glenoid and acetabular labra
  • The lining of the bony grooves for tendons
  • Articular disc of temporomandibular and sternoclavicular joint

The image below shows - hyaline cartilage, fibrocartilage, and elastic cartilage respectively. 

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

Type of Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage Elastic Cartilage Fibrocartilage
Colour Bluish opalescent Yellow White

questions.text: A 24-year-old male was brought to the casualty following a stab injury to the abdomen. Immediate laparotomy was performed and penetrating injuries to the retroperitoneum were noted. Identify the true statements regarding the various techniques performed for the exploration of abdomen in this case.
questions.solution:
Option 1, 4, and 5 are true regarding the various techniques performed for the exploration of the abdomen in the given case.

Penetrating injuries to the retroperitoneum identified during laparotomy require exploration and repair.

Various surgical maneuvers are done to explore different regions of the abdomen based on the location of the injury / Hematomas.

Mattox maneuver :

  • It involves medial visceral rotation on the left side.
  • This is achieved by dividing the peritoneum along the entire left side of the abdomen, from above the spleen down to the distal left colon. The plane posterior to the colonic mesentery and the pancreas is developed, and the abdominal viscera are retracted to the right to expose the superior retroperitoneal vasculature.
  • This allows exploration of injuries to the suprarenal great vessels and the left renal hilum.

Cattell-Braasch maneuver:

  • It involves medial visceral rotation on the right side.
  • This allows exploration of hematomas located in the infrarenal vasculature and the right renal hilum.

Kocher maneuver is performed to allow inspection of the duodenum, pancreas, and other retroperitoneal structures over to the great vessels

questions.text: A senior resident gives chance to the junior resident to induce anesthesia in some of the patients who were posted for surgery under general anesthesia (GA). Which of the following patients would require a lower dosage of inhalational anesthetic agent for the purpose of induction?
questions.solution:
Among the given options only Hypothermic and Hypercalcemic patients undergoing surgery requires a lower dosage of anesthetic agent.

Chronic alcoholics, Hypernatremic patients, and cocaine abusers would require a higher amount of anesthetic agent. 

Minimum Alveolar Concentration of an inhaled anesthetic agent is the alveolar concentration that prevents movement in 50% of patients in response to a standardized stimulus such as surgical incision.

Various factors alter the minimum alveolar concentration of an anesthetic agent. In those patients, in whom a factor which increases MAC are present, require a larger amount of anesthetic agent and in those with factors which decreases MAC are present, require a lower amount of anesthetic agent.

Factors increasing MAC:

  • Chronic alcohol abuse
  • Hypernatremia
  • Cocaine abuse
  • On Ephedrine drugs
  • Hyperthermia more than 42-degree celsius

Factors decreasing MAC :

  • Hypothermia
  • Hyperthermia ( < 42 degree celsius )
  • Acute alcohol intoxication
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hyponatremia

 

Related Pearl: Factors affecting Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC)

Factors increasing MAC Factors decreasing MAC No change in MAC
Hyperthermia >42°C Acute alcohol intoxication  Hyperthyroidism
Chronic alcohol abuse Hypothermia and hyperthermia up to 42°C Hypothyroidism
Acute amphetamine use  Older age (>6 months MAC decreases 6% per decade)  
Drugs: Cocaine, Ephedrine Chronic amphetamine abuse  
Hypernatremia  Drugs: Opioids, Ketamine, Barbiturates, Benzodiazepines, Sympatholytics   
Young age (<6 months; MAC is maximum at 6 months) Hyponatremia, Hypercalcemia  
  Hypotension  
  Hypercarbia, Hypoxia, Metabolic acidosis  
  Pregnancy

questions.text: You are making a diagrammatic representation of protein synthesis initiation in eukaryotes. Which of the following factors will you correctly mark in the formation of preinitiation and initiation  complexes during the steps of protein synthesis?
questions.solution:
The eukaryotic initiation factor (eIF) are accessory proteins that help in initiation of protein synthesis.

Functions of eIF:

  • eIF-3, eIF-1 & eIF-1A: Prior to the initiation of protein synthesis 80S ribosome dissociates into 40S and 60S subunits. eIF-3, eIF-1 & eIF-1A bind to newly dissociated 40s ribosomal subunit and delays the re-association of 40s and 60s.
  • eIF-2: It is involved in the formation of the binary complex (GTP+eIF-2). This complex binds to met t RNAi to form ternary complex GTP-eIF-2-tRNAi. This ternary complex then binds to the 40S ribosomal subunit to form the 43S preinitiation complex. This is the first step of initiation. eIF3, 1A, and subsequent binding of eIF-5 stabilize the 43S preinitiation complex.
  • eIF-4F: It is a cap-binding complex, which facilitates the binding of mRNA to 43S preinitiation complex by binding to the 5′ terminal of mRNA molecules which are capped. The association of mRNA to 43S requires ATP hydrolysis, which is caused by the action of eIF-4B helicase. The mRNA would then bind to the 43S preinitiation complex to form the 48S initiation complex, in the second step of initiation.
  • eIF-5: It is involved in the hydrolysis of GTP bound to eIF2. This results in binding of 60s subunit with 48s initiation complex to form the 80s initiation complex. This is the third step of initiation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient, who was diagnosed with a ventral hernia, is planned for mesh hernioplasty. The mesh is considered to be well placed if it covers all margins of the defect by a distance at least ________.
questions.solution:
The mesh should cover all the margins of the defect by at least 20 mm (2 cm) for it to be considered as a well-placed mesh. A well-placed mesh should have good overlap around all the margins of the defect by at least 2 cm and up to 5 cm if possible.

Mesh hernioplasty involves placing a tension-free prosthetic mesh over the hernia defect. It also strengthens the hernia repair after the defect is closed with sutures. Sometimes, a 3-dimensional mesh is kept in the defect to prevent future herniation through the defect. 

The most appropriate mesh used in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores.

Lightweight meshes generally contain less material and induce a less-pronounced foreign body reaction and decreased inflammatory response, which results in better tissue incorporation, increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.

Meshes with large pores exhibit less inflammatory infiltration, connective tissue, and scar bridging, which allows increased soft tissue ingrowth. They have greater elasticity and flexibility and also shrink less than other meshes. This results in fewer adhesions, better tissue incorporation, and less patient discomfort and pain than that observed with other meshes. 

Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological mesh depending on their composition.

Synthetic meshes are more commonly used these days. They are made from polymers of polypropylene, polyester, or PTFE polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE). 

Polypropylene Polyester PTFE
Monofilament multifilament solid
Hydrophobic hydrophilic hydrophobic
Rigidity elastic rigid

PTFE meshes are hydrophobic and have a higher risk of adhesion compared to polyester meshes.

Biological meshes are acellular matrix materials derived from humans or animals and have fewer complications than other meshes. But due to poor collagen deposition and absorption, they rapidly lose mechanical strength, and hence, their use is restricted to infected environments. 

Note: Microporous meshes (e.g, ePTFE) and multifilament meshes are at higher risk of infection because macrophages and neutrophils are unable to enter small pores (< 10 μm). This allows bacteria (< 1 μm) to survive unchallenged within the pores and braids.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-viral drugs are correctly paired with their respective class?
questions.solution:
Options 2,4 and 5 are correct.

Nevirapine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI).

Abacavir is a guanosine analogue and is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor.

Nelfinavir, saquinavir, and ritonavir are protease inhibitors.

Tenofovir is not a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. It is a nucleotide monophosphate analogue and is classified as a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NtRTI).

Nucleoside + Monophosphate = Nucleotide 
All NRTIs except tenofovir act here   Tenofovir, that is NtRTI acts here

Maraviroc is an Entry inhibitor.

Related Pearl: Classification of antiretroviral drugs

CLASS DRUGS
Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Zidovudine, Stavudine, Lamivudine, Abacavir, Emtricitabine, Didanosine
Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Tenofovir
Non-nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Nevirapine, Efavirenz, Delavirdine, Etravirine
Protease Inhibitors Saquinavir, Indinavir, Ritonavir, Nelfinavir, Lopinavir, Atazanavir, Tiprinavir, Darunavir
Entry Inhibitors Enfuvirtide, Maraviroc
Integrase Inhibitors Raltegravir, Elvitegravir, Dolutegravir

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented in the crawlers stage of lathyrism. Probing reveals that he has a history of consuming khesari dal. Which of the following are correct about this condition?
questions.solution:
Neurolathyrism is seen in humans and osteolathyrism is seen in animals. Vitamin C is used as prophylaxis in lathyrogenic diets.

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus.

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of lower limbs. In animals, it is referred to as osteolathyrism/odoratism because the pathological changes in the bones lead to skeletal deformities. 

It usually affects the young males aged 15-45 years and it is manifested in stages: 

  • Latent stage
  • No-stick stage
  • One-stick stage
  • Two-stick stage
  • Crawler stage

BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine) is the toxic compound causing Lathyrism. The water-soluble property of the toxin is used in removing from the pulses by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water. Although it is considered as irreversible, Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism.

The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act in India has banned Lathyrus sativus in all forms(whole/split/flour).

Related Pearl: Food adulteration diseases

Food Adulterant Toxin Disease
Dal Khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus) BOAA* Lathyrism
Oil Argemone mexicana (oil) Sanguinarine Epidemic dropsy
Millet Crotalaria seeds (Jhunjhunia) Pyrrolizidine alkaloids
(Hepatotoxic)		 Endemic ascites 
Bajra, wheat Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids Ergotism

 * BOAA-Beta Oxalyl Amino Alanine

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents with fever, flank pain, and dark-colored urine. He has a history of blood transfusion one week back. The test shown in the given image is positive. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of delayed hemolytic reaction following blood transfusion, which is caused by antibodies that recognize red cell antigens that the recipient was sensitized to previously. It is IgG-mediated and gives a positive result in the direct Coombs test ( shown in the image ).

  • Acute hemolytic reactions are usually caused by preformed IgM antibodies against donor red cells that fix complement. The direct Coombs test is usually positive. 
  • Delayed hemolytic reactions are caused by antibodies that recognize red cell antigens that the recipient was sensitized to previously, for example, through a prior blood transfusion. These are typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with a positive direct Coombs test and laboratory features of hemolysis (e.g., low haptoglobin level and elevated lactate dehydrogenase [LDH]).

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

(Seconds-minutes)

Shock, respiratory distress, angioedema

Stop transfusion immediately, give epinephrine

(Within 2-3 hours)

Recipient IgE against donor components causing mast cell activation

Urticaria, flushing, pruritus

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

(within 6h)

 

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

Antibodies against donor WBC and HLA antigens (sensitization)

Cytokine accumulation during blood storage

More common in multipally transfused patients and multiparous women

Fever and chills sometimes with mild dyspnoea

Transfusion can be stopped if symptoms are severe

Prevention: Leukoreduced products

Supportive care

Pre-existing high affinity IgM antibodies rapidly induce complement mediated lysis, intra-vascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria

Hemoglobinuria

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction

occurs after 24 hours ( usually 2 weeks )

Recipients have prior exposure to RBC antigens. After the transfusion, anamnestic response results in antibody production

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Mild fever, hemolytic anemia

Coomb’s test positive

Screening for new antibodies positive

Supportive care

Additional transfusions if needed

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia

  • Transient hypotension

questions.text: Thiazolidinediones are a selective agonist of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-gamma (PPAR-γ). The given  receptor is an example of _________
questions.solution:
(PPAR-γ) receptors belong to the family of nuclear receptors. Thiazolidinediones are a selective agonist of nuclear peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR-γ). They modulate the expression of genes involved in lipid and glucose metabolism, insulin signal transduction, and adipocyte differentiation. These effects increase the sensitivity of the tissues to insulin.

Pioglitazone and rosiglitazone are used to treat patients with type 2 diabetes. 

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypothyroid female patient presents with a painless, hard anterior neck mass, which progresses over weeks to years associated with dysphagia. Physical examination reveals a hard, “woody” thyroid gland with fixation to the surrounding tissues. Which of the following investigations will confirm the provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Riedel’s thyroiditis,  which is confirmed by an open thyroid biopsy.

FNAC is inadequate due to the firm and fibrous nature of the gland.

Riedel’s thyroiditis is invasive autoimmune fibrous thyroiditis where thyroid gland tissue is replaced by fibrous tissue. It is an IgG4-related systemic disease characterized by:

  • Elevated serum IgG4 levels
  • Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate
  • Abundance of IgG4 bearing plasma cells

It is associated with other focal sclerosing syndromes including mediastinal, retroperitoneal, periorbital, retro-orbital fibrosis, and sclerosing cholangitis.

Clinical features:

  • Occurs predominantly in women between 30-60 years
  • Painless, hard anterior neck mass
  • Progresses over weeks to years to produce symptoms of compression:
    • Dysphagia
    • Dyspnea
    • Choking
    • Hoarseness
  • Symptoms of hypothyroidism and hypoparathyroidism as the gland is replaced by fibrous tissue
  • Physical examination reveals a hard, “woody” thyroid gland with fixation to surrounding tissues

Treatment includes surgery, high-dose steroids, tamoxifen, and thyroxine replacement.

questions.text: A 40-year-old construction worker involves in work where he gets repeatedly exposed to the noise of around 100 dB at the construction site. This could lead to ____
questions.solution:
Repeated exposure to the sound of 100 dB can lead to permanent hearing loss.

Effects of Noise Exposure

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when the sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text: You were asked to do a fundoscopic examination of all the babies admitted in the pediatric ward. You notice the following fundoscopic finding in one of the babies. Which of the following metabolic disorders results in the given fundoscopic appearance?
questions.solution:
The given fundoscopic image shows a cherry-red spot.

Among the given options only GM1 gangliosidosis and GM2 gangliosidosis are the metabolic storage disorders which can give rise to cherry-red spot.

Cherry red spots appear in the context of thickening and loss of transparency of the retina at the posterior pole. The fovea, being the thinnest part, allows persistent transmission of underlying choroidal hue and appears red due to the underlying vascularity

Other options:

Cherry red spot is seen in Niemann Pick Disease type A and B and not in type C

Farber disease can result in a cherry-red spot at macula but not in Fabry’s Disease. 

Traumatic cause for the appearance of cherry red spot includes Commotio retinae (edema due to blunt trauma ). It is not a metabolic cause

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with a 7-day history of a generalized pruritic rash, which started around the neck, without a history of cough, fever, or rhinorrhea. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a large number of minute thin-walled vesicles on the trunk, consistent with a diagnosis of miliaria.

Other options:

Option A: Folliculitis would involve specific inflammation in the pilosebaceous units.

Option B:  Infantile acne would have characteristic comedones, papules, and pustules. Moreover, the question states the boy is 4 years old. 

Option D: Candidal infections usually occur as macerated erythematous lesions in the intertriginous areas.  

Note: Milia, conversely, are tiny keratin‐filled, epithelial‐lined cysts that are not connected to the overlying skin.

Related Pearl: Different types of miliaria

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions.

Based on the level of blockade it is differentiated into

  • Miliaria Crystallina- Stratum corneum
  • Miliaria Rubra - Malpighian Layer
  • Miliaria profunda - Dermoepidermal junction

Pathophysiology:

  • The first event may be an increase in the skin flora, perhaps with Staphylococcus epidermidis being responsible for producing an extracellular polysaccharide substance or slime that blocks the lumen of the sweat duct.
  • The parakeratotic plugs, a notable feature of the later stages of the disease, are not the primary cause of the obstruction but arise in the repair process, and further aggravate the obstruction.
  • Leakage of sweat into the epidermis is responsible for the final production of the lesions, and for their further aggravation.
  • Miliaria crystallina occurs commonly in infants due to a delay in the development of patency in the sweat ducts.

Clinical features:

  • Miliaria crystallina: Clear, thin‐walled vesicles, 1–2 mm in diameter without an inflammatory areola, are usually symptomless and develop in crops, mainly on the trunk. In persistent febrile illnesses, recurrent crops may occur. The vesicles soon rupture and are followed by superficial, branny desquamation.

 

  • Miliaria rubra: Typical lesions develop on the body, especially in areas of friction with clothing, and in flexures. The lesions are uniformly minute erythematous papules, which may be present in very large numbers. Characteristically, the lesions produce intense discomfort in the form of an unbearable pricking sensation. Relief is often instantaneous when the stimulus to sweating is abolished by a cool shower. In infants, lesions commonly appear on the occluded skin of the neck, groins and axillae, but also occur elsewhere.

 

 

  • Miliaria profunda: This nearly always follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra, and is common only in the tropics. The lesions are easily missed. The affected skin is covered with pale, firm papules 1–3 mm across, especially on the body, but sometimes also on the limbs. There is no itching or discomfort from the lesions.

 

Treatment:

  • First line
    • Control local environment (remove excess bedding, fans, air
    conditioning)
    • Cool the skin (damp compresses, cool showers)
    • Avoid tight or excessive clothing
  • Second line
    • Menthol (e.g. 0.5% menthol in aqueous cream)
    • Topical antibiotics if there is secondary infection
    • Mild topical steroids
  • Third line
    • Removal to cooler climate
    • Prophylactic oral vitamin C

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice the following nail finding. Which of the following conditions would you suspect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows leukonychia totalis. Leukonychia is a prominent feature of hypoalbuminemic states. 

Leukonychia is the opaque whitish discoloration of the nail.

It is seen in the following conditions:-

  • Dietary deficiency: Protein-energy malnutrition, pellagra, zinc deficiency
  • Drugs: Cytotoxic agents, Steroids, Retinoids, Pilocarpine
  • Dermatological pathology: Alopecia areata, erythema multiformae, exfoliative dermatitis, and SLE
  • Systemic diseases: Liver cirrhosis, renal failure, and cardiac failure.
  • Miscellaneous: Trauma, malignancy, and toxins (arsenic, fluoride).
  • Idiopathic

Note: The leukonychia secondary to arsenic poisoning is termed - leukonychia striata/Aldrich–Mees lines.

questions.text: A dead body was brought to the forensics department for post mortem and the finding given in the image below is seen. Which of the following is true about the fixation of the given finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows postmortem hypostasis, options 2 and 5 are true about the fixation of hypostasis.

Lividity of death: Postmortem lividity (suggilation, postmortem hypostasis/postmortem staining/livor mortis/vibices) develops in the dependent portions of the body due to engorged vessels showing through the skin.

Fixation of hypostasis usually occurs 6 – 12 hours after death. It occurs earlier in summer and delayed in asphyxial deaths and in intracranial lesions. Fixation happens due to the leak of blood to surrounding soft tissue due to hemolysis or breakdown of vessels. The condition of blood at the time of death considerably influences fixation.

Timing:

  • Mottled patches – 1-3 hours following death.
  • Uniform area of staining – 3-6 hours following death.
  • Fully developed and fixation of hypostasis – 6-12 hours.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy complains of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever and profuse ear discharge. Clinical examination shows mastoid tenderness and perforation of the tympanic membrane. If the pus in this infection breaks through the bony wall between the antrum and external osseous meatus, it results in the formation of  a _____________
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute mastoiditis that has occurred as a complication of acute infection of the middle ear. If the pus in this infection breaks through the bony wall between the antrum and external osseous meatus, it results in the formation of Luc abscess(Meatal Abscess) and presents as a swelling in the deep part of the bony meatus

Other abscesses related to mastoid infection:

  • Post auricular abscess - Commonest abscess that forms over the mastoid. In infants and children, this presents over the MacEwen’s triangle.
  • Zygomatic abscess - infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma
  • Bezold abscess - In this case, the pus breaks through the medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck
  • Citelli’s abscess - Here, the abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more towards the occipital bone

questions.text: An epidemiologist is tasked with ensuring the disinfection of wells in a city to reduce the spread of water-borne illnesses. 30 grams of bleaching powder was required to disinfect 2275 liters of well water. When measuring the chlorine demand with the Horrocks apparatus for this well water, which cup would have shown the blue color after adding the indicator?
questions.solution:
Horrocks apparatus used to measure chlorine demand of water. The 3rd cup would have shown a blue color for it to require 30 grams of bleaching powder to disinfect 2275 liters of well water.

Since 2275/455=5, the amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 liters of water is 30/5=6 grams

To calculate the dose of bleaching required to disinfect 455 liters of water, the formula is (n×2), We know the dose required, and we have to calculate 'n' (n represents the position of the cup which was first to show the color).

6=n×2, therefore n=3.

The third cup would have turned blue upon adding the indicator.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with intense pruritus. On evaluation, blood pressure was 128/80mm Hg, no proteinuria was found, and all liver enzymes were within the normal limits. A diagnosis of Obstetric cholestasis is made. Which of the following is true about its pathophysiology and clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Options 3 and 5 are true.

Obstetric cholestasis is also referred to as recurrent jaundice of pregnancy, cholestatic hepatosis, and icterus gravidarum. It is the second most common cause of jaundice in pregnancy, the first being viral hepatitis. Pruritis /itching is the predominant symptom, although jaundice occurs only in 10% of cases.

It is characterized clinically by pruritus, icterus, or both. It is more common in a multifetal pregnancy. Pruritus develops in late pregnancy (usually during the third trimester— 80% present after 30 weeks ), although it occasionally manifests earlier. It is more in palms and soles, interestingly pruritus may precede laboratory findings by several weeks.

The recurrence rate is high being around 50-60%.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a chronic alcoholic presented to the emergency room following two episodes of hematemesis and is currently hypotensive. The surgical resident on duty tries to control the bleeding with the instrument shown in the below image. Identify this instrument?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the Minnesota tube.

The given clinical scenario i.e chronic alcoholic with haematemesis is suggestive of esophageal variceal bleeding, in which temporary hemostasis can be achieved with the help of balloon tamponades.

Minnesota tube:This tube allows the aspiration of both gastric and oesophageal contents. It has 4 openings – 2 suction tubes and 2 inflation tubes - namely,

  • Gastric aspiration port
  • Oesophageal aspiration port
  • Gastric balloon port
  • Oesophageal balloon port

Protocol-based management of esophageal varices is given below:

Other options:

Option A- Sengstaken-Blakemore tube has 3 lumens. It has ports for gastric and esophageal balloons and a gastric aspiration port as shown below.

Option C- Linton-Nachlas tube has only two ports and a single gastric balloon. Below is the image showing various balloon tamponades.

Option D- Ewald tube is a stomach tube used in the removal of poisons through gastric lavage. It has only one aspiration port for the stomach as shown below.

questions.text: The image shows a graph plotted between the rate of reaction (on the y-axis) and substrate concentration (on the x-axis). Which of the following statements is not true regarding this plot?

choices.text: It is not seen with monomeric enzymes
The enzyme may have multiple binding sites

questions.solution:
Follows Michaelis Menten kinetics statement is not true regarding this plot. 

The given plot shows a sigmoid curve suggestive of cooperative binding of the enzymes to their substrates. This type of saturation kinetics is explained by Hill equation. 

Michaelis - Menten Kinetics:

The Michaelis - Menten equation gives the mathematical relationship between initial reaction velocity, v, and substrate concentration [S] which is as given below.

v = Vmax[S]/Km+[S]

where Km is the substrate concentration at which vi is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2) which is reached at a particular concentration of the enzyme.

A graph showing a hyperbola is suggestive of Michaelis - Menten kinetics of the enzyme which is as follows.

For enzymes showing Michaelis - Menten kinetics, there is an increase in the rate of reaction, V, with an increase in substrate concentration till a point Vmax is reached beyond which rate of reaction shows saturation.

Hill equation:

Allosteric enzymes are those for which catalysis at the active site may be modulated by the presence of effectors at an allosteric site.

This is the exclusive property of multimeric enzymes, which have multiple binding sites for enzymes. This property is analogous to oxygen binding by haemoglobin. This is not seen in monomeric enzymes.

As Michaelis Menten equations cannot be used, the Hill equation is used to describe the kinetics of positive cooperative binding.

Allosteric enzymes have one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds.

questions.text: A 4-week old infant presented to the emergency department with projectile, nonbilious vomiting after feeding. On examination, a firm ovoid abdominal mass with hyperperistalsis is present. What is the Investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Ultrasound examination is the Investigation of choice for this condition. Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. Cervix sign and Nipple sign are signs of Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis in USG.

 CHPS typically presents with the following:

  • Non-bilious vomiting, which is progressive, projectile, occurring immediately after a feed, usually presents after the 3rd week of age. 
  •  Physical examination reveals a firm, ovoid, 1 to 2 cm abdominal mass, and abnormal left to right hyperperistalsis is seen.
  • As the vomiting continues, a progressive loss of fluid, hydrogen ions, chloride ions, and potassium leads to hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

Pathogenesis: Hyperplasia of the pyloric muscularis propria, which obstructs the gastric outflow tract.

Treatment: Surgical splitting of the muscularis (Ramstedt pyloromyotomy) is curative.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV patient presented to the OPD with intractable diarrhea for the past 3 months. His stool was examined which showed the following oocysts. Which of the following are true about this parasite?
questions.solution:
Options 1 and 3 are correct.

Oocysts passed in the feces are immediately infectious in the case of cryptosporidium parvum, as they are sporulated oocysts.

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian parasitic infestation. The image shows a blue background and red-stained oocysts suggest modified acid-fast stain positive Cryptosporidium parvum.

Points in favor:

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are round, containing four sporozoites which are uniformly acid-fast on staining.

In other coccidian parasites namely, cyclospora and isospora, unsporulated oocysts are passed in the stool. Unsporulated oocysts take days or weeks to become infectious, and because of this, direct person-to-person transmission through fecal exposure is unlikely to occur.

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

Property  Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Isospora
Sporulated oocyst 4-6 μm, round contains four sporozoites 8-12 μm, round contains 2 sporocysts each having two sporozoites 23-36 μm, oval contains two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection Uniformly acid-fast Variably acid-fast Uniformly acid-fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst

Treatment is fluid replacement and cotrimoxazole.

 

Modified acid-fast staining (like Kinyoun stain) showing oocysts of Cyclospora cayetanensis.

Kinyoun stain positive images of Isospora:
