questions.text: A gynecologist is comparing Amsel's criteria and quantitative Bacterial PCR in a study with Nugent's score as the gold standard for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis. Which of the following bacteria are used as the main morphotypes in the gold standard test?
questions.solution:
Options 1, 3, and 4 are correct.

Nugent's score evaluates 3 types of bacteria via Gram stain:- Lactobacillus, Bacteroides/Gardnerella, and Mobiluncus.

Nugent's score is a gram stain based scoring system of vaginal smears to diagnose bacterial vaginosis. It is calculated by assessing for the presence of:

  • large gram-positive rods (Lactobacillus morphotypes; decrease in Lactobacillus scored as 0 to 4),
  • small gram-variable rods (G. vaginalis morphotypes; scored as 0 to 4), and
  • curved gram-variable rods (Mobiluncus spp. morphotypes; scored as 0 to 2)

They are each graded on a scale of 1+ to 4+

  • 1+ is < 1 cell per field
  • 2+ is 1-5 cells per field
  • 3+ is 6-30 cells per field
  • 4+ is >30 cells per field
Lactobacillus Gardnerella/Bacteroides Mobiluncus(Curved Gram variable rods) Points
4+ 0 0 0
3+ 1+ 1+ and 2+ 1
2+ 2+ 3+ and 4+ 2
1+ 3+   3
0 4+   4

Total scores are then calculated and used as follows:- 0-3 (Normal), 4-6 (intermediate bacterial count), and 7-10 (bacterial vaginosis).

Amsel criteria is also used to detect Bacterial Vaginosis, which includes

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine like odour on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

questions.text: When you are working in a tertiary care center, many patients were brought to the hospital following an explosion which took place in the nearby city. You notice various types of injuries in these patients. Identify the true statements regarding the mechanism of the injuries.
questions.solution:
Option 1, 2, and 5 are true statements regarding the mechanism of the injuries seen during explosion.

Blast injuries are multisystem life-threatening injuries that are caused by explosions. These injuries can be classified into following  types,

Primary blast injuries 

They result from the rapid overpressure or shock waves produced by an explosion. These injuries result from the dramatic changes in barometric pressure projected from the point of detonation.

Primary blast injuries predominantly cause damage to air-filled hollow organs of the body from rapid pressure change (barotraumas). Damage to air-filled organs includes middle ear, lungs, and GIT.

Secondary blast injury:

It refers to the effect of fragments that are accelerated away from the device following detonation. Sources of fragments include casing of the device or purposefully placed fragments within the device(such as nails, bolts) or nearby objects including glass and stones.

Tertiary Blast Injury: Injuries resulting from the victims being thrown by the high winds produced by the blast waves.

Quaternary blast injury refers to a miscellaneous group of injuries that do not fall within other categories. examples include burns, inhalational injuries.

Quinary injury is a more novel concept, refers to injury caused by the intentional addition of either biologically or radioactively active material to an explosive device.

Classification

Mechanism of injury

Examples

Primary

Overpressure

Tympanic membrane injury, Blast Lung, Intestinal blast injury.

Secondary

Flying debris penetrating/ fragmentation

All penetrating injuries.

Tertiary

Blast wind

Victim is thrown in air and strikes other objects leading to blunt trauma, crush injuries, and traumatic amputation

Quaternary

Any complicating factor not in the other three categories

Burns, Inhalational injury

Quinary blast

Biologically or radioactively active material

  

Radiation sickness

questions.text: Which of the following would you not expect to be the cause in a child with obstructive hydrocephalus?
questions.solution:
Choroid plexus papilloma is a cause of communicating hydrocephalus, and not a cause of obstructive hydrocephalus.

Hydrocephalus is not a specific disease; it represents a diverse group of conditions that result from impaired circulation or absorption of CSF. 

Causes of hydrocephalus

  • Communicating (increased production or reduced absorption)
    • Achondroplasia (raised ICP due to jugular foramen stenosis)
    • Choroid plexus papilloma
    • Meningeal malignancy
    • Meningitis
    • Posthemorrhagic
  • Noncommunicating (obstructive)
    • Aqueductal stenosis
    • Infectious (toxoplasmosis, mumps)
    • Inherited (X-linked, mitochondrial, autosomal recessive, autosomal dominant)
    • Chiari malformation
    • Dandy–Walker malformation
    • Klippel–Feil syndrome
    • Mass lesions
    • Hematoma
    • Tumors and neurocutaneous disorders
    • Vein of Galen malformation

questions.text: During your surgery internship, you observe the following incision was made by the senior resident while performing an abdominal surgery. What is the name of the incision  being performed here?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Chevron (rooftop) incision.

Chevron (rooftop) incision is a bilateral anterior subcostal incision joined in the midline. It can be used to access the organs of the upper abdomen and diaphragm.

A Mercedes-Benz modification of this incision includes a midline incision superiorly, providing further access to the upper abdomen or the lower mediastinum.

Other options:

Option A: Kocher’s incision is a right subcostal incision, which is commonly used in open cholecystectomy surgeries.

Option B: Mayo Robson’s incision is a right upper paramedian incision extended like a hockey stick to the midline. It is indicated in cholecystectomy

Option D: Rutherford-Morrison’s incision is an oblique muscle-cutting incision, with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally, as necessary.

questions.text: A 4-year old child presented with low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection. He also developed an erythematous rash on the cheek which progressed to the extremities the following day as shown below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most common manifestation of parvovirus B19 infection is erythema infectiosum, also known as the fifth disease, which is a benign, self-limited exanthematous illness of childhood. Affected children are afebrile or have a mild fever and do not appear ill. ( as in this child)

  • The hallmark of erythema infectiosum is the characteristic rash, which occurs in 3 stages
    • The initial stage is erythematous facial flushing, often described as a “slapped cheek” appearance
    • The rash spreads rapidly or concurrently to the trunk and proximal extremities as diffuse macular erythema in the 2nd stage
    • Central clearing of macular lesions occurs promptly, giving the rash a lacy, reticulated appearance
  • The rash tends to be more prominent on extensor surfaces, sparing the palms and soles.

 

B19 and HBoV (human bocavirus) are the only 2 parvoviruses known to be pathogenic in humans.

 

Other options:

Fever is characteristically high with Scarlet fever and Kawasaki disease (unlike in this patient)

The malar rash which is pathognomonic of SLE involves the cheek, bridge of nose and lower eyelids; Discoid lesions are rare in childhood; photosensitivity rash may be present

questions.text: You are a junior doctor posted for duty in Covid-19 wards. You have been given 5 antibody tests of different patients to interpret as shown below, which among the given tests will you consider as positive?
questions.solution:
Options 3, 4 and 5 are correct.

In a typical lateral flow immunoassay cassette test:

  • “C” control band
  • “M” band indicates the presence of IgM
  • “G” band indicates IgG is detected

Interpretation:

  • Control band and no antibody bands- negative test result
  • Lack of control band, despite both antibody bands being present- an invalid result
  • IgG band is detectable and the control band is present, colour intensity should not be interpreted quantitatively- a positive result
  • IgM band is detectable and the control band is present, colour intensity should not be interpreted quantitatively- a positive result
  • Both IgM and IgG bands are present, in addition to the control band- a positive result

questions.text: A person has been bitten by the following snake. Which of the following options describe the symptoms seen classically in this snake bite?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows common krait, which is neurotoxic and shows classical symptoms such as muscle paralysis.

The neurotoxicity symptoms that would be seen in the patient include: 

  • headache
  • blurred vision
  • perioral paraesthesia
  • hyperacusis
  • dizziness
  • vertigo
  • gooseflesh
  • vomiting
  • hypersalivation

Neurotoxicity effects are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase or they may wear off spontaneously in about a week.

Other options:

Option A: Anaphylaxis is seen in poisoning due to stiletto snakes. Other symptoms include pain, swelling, blisters and local lymph node enlargements.

Option B: Systemic bleeding such as intravascular hemolysis, ecchymosis and incoagulable blood is seen in bites due to back fanged snakes.

Option C: Myoglobinuria is seen in poisoning due to sea snakes.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of snake venom

  • Krait

questions.text: A 30-year-old businessman came to the hospital with complaints of loin pain along with fever and hematuria.  X-ray KUB of this patient is shown below. Which of the following ions is least likely to have contributed to the formation of this stone?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray KUB showing a staghorn appearance is suggestive of struvite calculi, which is formed due to precipitation of  magnesium,ammonium, and phosphate.

Struvite stones (triple phosphate stones)  are usually seen in a setting of infection with urease producing bacteria like Proteus, Pseudomonas, and Staphylococcus. They can grow very large and form a cast of the renal pelvis and calyces resulting in staghorn calculi. Production of urease enzyme by Proteus, which hydrolyses urea to ammonia causes alkalinization of urine. Alkalinization of urine leads to precipitation of organic and inorganic compounds which contributes to the formation of Struvite stones. 

 

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: You notice the following prosthetic limb is being used in a person who had undergone lower limb amputation during your postings. Which of the following statements is true regarding the given prosthesis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the prosthesis of Jaipur foot. Options 3 and 4 are true with respect to Jaipur foot.

Commonly used foot prosthesis includes:

  • Jaipur foot
  • Solid ankle cushion heel (SACH)
Prosthesis  SACH Jaipur foot

Absent

Note: It is possible to walk on uneven grounds with Jaipur foot as subtalar movements (inversion and eversion) are present.

The above features make Jaipur foot more suitable for indian scenario.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male who presented with Low-grade fever, intermittent pain, and swelling in the left lower limb along with raised ESR was diagnosed with Garre's osteomyelitis. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Options 2, 4 and 5 are true regarding Garre's Osteomyelitis.

Garre's Osteomyelitis:

This is a Sclerosing, non-suppurative chronic osteomyelitis.

It is caused by a low-grade anaerobic infection which is effectively contained by the host immune system. Hence, there is no abscess or sequestrum formation. There is no discharging sinus,  Only diffuse enlargement of bone at the affected site is present. Diaphysis of tubular bones are commonly affected.

It is usually seen in children or young adults, who typically presents with Low-grade fever, intermittent pain, and swelling.

This condition is characterized by an excessive periosteal reaction at the affected site of the bone, causing marked sclerosis and cortical thickening and Hence X-ray shows increased bone density and cortical thickening with no abscess cavity.

 

The given radiograph shows Garre's osteomyelitis:

questions.text:
Mark the following statements true or false regarding surfactant replacement therapy.
  1. The surfactant should be warmed prior to administration
  2. The surfactant vial should be shaken well to ensure good mixing
  3. Chest X-ray is not mandatory for confirmation of ET tube position
  4. ET tube position change is mandatory between the administration of each aliquot
  5. Suctioning of ET tube should be done every half an hour for 2 hours post-administration of surfactant
questions.solution:
The surfactant should be warmed prior to administration - True

The surfactant should be warmed prior to administration (for 8 minutes between the palms or for 20 minutes at room temperature.) The vial should not be heated and it should not be kept on a radiant warmer. It should not be kept in room air for more than 30 min as it increases viscosity.

The surfactant vial should be shaken well to ensure good mixing - False

The surfactant vial may be rolled but it should not be shaken.

Chest X-ray is not mandatory for confirmation of ET tube position - True

The baby is intubated with an appropriate size endotracheal tube and breath sounds equality is assessed. A chest x-ray is not mandatory for confirmation of the ET tube position.

ET tube position change is mandatory between the administration of each aliquot - False

The surfactant is administered through a feeding tube inserted in the ET tube or through the side port of the ET tube. Surfactant is given as bolus instillation in four aliquots of the total dose. No position change is required between the aliquots.

Suctioning of ET tube should be done every half an hour for 2 hours post-administration of surfactant - false

Suctioning of ET tube should be avoided at least 2 hrs following surfactant administration

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient was brought to the emergency department with complaints of severe headache, vomiting, and progressive weakness of the right upper and lower limb weakness. A CT image of the patient is shown. Which of the following drugs is best suited to reduce morbidity in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the patient presenting with complaints of headache, vomiting, and paralysis and the CT image showing blood in the cistern is suggestive of subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) where nimodipine is best suited to reduce morbidity.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage is the hemorrhage in the subarachnoid space between the arachnoid and pia mater, mixed with CSF.

After head trauma, it is mostly caused as a result of the rupture of a saccular aneurysm. Other causes include bleeding from a vascular malformation such as arteriovenous malformation or dural arteriovenous fistula and an intracerebral hemorrhage extending into the subarachnoid space.

Some SAHs may be limited to the perimesencephalic cisterns and is arterial in origin but there could be a venous or capillary source. Manifesting features are due to raised intracranial pressure.

Nimodipine is indicated to relieve a neurological deficit occurring secondary to cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid haemorrhage. It is a member of the dihydropyridine group of calcium channel blockers and causes vasodilation in cerebral blood vessels. It is lipid-soluble and has a high affinity for cerebral blood vessels and appears to reduce morbidity after subarachnoid haemorrhage.

questions.text: A young male patient, with a history of blunt abdominal trauma, was brought to the ER. As he was hemodynamically unstable, and FAST examination revealed free fluid, an immediate laparotomy was done. Since severe bleeding from the liver was present, the following maneuver was done to visualize the injury but, the bleeding continued even after clamping. Identify the correct statement regarding this maneuver.
questions.solution:
The image shows clamping of hepatoduodenal ligament, which is done in Pringle maneuver. Options 1,2, and 4 are correct with respect to this maneuver.

Pringle maneuver:

  • When severe bleeding from the liver is present, the Pringle maneuver is a valuable adjunct to slow blood flow enough to visualize the injury.
  • The hepatoduodenal ligament is encircled with a vessel loop or vascular clamp to occlude hepatic blood flow from the hepatic artery and portal vein.
  • This maneuver helps distinguish hepatic arterial and portal venous bleeding from hepatic vein bleeding, which will persist with the hepatoduodenal ligament clamped.
  • In many cases, the liver laceration can then be explored and any actively bleeding vessels controlled with suture ligation.
  • Hepatic parenchyma that appears to be devitalized should be debrided and drains should be placed when injuries appear to be at risk for a bile leak.
  • A vascularized pedicle of the omentum may reduce parenchymal bleeding and promote healing of the laceration when it is packed with the liver injury

Note:

Ischemia and portal hypertension are complications that result from either prolonged clamping time during the Pringle maneuver or normal clamping time in patients with compromised liver function (eg, from cirrhosis).

questions.text: A 3-day-old male child presented with lethargy, poor feeding and hypotonia. An inborn error of metabolism (IEM) panel was sent which revealed HHH Syndrome. Which of the following statements are correct regarding this disease?
questions.solution:
HHH syndrome (hyperammonemia, hyperornithinemia and homocitrullinuria) is due to ornithine transporter defect.

  • It is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder caused by a defect in the transport system of ornithine from the cytosol into the mitochondria (deficiency of ornithine permease/translocase), resulting in the accumulation of ornithine in the cytosol and a deficiency of this amino acid in mitochondria.
  • The former causes hyperornithinemia, and the latter results in the disruption of the urea cycle and hyperammonemia.
  • Homocitrulline is formed from the reaction of mitochondrial carbamyl phosphate with lysine, which can become a substrate for the OTC reaction when ornithine is deficient, leading to homocitrulliuria.

Components of HHH syndrome:

  • Hyperammonemia
  • Hyperornithinemia
  • Homocitrullinemia

Citrullinemia-ll is due to citrin defect.

Hyperargininemia is seen in cases of defective arginase.

Hyperuricemia is not a component of HHH syndrome

questions.text:
A method of development of drug resistance is shown below. This method is not the primary mode of resistance to which of the following drugs? 
(Extracellular environment - above the membrane, Intracellular environment - Below the membrane)
questions.solution:
Efflux pumping of the drug is shown in the GIF above. It is the primary mode of resistance for Chloroquine, mefloquine, halofantrine, lumefantrine, quinine, etc . It is mediated by an ABC transporter encoded by P. falciparum multidrug resistance gene 1 (Pfmdr1). 

Ciprofloxacin resistance is developed mainly by reduced affinity to the altered target.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient with an abdominal mass was diagnosed with gestational trophoblastic neoplasia. On further evaluation, it is found that neoplasia has metastasized to the liver and lungs. What would be the clinical staging according to FIGO classification?
questions.solution:
The patient would be classified to have stage-IV gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN).

International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) Staging for GTN is as follows:

  • Stage I - Confined to the uterus
  • Stage II - GTN extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structures
  • Stage III - GTN extends to the lungs, with or without known genital tract involvement
  • Stage IV - All other metastatic sites.

This patient with metastasis to the liver and lungs has Stage IV disease.

GTN includes tumors that cause aggressive invasion of the endometrium and myometrium by trophoblastic cells. This includes invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumor, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumor. GTN is diagnosed based on elevated β-hCG levels. Criteria for diagnosis of GTN:

  • Persistence of β-hCG level plateau in 4 measurements for 3 weeks or longer
  • Rise in β-hCG levels in 3 or more consecutive measurements done weekly, over a period of 2 weeks or longer
  • Elevated β-hCG level for 6 months or more
  • Histologic diagnosis of choriocarcinoma.

A modified prognostic scoring system by the WHO distinguishes patients at low risk for therapeutic failure from those at high risk. Treatment for the low-risk disease is chemotherapy with methotrexate, while those with high-risk disease are treated with etoposide, methotrexate, and dactinomycin alternating with cyclophosphamide and vincristine (EMA/CO) chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and FIGO staging of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Risk factors

  • Older age
  • β-hCG levels > 100,000 mIU/mL
  • Uterine size that is large-forgestational age
  • Theca-lutein cysts > 6 cm
  • Slow decline in β-hCG levels
  • Postevacuation uterine sonographic surveillance showing myometrial nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia.

FIGO staging:

Stage I Disease confined to the uterus
Stage II GTD extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structure
Stage III Lung metastasis with or without genital tract involvement
Stage IV Other metastasis

questions.text: A psychiatrist started his patient on lithium carbonate tablets 900 mg OD for the management of mania. A partial improvement was seen. The serum lithium levels done one week later were found to be 0.5 mEq/L. What should be done next?

choices.text: Wait for improvement with the same dosage

questions.solution:
The given blood lithium levels are inadequate for the treatment of mania. The next best step is to increase the dose of lithium carbonate for the optimal management of acute mania. The treatment of mania requires blood levels to be higher than 0.8 mEq/L.

Lithium is used in the management of bipolar disorder, mania, and has anti-suicidal properties. It has a narrow therapeutic index, and higher blood levels may cause symptoms of toxicity. Therapeutic drug monitoring is done by measuring lithium levels 12 hours after the previous dose. 

Other options:

900mg OD is generally the starting dose of lithium carbonate. Because of variable excretion and blood levels are variable in individuals. Weekly blood level monitoring is necessary to avoid toxicity and for dose titration.

Wait and watch is not the best option here because the optimal therapeutic level has not been achieved yet. Acute mania gradually resolves in 2 weeks with optimal treatment.

Sodium valproate alone or in combination with antipsychotics is the preferred agent for acute mania because it has a faster onset of action.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A 17-year-old  boy presents with a tremor in the right arm as shown below when arms are held outstretched with opposing the fingers, which began a year ago and has gradually progressed to the other arm too. Examination revealed a characteristic greyish rim at the limbus of the cornea on slit-lamp examination. He had also developed dysarthria and dysphagia. Which of the following is/are correct regarding the workup/management of the suspected diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution:
Options 1, 2 and 3 are correct.

The tremor shown is wing-beating tremor characteristically seen in Wilson's disease.

Wilsons disease:

The autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioural disturbances
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) Ring:

  • KF ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea
  • Characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomic
  • Does not interfere with vision
  • Present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms
  • Absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

Diagnosis:

    • Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

Treatment: Trientine and Zinc is the first choice of a drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

Recommended Anticopper Drugs for Wilson's Disease

Disease Status First Choice Second Choice
Initial hepatic    

Hepatitis or Cirrhosis without decompensation

 Zinc Trientine
Hepatic decompensation    
Mild Trientine and Zinc Penicillamine and Zinc
Moderate Trientine and Zinc Hepatic transplantation
Severe Hepatic Transplantation Trientine and Zinc
Initial neurological/Psychiatric Tetrathiomolybdate and Zinc Zinc
Maintenance Zinc Trientine
Presymptomatic Zinc Trientine

questions.text: As a factory medical officer, you are screening the workers for occupational hazards related to Light.  You would look out for
questions.solution:
Of the conditions listed, only Miner's nystagmus is the occupational hazard related to Light. 

Light:

Poor illumination has acute effects like eye strain, headache, eye pain, lacrimation, congestion around the cornea, and eye fatigue. It has chronic effects like 'Miner's nystagmus'. Glare/excessive brightness can cause discomfort, annoyance, and visual fatigue.

Other options:

  • 'Welder's flash'(Keratitis) is associated with ultraviolet radiation exposure.
  • White fingers (Increased sensitivity to spasm): effect of prolonged exposure to Vibration as seen in work with drills and hammers.
  • Chilblains/pernio are painful inflammations of skin related to cold exposure.

questions.text: An anatomy student while studying the structures forming the roof of the mouth notices the regions 'A" and 'B" as shown in the below image. Which of the following vessels supply the region marked as "A"?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as "A" in the above image is Hard Palate, which is mainly supplied by the greater palatine artery.

The palate forms the roof of the mouth and is divisible into two regions namely, Hard palate in front and soft palate behind

The boundary between the hard and soft palate is readily palpable and may be distinguished by a change in colour, the soft palate being a darker red with a yellowish tint.

Blood supply of the palate:

  • The hard palate is mainly supplied by the greater palatine artery which is a branch of the third part of the maxillary artery.
  • The soft palate is supplied by the ascending palatine branch of the facial artery, ascending pharyngeal artery, and lesser palatine arteries.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl has deliberately drunk phenol in an attempt to commit suicide. She complains of hot burning sensation extending from mouth to stomach. Which of the following statement is false regarding this?

choices.text: Methaemoglobinaemia is an associated feature in severe cases
It causes numbness by damaging the nerve endings
It is excreted in urine as hydroquinone and pyrocatechol

questions.solution:
Carbolic acid/Phenol is a corrosive acid, however, it hardens the GI mucosa producing a leather bottle stomach and anesthetizes the nerve endings. Gastric lavage is not contraindicated in phenol poisoning.

Poisoning by carbolic acid is called carbolism.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Local skin effects: Burning, tingling followed by anesthesia and greyish white sloughing 
  • Headache, giddiness, tinnitus
  • Vomiting, diarrhea, pain abdomen
  • Muscular spasms, convulsions
  • Collapse
  • A clammy, cold sweating body
  • Pupils contracted

In severe cases, hemolysis and methemoglobinemia are a characteristic feature.

In carbolic acid poisoning if the patient survives for 48 hrs there will be carboluria followed by anuria. The victim will pass dark, smoky urine which soon turns olive green on standing due to oxidation of hydroquinone and pyrocatechol. 

In patients with acute poisoning, the stomach should be washed repeatedly. Initially with plenty of lukewarm water containing activated charcoal, olive oil, castor oil, magnesium or sodium sulphate, or saccharated lime with which phenol combines and forms harmless products. A soap solution or 10% glycerine may be used and the washing continued until the washings are clear and odorless.

Once the above is done, the administration of olive oil or vegetable oil is done to remove surface phenol and prevent deep penetration. When lavage is completed, 30 g. of magnesium sulfate or a quantity of medicinal liquid paraffin should be left in the stomach.

Related Pearl: Urine Color caused by certain Toxins

Urine colours

Causes

Olive green colour urine on standing

Carbolic acid

Grey-black

Phenols, cresols

Opaque appearance which settles on standing

Primidone crystals

Orange or orange-red

Rifampicin, iron (especially after giving desferrioxamine)

Related Pearl: Typical appearance of Stomach Mucosa in some Poisoning

Poison

Appearance of Gastric Mucosa

Arsenic

Red velvety mucosa

H2SO4

Brown or black with erosion perforation and Carbolization

Carbolic acid

Grey leathery and thickened mucosa

HNO3

Yellow

HCN

Pink

KCN

Brick red to brown

Phosphorous

Yellow or grey white

questions.text: The mother of a newborn in your unit is extremely sick and is unable to feed her baby. The relatives have arranged a breast milk donor and wish to feed the baby using the device shown in the image. This method of primary feeding can be recommended in newborns with a gestational age of _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows paladai. It can be used as a primary feeding method during routine feeding in neonates born at gestational age 32-34 weeks only. Sick mothers or mothers with contraindications to breastfeeding can feed their child using paladai. The milk can either be expressed breastmilk or they can resort to using undiluted cow milk or formula feeds. 

<32 weeks will not have the coordination between swallowing and breathing. So, paladai can only be used occasionally.

>34 weeks will have a completely mature sucking pattern when breastfeeding becomes more preferred.

Choice of initial feeding methods in low-birth-weight (LBW) infants

Gestational Age Feeding Skill Matured Method of Feeding
<28 weeks No proper sucking effort. No propulsive motility of the gut IV Fluids
28-32 weeks

Sucking Bursts develop

No coordination between suck/swallow and breathing

 Oro-gastric/ Nasogastric tube feeding with occasional spoon/ paladai feeding
32-34 weeks Slightly mature sucking pattern. Coordination between breathing and swallowing begins Feeding by spoon/paladai/cup
>34 weeks Mature sucking pattern. More coordination between breathing and swallowing Breastfeeding

questions.text: The following structure (arrowed) is marked during an anatomy practical exam. Which of the following structure does not contain the same type of white matter fibre present in the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the fornix which contains the association fibres. The commissure of the fornix/Hippocampal commissure is made up of commissural fibres, not association fibres. 

The fornix is a part of the connecting pathways of the limbic system. It arises from the hippocampus which wraps around the thalamus and ends in the mammillary body. It connects the hippocampus with distal brain sites. 

The fornix has two types of fibres:

  • Association fibres: They connect the various cortical regions within the same hemisphere 
  • Commissural fibres: They connect the corresponding regions of two hemispheres. It is seen in the hippocampal commissure of the fornix. 

It is supplied by the anterior communicating artery arising from the anterior cerebral artery. The fibres present in the fornix are association fibres except for the hippocampal commissure of the fornix which has commissural fibres. 

Uncinate fasciculus and the Cingulum contains long association fibres. Arcuate fasciculus/U fibres have short association fibres. 

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: Cells in the cerebellum which release GABA as neurotransmitters are:
questions.solution:
Options 1, 3, 4 and 5 are correct.

The neurotransmitters released by the stellate, basket, Golgi, and Purkinje cells are GABA, whereas the granule cells release glutamate

The fundamental circuits of the cerebellar cortex :

  • Climbing fibres exert a strong excitatory effect on single Purkinje cells. Mossy fibres exert an excitatory effect on granule cells. Each granule cell sends an axon to the molecular layer, where the axon bifurcates to form a T. The branches of the T are straight and run long distances; thus, they are called parallel fibres. The parallel fibres form excitatory synapses on the dendrites of many Purkinje cells.
  • The other neurons (basket cells, stellate cells and Golgi cells) are inhibitory interneurons. Basket cells and stellate cells receive excitatory input from the parallel fibres and each inhibits many Purkinje cells. Golgi cells receive excitatory input from the parallel fibres and mossy fibres. Their axons project to the dendrites of the granule cells where they form an inhibitory synapse.
  • The output of the Purkinje cells is, in turn, inhibitory to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

Related Pearl: Cerebellar Circuitry

Cerebellar circuitry includes:

Afferents- Climbing and mossy fibers

  • Climbing fibers -
    • Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata
    • Terminates on - Purkinje cell
  • Mossy fibers -
    • Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem
    • Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

  • Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells
  • Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

  • The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei
  • The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei
    • Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle
    • Fastigial - via inferior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: In the image of the bacterial RNA polymerase given below, which subunit  enables RNA polymerase to recognize promoter regions on the DNA and thus helps to position it correctly on the template DNA?
questions.solution:
The σ subunit (sigma factor) enables RNA polymerase to recognize promoter regions on the DNA and thus helps to position it correctly on the template DNA. Thus, the σ subunit enables the core enzyme to recognize and bind the promoter region to form the preinitiation complex (PIC).

Following this, the RNA Polymerase catalyzes the formation of the first phosphodiester bond, and the nascent chain is attached to the polymerization site on the β subunit of RNA Polymerase. This reaction is termed initiation. The β subunit also binds to the Mg ion.

Related Pearl: RNA polymerase in Humans and Their Major Products

Types

Major Products

RNA polymerase I

rRNA

RNA polymerase II

mRNA, miRNA, snRNA, lncRNA

RNA polymerase III

tRNA, 5srRNA

questions.text: A child born prematurely at 31 weeks was referred to you for ROP screening. In which of the following conditions of ROP, you would classify this child as high-risk pre-threshold and advise for laser photocoagulation?
questions.solution:
Zone I: Stage 3 with No plus disease and  Zone I: Stage 1 with Plus disease should be advised for photocoagulation

Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP): It is a proliferative retinopathy seen in premature infants with low birth weight who often have been exposed to a high concentration of oxygen

Stages of Retinopathy of Prematurity:

  • Stage 1: Demarcation line formation at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the avascular retina.
  • Stage 2: Intraretinal ridge formation
  • Stage 3: Ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous.
  • Stage 4: Subtotal retinal detachment
  • Stage 5: Total retinal detachment

"Plus" disease" signifies a tendency to progression and is characterized by the dilatation and tortuosity of blood vessels involving at least two quadrants of the posterior fundus.

Concentric zones centred on the optic disc are described.

  • Zone I is bounded by an imaginary circle, the radius of which is twice the distance from the disc to the center of the macula.
  • Zone II extends concentrically from the edge of zone I; its radius extends from the center of the disc to the nasal ora Serrata.
  • Zone III consists of a residual temporal crescent anterior to zone II.

 

ROP that requires treatment with Laser photocoagulation:

  • Zone I, any stage ROP with plus disease or
  • Zone I, stage 3, with or without plus disease
  • Zone II, stage 2 or 3 ROP, with plus disease

Not to treat, but weekly follow up:

  • Zone I, stage 1 or 2 non-plus disease or
  • Zone II, stage 3 non plus disease

questions.text: While performing the following procedure on a 35-year-old male at a distance of 1 meter, you found out that the red reflex was not moving with the movement of the instrument. How will you interpret your findings?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the procedure of retinoscopy (skiascopy) being performed. As the red reflex is not moving with the movement of the retinoscope, the patient is interpreted as having myopia of 1D.

Retinoscopy is an objective method of determining the error of refraction. It is based on the principle that when light is reflected from a mirror into the eye, the direction in which tlhe light will travel across the pupil depends upon the refractive stale of the eye. Interpretation of retinoscopy done at 1m is:

  • No movement of red reflex: Myopia of 1D
  • Movement of red reflex with retinoscope: Emmetropia, hypermetropia, myopia less than 1D
  • Movement of red reflex against the retinoscope: Myopia more than 1D

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presented with complaints of diarrhea for the past 3 days. On examination, he is tachypneic. His laboratory investigations are given below. What is the acid-base disorder in this patient?
pH 7.2
pCO2 20 mmHg
HCO3- 7 mEq/L
Cl- 120 mEq/L
Na+ 135 mEq/L

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with increased anion gap

questions.solution:
The acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap.

Diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.20 indicates acidosis. The normal pH is 7.35-7.45. 

Step 2: Bicarbonate level of 7 mEq/L (normal = 22-28) together with low pH indicates that acidosis is due to loss of bicarbonate (i.e. base). Hence this is metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: PCO2 levels of 20 mmHg indicate respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in PCO2 with a decrease in pH indicates that it is a compensatory mechanism. Hence the patient has metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.

Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- {(Cl-)+(HCO3-)}

=135-(120+7)

=8 mEq/L

The normal anion gap is 6-12 mEq/L. Hence the anion gap is within the normal range.

Diarrhea causes metabolic acidosis due to intestinal loss of bicarbonate-rich fluid.

Other options:

Option B: Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap is seen if the anion gap is >12 mEq/L. It occurs in conditions such as methanol poisoning, uremia, diabetic ketoacidosis, paracetamol poisoning, lactic acidosis, salicylate poisoning, etc. 

Option C: Respiratory acidosis occurs in conditions in which decreased ventilation (hypoventilation) increases the concentration of carbon dioxide in the blood and decreases the blood's pH. 

Option D: Lactic acidosis causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: You are a junior resident and you are examining a patient admitted in the medicine ward. On neurologic examination, the flowing clinical sign is seen on abrupt passive dorsiflexion of the foot. This sign can be caused by:
questions.solution:
Options, 1, 4 and 5 are correct.

The given clinical sign is clonus, it is seen in upper motor neuron lesions and serotonin syndrome. Myasthenia Gravis is a disorder of neuromuscular junction. Hyporeflexia is seen in Guillain–Barré syndrome.

Clonus is defined as regular, rhythmic, repetitive involuntary muscle contractions of the part of a limb (ankle, patella) when abrupt sustained muscle stretch is given. Clonus is due to sustained hyperactivity of alpha and gamma motor neurons.

This finding is seen in upper motor neuron type palsy which removes the inhibitory cortical control.

Causes are:

  • Cerebral infarction
  • Cerebral haemorrhage
  • Lacunar infarction
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Spinal cord injury
  • Upper motor neuron lesions
  • Serotonin syndrome

Management includes treatment of the underlying cause along with physical therapy.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man came with complaints of reduced vividness of saturated colors. On examination, he was found to have altered depth perception for moving objects. This phenomenon is due to which of the following condition seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Altered depth perception, especially for moving objects, is known as Pulfrich phenomenon. The given clinical findings of Pulfrich phenomenon and reduced vividness of saturated colors (vivid and intense colors) are suggestive of optic neuritis.

On examination, Pulfrich phenomenon is observed when a small target is oscillated to and fro within the plane facing the patient. He perceives it as moving in an elliptical path.

Pulfrich phenomenon is an indication of nerve dysfunction. It is seen in optic neuritis because there is a delay in visual information reaching the cortex via the affected optic nerve, which results in altered depth perception.

Optic neuritis comprises inflammatory and demyelinating disorders of the optic nerve. Other symptoms of optic neuritis include:

  • Visual loss – monocular, sudden, progressive, and profound (the hallmark of acute optic neuritis) 
  • Lowered dark adaptation
  • Visual obscuration in bright light
  • Reduced vividness of colors
  • Phosphenes – Movement and sound-induced glowing sensations in the eye (phosphenes are the glowing sensation produced by non photic inadequate stimuli)
  • Uhthoff's phenomenon – Transient visual obscuration on exertion and exposure to heat that resolves on resting or moving away from the heat source
  • Pain – Mild dull eye ache. More marked in retrobulbar neuritis. Aggravated by eye movement

Signs of optic neuritis:

  • Marked reduction in visual acuity
  • Impaired color vision
  • Marcus Gunn Pupil indicates the relative afferent pupillary defect, is a diagnostic sign. Can be detected by swinging flashlight test
  • Disc hyperemia with blurred margin
  • Central or centrocaecal scotoma in the visual field (most common field defect in optic neuritis)

Other options:

Option A- Retinitis pigmentosa is a hereditary disorder predominantly affecting photoreceptors. It leads to night blindness and tubular vision.

Option B- Retinal detachment is the separation of the neurosensory retina proper from the pigment epithelium. It usually presents as floaters in front of the eye and the sensation of flashes of light.

Option D- Vitreous hemorrhage is a disease occurring in the posterior segment of the eye. It usually presents as floaters in front of the eye and loss of vision.

questions.text: The radiologist performs  myocardial perfusion imaging  with  technetium-99m labeled compounds in a cardiac patient to determine the effectiveness of acute revascularization. Identify the true statement about technetium-99m.

choices.text: Pure beta emitter with half life of 12 hours
Pure gamma emitter with half life of 12 hours
Pure beta emitter with half life of 6 hours
Pure gamma emitter with half life of 6 hours

questions.solution:
Technetium-99m is a pure gamma emitter as it is in the metastable state and its half-life is  6 hours.

Technetium agents based on the Technetium-99m (Tc-99m) radioisotope are most frequently used an agent in medical imaging. The radioactive technetium can be chelated to a number of different compounds to create specific radiopharmaceuticals and optimise imaging of various structures.

Half-life of Tc 99m is 6 hours

Tc 99m produce gamma rays of 140 keV.

Note:

Myocardial perfusion imaging is done with either thallium-201 or technetium-99m labeled compounds (e.g., technetium-99m sestamibi).

questions.text: Investigations of a pregnant lady with twin gestation reveal poly-oli syndrome. Which among the following is/are true regarding the donor and recipient twins in this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Options 1, 2, 4, and 5 are true.

Fetus in the donor sac has oligohydramnios, the virtual absence of amniotic fluid prevents fetal movement, giving a descriptive term 'stuck twin'

Donor twin is anemic in twin to twin transfusion syndrome

Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS):

  •  This is a type of fetal syndrome which can arise when monozygotic twinning results in two amnionic sacs and a common surrounding chorion.
  • This leads to anatomical sharing of the two fetal circulations through anastomoses of placental arteries and veins. It depends on the degree to which they are hemodynamically balanced. In those with significant pressure or flow gradients, a shunt will develop between fetuses. This chronic feto-fetal transfusion results in twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS).
  • In this syndrome, blood is transfused from a donor twin to its recipient sibling such that the donor may eventually become anemic and its growth may be restricted. In contrast, the recipient becomes polycythemic and may develop circulatory overload manifest as hydrops.

Other features:

Donor twin  Recipient twin 
Oliguria Polyuria
Anemia Polycythemia
Oligohydramnios Polyhydramnios
Activation of Renin-angiotensin system (RAA) Activation of Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)
Decreased renal blood flow Increased renal blood flow
Non-visible bladder

Over distended bladder, circulatory overload, hyperviscosity syndrome, hyperbilirubinemia, hypertension 
Renal failure

Congestive cardiac failure (CCF), Hydrops twin (late cases )

Note:

The donor twin is also known as pump twin / stuck twin, and the manifestation is termed as polyhydramnios -oligohydramnios syndrome or poly-oli syndrome.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with incomplete vaccination history comes with vomiting after bouts of severe, violent cough. His nasopharyngeal aspirate shows Gram negative coccobacilli. Which of the following statements are correct regarding the causative organism of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture points towards a diagnosis of pertussis/whooping cough caused by bordetella pertussis which can be cultured on the Bordet-Gengou medium.

Bordetella pertussis shows colonies resembling “bisected pearls” or “mercury drops” on Bordet-Gengou medium.  

After incubation for 48 to 72 hours, B. pertussis colonies on Bordet-Gengou are small, dome- shaped, smooth, opaque, viscid, greyish white, refractile and glistening resembling “bisected pearls” or “mercury drops” and are surrounded by a hazy zone of hemolysis. Confluent growth presents as an "Aluminium paint" appearance.

 

Whooping cough derives its name from the inspiratory whoop at the end of a coughing bout. The disease courses over 3 phases after an incubation period of 2 weeks:

  • Catarrhal - lasts for 1-2 weeks and consists of cough, coryza, and nasopharyngeal secretions.
  • Paroxysmal - lasts for 2-6 weeks and consists of worsening paroxysms of productive whooping cough. It becomes more frequent and ends with vomiting. 
  • Convalescent - Intensity and frequency of cough decrease over 4 weeks.

The diagnosis is made on clinical grounds. A specific diagnosis can be done by isolation of the organism from a nasopharyngeal swab taken in the first two phases, and cultured on Bordet-Gengou-glycerine-potato-blood agar and Regan Lowe medium.

Management involves antibiotic therapy and supportive care. The incidence of pertussis has decreased significantly after widespread vaccination. 

Other conditions with prolonged cough include adenoviral infections, reactive airway disease, foreign body in the airway.

Other options:

  • Potassium telluride agar - used for the culture of corynebacterium diphtheria.
  • BCYE medium -used for the culture of Legionella.

 

Note: In culture films, Bordetella pertussis bacilli tend to be arranged in loose clumps, with clear spaces in between, giving a "thumbprint" appearance. 

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

questions.text: Given below is the histological section of the skin taken from a patient suspected to be suffering from a dermatological condition. Which of the following conditions shows a similar finding seen in the given histological image?
questions.solution:
All the given options are correct.

The above histological image shows the presence of nucleated cells in the stratum corneum, which indicates parakeratosis. (Note that normally, the cells of stratum corneum are devoid of nucleus.)

  • Parakeratosis is defined as the retention of keratinocyte nuclei within the horny cell layer or stratum corneum.
  • It represents a disorder of keratinization, and is usually associated with an absence or reduction in thickness of the granular cell layer.
  • The histological feature of parakeratosis is commonly seen in many different forms of inflammatory dermatosis, and is closely associated either with increased epidermal cell turnover or with inflammatory changes in the epidermis itself.

Parakeratosis is commonly seen in

  • Psoriasis
  • Subacute eczematous reactions
  • Pityriasis lichenoides
  • Actinic keratoses
  • Bowen disease

questions.text: A child presented with a lower neck swelling since birth, which bulges during deep inspiration and Valsalva maneuver. CT revealed herniation of the lung apex and its pleura in the neck. You suspect a congenital defect of a fascia which has led to this presentation. Which of the following statements about the concerned fascia is/are correct:
questions.solution:
Options 1,2 and 5 are correct.

Sibson's fascia (supra-pleural membrane) serves as a plane of separation between the lower neck and the thorax and covers the apical part of the lung. It is formed by scalenus minimus and endo-thoracic fascia. 

Its base is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib and apex to the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra. The superior surface is related to the subclavian vessels, and inferior surface fuses with the cervical pleura.

Its function is to prevent puffing up and down of the root of the neck during respiration. There can be anatomical variations, if there is congenital defect/weakness it causes unusual protrusion of the apex of the lung and its pleural coverings.

questions.text: The sequence of the non-template strand in a DNA fragment is TAAAGC. The mRNA that will be transcribed from the anti-sense strand will have the following sequence______
questions.solution:
UAAAGC will be the sequence of mRNA produced from this fragment of DNA (the non-template strand, which is TAAAGC), while the template strand will have a complementary sequence of ATTTCG.

The non-template strand or, coding strand, or sense/plus strand in the DNA, will have the same sequence of the RNA that is produced, except that the non-template or coding strand has T in place of U. 

As all sequences are written in the 5′ to 3′ direction, unless otherwise specified, an RNA sequence of UAAAGC would correspond to a DNA sequence on the non-template strand of TAAAGC.

Both the non-template strand and RNA produced will be a complementary sequence to the template strand. Therefore, the template strand would be ATTTCG (written 5′ to 3′).

Note:

Template strand - known as minus or, antisense or non-coding strand.

Coding strand- known as plus or, sense or non-template strand.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with the polycystic ovarian syndrome was treated for infertility with therapies for ovulation induction. She later developed Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome(OHSS). This iatrogenic complication is more commonly seen with  ___________ therapy.
questions.solution:
OHSS is more commonly seen in FSH/LH therapy than other methods of ovulation induction.

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is an iatrogenic complication seen during the luteal phase or early pregnancy. It is seen in patients taking ovulation induction therapies for infertility more common in FSH/LH therapy than clomiphene or pulsatile GnRH therapies. FSH/LH causes a higher incidence of OHSS (30%) than clomiphene (10%) and GnRH (1%)

The pathogenesis in OHSS is the increased vascular permeability leading to fluid shift from intravascular to extravascular space.

The risk factors for OHSS are:

  • Younger age 
  • PCOS
  • Previous history of OHSS
  • An increased oestradiol level (>3000 pg/mL)
  • Presence of 20 or more small follicles
  • High LH/FSH ratio

Complications of OHSS are:

  • Coagulopathy
  • Thromboembolic phenomenon
  • Deep venous thrombosis
  • Cerebrovascular accidents
  • Liver dysfunction
  • Adult respiratory distress caused by ascites/hydrothorax
  • Hypovolemia leading to Renal failure
  • Torsion and hemorrhage in the ovarian cyst

questions.text: In metal factories, the temperature is measured by the Kelvin scale. It is an example of ____ type of data measurement.
questions.solution:
Kelvin temperature measurement is an example of Ratio scale data.

Ratio scales are similar to interval scales but additionally, there is an absolute zero and therefore meaningful ratios do exist.

Kelvin scale is the only scale of temperature where the zero actually indicates an absolute absence of heat. 

Related Pearl: Scales of data measurement

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

 

Description

Example

Discrete data

Can take certain values and none in between

Number of cancer patients in a hospital. 

Continuous data

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range. 

Most biomedical data is continuous.

Height, weight, blood pressure, etc.

 

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

 

Nominal Scale Data

Ordinal Scale Data

Interval Scale Data

Ratio Scale Data

Example

Male/female; red/green; sub-urban/rural

Students ranked 1st/2nd/3rd in their class. 

A customer feedback survey using terms like very good, good, poor and very poor or the Likert Scale.

Severity of a disease as mild, moderate, severe

 

 Measurements on the celsius scale. Pulse rate; 

Notes

Have no quantitative value.

They have no order or ratio. 

Arranged in a meaningful order.

No size interval is defined

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Example: Temperature in Celsius. If temperature in A is 40 deg Celsius and that in B is 20 deg Celsius, then A is 20 deg Celsius hotter than B (taking difference)

Does not have an absolute zero.

For example, Celsius scale has no such thing as “no temperature”. So the value cannot be zero.

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Eg: A pulse rate has well defined intervals and is meaningful in comparison. A 100/min pulse is exactly twice of 50 beats/min.

 

Has an absolute zero.

Eg: There can be a value of zero for pulse.

Type

Qualitative

Qualitative

Quantitative

Quantitative

questions.text: A 15 year old boy is brought to the clinic with complaints of delayed intellectual development, speech problems. O/E systolic heart murmur 3/6 in right upper sternal border radiating to the right cervical region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Williams syndrome is the likely diagnosis

It occurs due to deletion at chromosome 7.

Classical facial features include:

  • Periorbital fullness of subcutaneous tissues,
  • Hypertelorism,
  • Stellate pattern of the iris,
  • Long philtrum,
  • Thick vermillion border of the lips,
  • Wide mouth,
  • Small jaw (elfin facies).


They present with cognitive impairment. The auscultatory findings are due to supravalvular aortic stenosis.

Other options:

B. Fragile X syndrome: caused by deletion of FMR1 gene. Characterised by intellectual disability, autistic behaviour and delayed language development. Characteristic facial features include long and narrow face, big ears, hypermobile joints. Men have macroorchidism.

C. Cri-du-chat syndrome: Is characterised by high pitched cry, Ventricular septal defect and intellectual disability. Facial features include microcephaly, epicanthal folds, broad nasal bridge, down slanting palpebral fissure and widely spaced eyes.

D. Rett syndrome: Affects females. Initial normal development then loss of intelligence and cognitive abilities between 7-24 months of age.

questions.text: When you posted in surgery opd during your internship, you observed the following sign being elicited by the senior resident in a case of acute appendicitis. Which of the following statements are true with respect to the scoring system used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the method of eliciting Obturator sign ( i.e. Pain on internal rotation of hip) in a case of acute appendicitis. Alvarado scoring system is used in this condition. 

All the given statements are correct with respect to Alvarado scoring system except option 3. Migratory right iliac fossa pain has a score of 1

The components of the Alvarado scoring system can be remembered using the mnemonic MANTRELS

Related Pearl: Alvarado Scoring System

Findings

Points

Migratory right iliac fossa pain

1

Anorexia

1

Nausea / vomiting

1

Tenderness in right iiliac fossa

2

Rebound tenderness right iliac fossa

1

Elevated temperature ≥ 37.3°C

1

Leukocytosis ≥ 10⨯109 cells/L

2

Shift to the left of neutrophils

1

 

A score of 4-5 or below rules out the diagnosis of acute appendicitis in children, and in adults, a score of 8-9 or higher rules in the diagnosis.

If the score is 4-6, an an adjunctive CT scan would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

If the score is 7 or higher, surgery is recommended.

Related Pearl: Signs in appendicitis

Sign

Pelvic appendicitis

Pain on extension of hip

Retrocaecal appendicitis

Aaron sign

Pain or pressure in epigastrium or anterior chest with persistent firm pressure applied to McBurney’s point

Acute appendicitis

Sharp pain created by compressing appendix between abdominal wall and iliacus

Chronic appendicitis

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient approached a radiologist for a screening breast examination during breast cancer awareness month. Which of the following best represents the difference in the  X-ray tube used in this procedure from that of a conventional X-ray machine?

choices.text: Beryllium exit window and molybdenum filter
Glass exit window and aluminium filter
Beryllium exit window and aluminium filter
Glass exit window and molybdenum filter

questions.solution:
The screening procedure for breast cancer is mammography. The x-ray tube used in mammography differs from that of a conventional x-ray machine in that it has a beryllium exit window and molybdenum filter.

Differences between mammography and conventional radiography:

  • Mammography involves the use of low-energy and high-amperage waves.
  • The target anode is made of a tungsten disc in conventional x-ray tubes and molybdenum in mammography x-ray tubes.
  • Most mammography tubes use beryllium exit windows between the evacuated tube and the atmosphere.
  • The conventional X-ray tube has an aluminum filter, but in mammography, a molybdenum filter is used.

Some indications for mammography:

  • Evaluation of breast signs and symptoms like masses, skin changes, deformities, nipple retraction, discharge, and eczema
  • Breast cancer screening
  • Follow-up for patients treated for breast cancer
  • Localization of lesions not visible on ultrasound

The two standard mammographic projections are the mediolateral oblique view and the craniocaudal view.

Note: Breast cancer awareness month is an annual international health campaign organized by major breast cancer charities every year in the month of October.

Related Pearl: Difference between Normal Radiography and Mammography

  Radiography Mammography
Type of X rays Bremsstrahlung reaction Characteristic radiation
Target Tungsten Molybdenum
Exit Window Glass Beryllium
Filter Aluminum Molybdenum

questions.text: During your radiology residency, one of your close relatives shows his friend's CT image for getting your opinion. In which of the following conditions, can similar CT findings can be seen?
questions.solution:
Options 1, 4, and 5 can show similar findings in Chest CT.

The given CT image shows Tree-in-bud sign or pattern which is the appearance of multiple areas of centrilobular nodules with a linear branching pattern.

Tree in bud

 

Tree in bud sign is also seen in a variety of other disorders like:

  • Bronchiolitis
  • Endobronchial TB
  • Bronchopneumonia
  • Bronchoalveolar Carcinoma
  • Connective tissue disorders like Sjogren's syndrome
  • Bronchiectasis - Cystic fibrosis

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient had undergone prolonged surgery in a  prone position with his hip extended. Post-operatively he complained of pain, numbness, and paresthesia along the anterolateral aspect of the thigh. What is the root value of the nerve involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of prolonged surgery in prone position with hip extended and symptoms of paresthesia over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh is suggestive of meralgia paresthetica. It is due to compression neuropathy or neuroma of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. The root value of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is L2 and L3.

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh arises from the posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L2 and L3, and it supplies the skin of the anterior and lateral surfaces of the thigh up to the knee.

It is prone to injury especially as it leaves the pelvis deep to the inguinal ligament just medial to the anterior superior iliac spine. The angulation of the nerve as it crosses the iliac crest makes it vulnerable to compression during hip extension which may increase angulation and tension on the nerve.

Related Pearl: Compression neuropathies

Syndrome 

Nerve involved

Pronator teres syndrome

Median nerve (proximally compressed beneath ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origins of pronator teres)

Radial tunnel (Arcade of Frohse) syndrome

Posterior Interosseous nerve (in proximal forearm)

Ulnar nerve behind medial epicondyle

Superficial sensory branch of radial nerve

Ulnar nerve(at wrist)

Lower trunk of brachial plexus

Sciatic nerve

questions.text: A surgeon performing a modified radical neck dissection on a patient decides to preserve only the spinal accessory nerve. What type of MRND being performed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Type 1 MRND involves the preservation of the spinal accessory nerve.

Modified radical neck dissection (MRND): It is similar to radical neck dissection but with the preservation of one or more of the following structures:

  • Spinal accessory nerve
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Sternocleidomastoid muscle
