questions.text: While investigating the health status of a population, the medical authorities would use the following utilization rates:
questions.solution:
Bed-occupancy rate, bed turnover ratio and the average length of stay, are examples of utilization rates of health service.

Utilization of services is expressed as the proportion of people in need of a service who actually receive it in a given period. It is considered to be indicative the health status of the population.

The following are utilization rates:

  • The proportion of infants immunized against 9 diseases in the expanded program on immunization (EPI)
  • The proportion of women receiving antenatal care and supervised delivery 
  • Percentage of population using family planning methods
  • Bed occupancy rate
  • The average length of stay
  • Bed turnover ratio

Health care delivery indicators: The provision of health care and the equity of distribution of health resources in different parts of the country are reflected by these indicators.

Examples are:

  • Doctor- population ratio
  • Doctor-nurse ratio
  • Population-bed ratio
  • Population per health/subcentre
  • Population per trained birth attendant

questions.text: Which of the following auscultatory findings do you expect to hear in a child during clinical examination in a child with an ASD?
questions.solution:
In Atrial septal defect (ASD), the characteristic finding is that the second heart sound is widely split and fixed during all phases of respiration.

Other options:

  • In Ventricular septal defect (VSD) – Wide variable splitting of the 2nd heart sound which is masked by the pansystolic murmur.
  • In Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) – the first sound is accentuated and the second sound is narrowly or paradoxically split.
  • In the Coarctation of the aorta – the first sound is accentuated, the second sound is normally split with a loud aortic component.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with recurrent viral, fungal and bacterial infections. The child has a history of hemolytic anemia. The thymus is dysplastic but immunoglobulin levels are normal.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the above clinical history and examination, the most probable diagnosis is Nezelof syndrome.

Nezelof syndrome is a combined immunodeficiency disorder with a marked deficiency of T-cell immunity and a varying degree of B-cell deficiency immunity.

Nezelof syndrome: There is a marked deficiency of T cell immunity and varying degrees of deficiency of B cell immunity. Patients are susceptible to recurrent fungal, bacterial, viral, and protozoal diseases. Abundant plasma cells are seen in the spleen, lymph nodes, and intestines. Thymic dysplasia is common with lymphoid depletion. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia can also be seen. In spite of normal levels of immunoglobulins, antigenic stimuli do not induce antibody formation. 

 Management- Antimicrobial therapy and stem cell transplantation is the definitive treatment.

Hyper-immunoglobulinemia E syndrome (Job’s Syndrome) is a rare primary immunodeficiency disease caused due to a failure of neutrophils to generate an immune response, causing elevated IgE levels.

questions.text: During your residency, A patient comes to you with difficulty in breathing. As you were not confident to do the endotracheal intubation, you try to secure the airway with the following device. Which of the following are the disadvantages associated with the use of this device when compared with tracheal intubation?
questions.solution:
The given image is of Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA). Among the given options, Option 1 and 2 are the disadvantage associated with its use when compared with tracheal intubation.

The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that sits in the hypopharynx and partially protects the larynx from pharyngeal secretions, but not gastric regurgitation.

Advantages and disadvantages of the laryngeal mask airway compared with tracheal intubation are: 

Advantages:

  • Easy and rapid
  • Less invasive
  • Better hemodynamic stability
  • Very useful in difficult intubations
  • Less tooth and laryngeal trauma
  • Does not require muscle relaxation
  • Does not require neck mobility 
  • No risk of esophageal or endobronchial intubation

Disadvantages:

  • Increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration
  • Less safe in prone or jack-knife positions
  • Less secure airway
  • Greater risk of gas leak and pollution
  • Can cause gastric distention

questions.text: You advise abdominal ultrasound in a patient presenting with jaundice, abdominal pain, and a palpable abdominal mass in the right upper quadrant.  USG abdomen reveals a cystic mass that is separate from the gallbladder. Identify the correct statement regarding various types of this condition based on the Todani system of classification.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with USG findings is suggestive of Choledochal cysts. Options 1,3, and 5 are correct regarding the Todani system of choledochal cysts classification.

Choledochal Cysts are Cystic dilations of the extrahepatic and/or intrahepatic biliary tree. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass and abdominal pain.

Abdominal ultrasound reveals a cystic mass that is separate from the gallbladder and allows anatomic assessment of the biliary tree.

Todani classification system divides choledochal cysts into five groups. Type 1 cysts are the most common type and have the highest risk of malignancy whereas Type III cysts are associated with the lowest malignancy risk of any choledochal cyst. Type IVa cysts involve both intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree.

Surgical management of choledochal cysts consists of resection of the entire cyst. After cyst excision, Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy is performed for reconstruction.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents with worsening epigastric abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. CT scan revealed features suggesting gastrinoma with secondary duodenal inflammation. Presence of which of the other endocrine tumors would form the triad that is commonly seen in MEN -1 syndrome
  1. Mucosal neuroma
  2. Pancreatic tumour
  3. Pituitary adenoma
  4. Pheochromocytoma
questions.solution:
Options 2 and 3 are correct.

MEN 1 syndrome is characterized by the triad of tumours involving the parathyroids, pancreatic islets, and anterior pituitary.

Gastrinoma is the most common pancreatic islet tumour in MEN 1 syndrome. The most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome is the first and second part of duodenum. Gastrinoma if associated with marked gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcer is called Zollinger Ellison syndrome.

The diagnosis of MEN 1 is made if the patient has

  • ≥2 primary tumor types OR
  • 1st degree relative with 1 tumor + clinical diagnosis of the syndrome OR
  • Germline mutation in the associated gene

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy, who had collapsed suddenly while playing cricket, was rushed to the ER, where he was declared dead due to cardiac arrest. His family is shocked by this, as he had no previous medical history, but they do recollect that few other members of the family also died at a young age. Which of the following is correct about the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Options 2, 4 and 5 are correct.

HCM is the leading cause of sudden death in young. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is characterized by predominant diastolic dysfunction presenting as exercise intolerance. 

The patients have a dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction due to septal hypertrophy and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet (SAM). SAM leads to mitral regurgitation with the jet directed posteriorly. It is characterized by misalignment of the enlarged myofibrils and myocytes

The ventricular cavity is banana-shaped in HOCM as seen on echocardiography. The murmur of HCM is an ejection systolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. 

The murmur of HCM is accentuated by

  • A decrease in left ventricular cavity volume or pressure (decreased preload)
  • A decrease in systemic vascular resistance and/or arterial pressure (decreased afterload)
  • Increase in left ventricular contractility

Therefore, the intensity of the systolic murmur is 

  • Increased by -Valsalva strain phase, Standing posture, and exercise
  • Decreased by - Squatting, passive leg raising and handgrip

The image below shows a cross-section of a heart with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. We can see that when the left ventricular size is small, the approximation of the interventricular septum with the mitral valve increases. This increases the obstruction to the outflow of blood and increases the intensity of the murmur.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

questions.text: A  34-year-old woman comes with mild chronic pain in the ankle region of both lower limbs. On examination, the following finding is seen (as shown in the below image). Squeezing of the calf produces plantar flexion of the foot without tenderness. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given deformity is Retrocalcaneal exostosis/Haglund deformity, pump bump, or Mulholland deformity, which is seen around the ankle joint. It is a bony enlargement formed at the posterosuperior aspect of the calcaneum.

Retrocalcaneal bursa usually protects the Achilles tendon from the calcaneal tuberosity.

But in Haglund deformity, there is chronic inflammation of this retrocalcaneal bursa. Recurrent pressure from the shoe may lead to chronic inflammation of the bursa and calcification at the site of the insertion of the Achilles tendon. This leads to worsening pain symptoms, prolonged inflammation, and degenerative changes.

Management is usually conservative, using a heel lift, silicone pads in closed shoes, ice application, anti-inflammatory drugs, and stretching exercises of the calf.

 

Other options:

Avulsion of Achilles tendon: Defect or gap could be felt on the contour of the calf, Thompson test would be positive.

Plantar fasciitis: Pain and tenderness over the sole of the feet.

Calcaneal fracture: Would present with severe pain, usually after trauma/fall.

questions.text: A 24-year old male patient presents to you with complaints of pain and inability to do pinching activities, after suffering a fall on an outstretched hand while practicing skiing for the winter sports events. Which of the following structure is usually injured in the given scenario? (DIP- distal interphalangeal joints)

choices.text: Injury to extensor tendon at DIP
Injury to flexor tendon at DIP

questions.solution:
Clinical history of a Skier falling on an outstretched hand, after which pinching activities are affected, is suggestive of Gamekeeper’s thumb/Skier's thumb. It involves injury to Ulnar collateral ligament.

A gamekeeper thumb, also known as skier’s thumb is an injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the first metacarpophalangeal joint. The UCL may get ruptured or avulsed from its site of insertion on the base of the proximal phalanx.

Injury is usually caused by a fall on an outstretched hand with radial and palmar abduction. Patients present with pain, swelling, and ecchymosis around the first metacarpophalangeal joint. Diagnosis can be made on plain radiographs and/or anteroposterior stress radiographs.

In a partial rupture:

  • Only the ligament is torn and the thumb is unstable only in flexion 
  • The volar plate is intact, keeping the thumb stable in extension

In a complete rupture:

  • Both the ligament and the volar plate are torn 
  • The thumb is unstable in all positions

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented to the OPD with failure to thrive and a developmental defect of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches and was referred for further evaluation. The Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization ( FISH) findings have been shown in the following image. This syndrome is known as____
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2 seen on Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH) are suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome.

A child with a developmental defect of thymus and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2 points towards the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome.

In this syndrome, the fourth branchial arch and the derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches (which contribute to the formation of the thymus, parathyroids, and heart) develop abnormally. This syndrome is therefore associated with multiple deficits (memorable through the mnemonic CATCH - 22)

Mnemonic CATCH-22:

  • Cardiac abnormality
  • Abnormal facies
  • Thymic aplasia
  • Cleft palate
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Deletion 22q11.2  

Thymic hypoplasia with impaired T cell immunity can manifest as:

  • T cells are absent in the lymph nodes, spleen, and peripheral blood, and infants with this defect are extremely vulnerable to viral, fungal, and protozoal infections.
  • Patients also are susceptible to infection with intracellular bacteria, because of defective T cell-mediated immunity.
  • B cells and serum immunoglobulins are generally unaffected.

 

Other options:

Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by the partial deletion of the short arm of Chromosome no. 5. Affected children have a cat-like cry, microcephaly, mental retardation, and congenital heart disease.

Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome or Pitt–Rogers–Danks syndrome (PRDS) or Pitt syndrome occurs due to partial deletion or monosomy of chromosome 4. The main features of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome are typical “Greek helmet” facies secondary to ocular hypertelorism, prominent glabella, and frontal bossing and microcephaly.

Williams syndrome occurs due to deletion at chromosome 7. Classical facial features include:

  • Periorbital fullness of subcutaneous tissues,
  • Hypertelorism,
  • A stellate pattern of the iris,
  • Long philtrum,
  • Thick vermillion border of the lips,
  • Wide mouth,
  • Small jaw (elfin facies).

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought in cardiopulmonary arrest to the ER, the EMT has tried to gain venous access for the past 1 minute, but in vain. It is decided to get access through the following method. Which of the following is true regarding resuscitation using this route?

choices.text: Only emergency epinephrine can be given through this route
Only blood products and fluids can be administered through this route
Any medications, blood products, and fluids can be administered
Only fluids to be given through this route

questions.solution:
The given image shows intraosseous cannulation for fluid transfusion in the anterior proximal tibia. Any and all medications, blood products, and fluids can be administered through this route.

The intraosseous route is an alternative to the intravenous (IV) route in the transfusion of fluids in shock. 

  • The marrow of long bones has a rich network of vessels that drain into a central venous canal, emissary veins, and ultimately the central circulation.
  • So, the bone marrow functions as a non-collapsible venous access route.

Intraosseous cannulation is recommended for patients in whom IV access proves difficult or unattainable. (e.g., in cardiopulmonary arrest). In such a case, if venous access is not available within 1 min, an intraosseous needle should be placed in the anterior proximal tibia.

Complications are uncommon, but may include osteomyelitis with prolonged infusions and tibial fracture.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman in her 38th week of gestation has her fetus in the breech position. She is being explained about the need for a cesarean section in case of difficult breech delivery by her obstetrician. Which breech presentations at delivery are associated with least and maximum fetal mortality respectively?
questions.solution:
Fetal mortality is least in frank breech and maximum in a footling presentation

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs

questions.text: Mr. A is furious after his fiancee broke off their engagement, and gets inebriated. He then attacks her with a heavy rod and injures her right eye. He will be deemed liable for his actions even though they were committed in a state of inebriation under which section of the IPC?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, Mr. A will be charged under Section 86 of the IPC (BNS Sce 24) as he was under voluntary intoxication while he committing the act and he is liable for his actions.

McNaughten's rule falls under section 84 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) (BNS Sec 22). Mc Naughten's rule (The right or wrong test / The legal test) states that "A person of unsound mind is not liable for an act."

Defect: In Mc Naughthen’s rule, only intellectual factors are considered but emotions, delusion, and control of impulses are ignored.

Related Pearl: BNS section 22, M'Naghten's rule

M'Naghten's rule, BNS 22 (Previously - Section 84 IPC):  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

Related Pearl: Criminal Responsibilities

BNS section

Previous IPC Section

Deals with

-

Child of 7–12 years if not attained proper mental maturity is not liable for the act.

questions.text: An ENT professor while explaining about the air-containing cavities that are present in skull bones asks you to select the true statements by providing the following options. Which of the following options you would select.
questions.solution:
Among the given statements, Option A, B, and E are the true statements.

Paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities in that are present in the bones of the skull. These paranasal sinuses have been divided into two groups:

Anterior group: It includes,

  • Maxillary sinus(Antrum of highmore)
  • Frontal sinus
  • Anterior ethmoidal.

All of the above sinuses open in the middle meatus and their ostia lie anterior to basal lamella of middle turbinate.

Posterior group: It includes,

  • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses: Opens in the superior meatus 
  • Sphenoid sinus: Opens in sphenoethmoidal recess.

Note: 

Maxillary and Ethmoid sinuses( including both anterior and posterior ethmoidal sinuses) are present at birth. The frontal and the sphenoid sinuses are not present at birth

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Which of the following statements are correct?
questions.solution:
Options 1,3 and 5 are correct.

Phenylephrine is a selective alpha 1 receptor agonist.

Dobutamine shows both α and β receptor agonism.

Tamsulosin is a selective α1 receptor antagonist.

Other options:

Selective alpha 1 receptor antagonist are prazosin, terazosin, doxazosin, alfuzosin, tamsulosin.

Oxymetazoline is a nonselective α receptor agonist.

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: A patient presented with lateral gaze palsy in the left eye, with ataxia of the left arm and leg.  He also has paralysis of the right arm, legs, and face, along with loss of touch sensation and proprioception over the right side of the body. Where is the lesion most likely to be located?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of medial pontine syndrome, which occurs due to a lesion located at the medial pons.

The medial pontine syndrome occurs due to the involvement of the paramedian branch of the basilar artery.

  • Ipsilateral manifestation
    • CN VI: Diplopia (lateral rectus muscle paralysis - the affected eye looks downwards and inwards)
    • Vestibular nucleus: Nystagmus
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle: Ataxia of limb and gait
  • Contralateral manifestation
    • Corticobulbar and corticospinal tract: Paralysis of face, arm, and leg
    • Medial lemniscus: loss of touch and proprioception from the body.

The lateral pontine syndrome occurs due to the involvement of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery.

  • Ipsilateral manifestations include:
    • CN VII: Facial paralysis 
    • CN V: loss of pain and temperature sensation over the face.
    • Vestibular nerve or nucleus: Horizontal and vertical nystagmus, vertigo, nausea, vomiting, oscillopsia.
    • Auditory nerve or cochlear nucleus: Deafness, tinnitus.
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle: Ataxia of limb and gait.
  • Contralateral manifestations include:
    • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain and temperature sensation over the body.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face

  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

questions.text: During your orthopedic postings, you notice the senior resident using the following orthosis in patients with ulnar nerve palsy. Identify the correct statements regarding the clinical test done in these patients to assess the ulnar nerve injury?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a knuckle bender splint which is used to correct claw hand deformity due to ulnar nerve palsy.

Option 1, 3, and 5 are correct statements regarding the clinical tests done in a patient with ulnar nerve injury.

Tests used in ulnar nerve injuries include:

  • Wartenberg's sign - Due to weakness of the palmar interossei muscles and unopposed action of the extensor digiti minimi, there is involuntary abduction of the little finger.
  • Card test - Inability to hold a card between the fingers due to loss of adduction by palmar interossei muscles.
  • Positive Egawa's test - Due to weakness of dorsal interossei, side to side movements of middle finger is weak.
  • Positive book test or Froment's sign - Due to weakness of adductor pollicis muscle, adduction of thumb is lost. When asked to hold a book, patient tries to hold the book by using flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at inter-phalangeal joint while holding the book.

 

Note:

A positive pen sign is seen in the median nerve palsy. It tests the abductor pollicis brevis. The hand must remain flat with palm facing upwards; a pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb - Positive sign is unable to touch the pen.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is studying the diseases transmitted by the vector whose life cycle is given below. It is responsible for the transmission of all of the following except __________
questions.solution:
The given in the image above is the life cycle of louse and it can transmit trench fever, epidemic typhus(not endemic typhus), relapsing fever, and is responsible for pediculosis.

The trench fever/quintan fever/5-day fever is caused by Rickettsia Quintana.

Trench fever characterized by sudden onset of fever accompanied by headache, malaise, restlessness, and shin pain. It is an exclusively human disease and no animal reservoir is known. It is transmitted by the body louse.

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the worm shown in the image?

choices.text: The infective form is the third-stage larva
Freshwater crustacean Cyclops is the reservoir
The definitive host of this worm is man.

questions.solution:
The freshwater crustacean Cyclops is the intermediate host for guinea worm or Dracunculiasis. There is no animal reservoir. Man is the definitive host.

Life cycle:

The adult worm is viviparous and discharges larvae, which are ingested by the freshwater crustacean Cyclops (the intermediate host). Humans get infected by drinking unfiltered water containing cyclops with the infective form, the third-stage larva. The larvae penetrate the wall of the duodenum and reach the retroperitoneal and subcutaneous connective tissues. Here the larvae develop into male and female adults in about 3 to 4 months and mate.

The fertilized female worm grows in size and migrates within the connective tissues and along fascial planes. It reaches a site where it is likely to come into contact with water. At this site, it sets up a local inflammatory reaction.

The most common site affected is the leg, but other sites such as arms, shoulder, breast, buttocks, or genitalia can be affected. When the gravid female worm comes beneath the skin surface, it secretes a toxin which causes a blister formation. The blister ruptures, forming a shallow ulcer, in the base of which is a small hole through which the head of the worm protrudes. When the ulcer comes into contact with water, the worm contracts, discharging a milky white fluid containing numerous larvae.

questions.text: As a medicine resident at AIIMS Delhi, you've been asked to do blood sampling for a patient in your unit's ward. All of the following incorrect procedures lead to hemolysis in blood samples except?

choices.text: Drawing blood from an IV line in-situ
Collecting blood sample before letting the spirit dry

questions.solution:
Overfilling does not cause hemolysis. Underfilling causes hemolysis. Underfilling of the vacutainer vials would increase the proportion of anticoagulant to blood, this might cause hemolysis.

Hemolysis during blood collection may be due to one of the factors

  •  use of a needle of too small a gauge (23 or under), or too large a gauge for the vessel
  •  pressing the syringe plunger to force the blood into a tube, thus increasing the shear force on the red blood cells
  •  drawing blood specimens from an intravenous or central line
  •  underfilling a tube so that the ratio of anticoagulant to blood is greater than 1:9
  •  reusing tubes that have been refilled by hand with inappropriate amounts of anticoagulants
  •  mixing a tube too vigorously
  •  failing to let alcohol or disinfectant dry
  •  using too great a vacuum; for example, using too large a tube for a pediatric patient, or using too large a syringe (10–20 ml).

questions.text: A 26-year-old female in the 10th week of gestation presents with the following rash. Considering the likely diagnosis, which of the following is the most appropriate medication in her case?
questions.solution:
This "classic" bulls-eye rash is also called erythema migrans. This lesion is usually seen in individuals with Lyme’s disease.
In pregnant women with early Lyme disease, it is treated with amoxicillin 500mg t.i.d for 14-21 days.

Doxycycline and other tetracyclines are contraindicated in pregnancy, as this is seen to increase risk of fetal teeth and bone malformations

Doxycycline is generally the drug of choice in Lyme’s disease except in pregnant, lactating women and children under 8 where amoxicillin is used. IV penicillin G or third generation cephalosporins can be used in severe Lyme disease.

questions.text: You are working as an intern in the ENT department. During the ward rounds, the HOD asks you to show the pure tone audiometry of a patient, who was diagnosed with left-sided otosclerosis. Which of the following graphs you would show to the HOD?
questions.solution:
Graph C represents the pure tone audiometry (PTA) of a patient with left-sided otosclerosis and has the following features:

  • A dip in the bone conduction curve of the left ear with a maximum dip at 2000 Hz called Carhart’s notch.
  • Air conduction is poor & worse for lower frequencies.
  • A large air-bone gap is seen

PTA is interpreted by:

  • Blue color PTA is indicative of the left ear and red color for the right ear.
  • [ and ] indicate right and left bone conduction respectively.
  • O and X indicate right and left air conduction respectively.

Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which the normally dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It has a positive family history with an autosomal dominant trait. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause. It may be associated with osteogenesis imperfecta and a viral infection like measles. 

Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis. The lesion starts in an area called fissula ante fenestram just in front of the oval window. Patients complain of hearing loss, that they hear better in noisy environments (Paracusis willisii), and tinnitus. On examination, a red blush of the tympanic membrane due to vascularity can be seen known as Schwartze sign. Surgical intervention by stapedectomy/stapedotomy is the mainstay of treatment.

Other options:

  • Graph A shows a dip in the bone conduction curve of the right ear and is seen in right-sided otosclerosis.
  • Graph B and graph D shows a dip in the air conduction curve.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: What percentage of drug given will be left in the body after 3 half-lives, if the drug is eliminated by first order kinetics?
questions.solution:
The percentage of drug given will be left in the body if the drug eliminates by first-order kinetics after 3 half-lives is 12.5%.

In first-order kinetics, the rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional to the drug concentration.

The rate of clearance remains constant.

Half-life Elimination (%) Drug left in the body(%)
First 50  50
Second 75  25
Third 87.5  12.5
Fourth 93.75  6.25

questions.text: An elderly male is being evaluated for bone pain. Laboratory findings show elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and urinary hydroxyproline but normal serum calcium and phosphorus levels. The histopathological slide from the lesion is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological slide are suggestive of Paget's disease or Osteitis deformans. It is a disorder of increased, but disordered and structurally unsound, bone mass.

Histology of Paget's disease of the bone showing a jigsaw-like pattern produced by unusually prominent cement lines, which join haphazardly oriented units of lamellar bone

Pathogenesis: Mutations in the SQSTM1 gene increase the activity of NF-κB, which increases osteoclast activity.

Three sequential phases: (1) initial osteolytic stage, (2) a mixed osteoclastic-osteoblastic stage, and (3) a final burned-out quiescent osteosclerotic stage

The onset is in late adulthood (average age at diagnosis, 70 years).

The axial skeleton or proximal femur is involved in up to 80% of the cases.

  •  Enlargement of the craniofacial skeleton:  leontiasis ossea or lion face
  • Weakened Pagetic bone: invagination of the skull base (platybasia) 
  • Chalk stick-type fractures in the long bones of the lower extremities.

The pathological hallmark is a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone, seen in the sclerotic phase.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man files a medical negligence case against a surgeon who operated on him for inguinal hernia three and a half years ago. Which of the following defenses against negligence will be applicable in this case?
questions.solution:
Res indicata is the defense against negligence that will be applicable in this case. 

Res indicata specifies that a suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed as being beyond the period of limitation. Legal action may still be brought up to three years after the alleged negligent act where a patient and doctor have entered into a specific contract that requires the provision of care.

Other defenses against negligence

  • No duty owed to the plaintiff
  • Duty discharged according to prevailing standards
  • Misadventure - This may be therapeutic, diagnostic, and experimental. Therapeutic misadventure is a situation in which a patient has suffered harm or has died as a result of an error made by a doctor or agent of the doctor or the hospital.
  • Error of judgment
  • Contributory negligence - the absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant
  • Res judicata (S.300, CrPC) -If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same in another legal proceeding, based on the same set of facts. Multiple appeals cannot be made. 
  • Limitation (Res indicata) - A suit for damages for negligence must be filed within 2 years from the date of alleged negligence against the doctor. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed. But, where a breach of duty to provide care as per a contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action may be undertaken for up to three years from the date of alleged negligence.

Other options:

'Res ipsa loquitur' means 'the thing or fact speaks for itself'. It is obvious evidence of the negligent act committed, such as swabs left in the abdominal cavity post laparotomy.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: A 50-year-old obese female patient presents with blackish discoloration near the neck area and axilla. On examination, you notice lipoatrophy and acanthosis nigricans. You suspect insulin resistance and the presence of which of the following will help you to diagnose Metabolic syndrome in this patient based on  NCEP-ATP III criteria
questions.solution:
Metabolic syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met, which is given by NCEP-ATP III (National Cholesterol Education program and adult treatment panel III). It includes-

  • Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level ≥ 150 mg/dL
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively.
  • Hypertension: blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥ 85 mmHg diastolic.
  • Fasting plasma glucose level ≥100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old sportsperson comes to the ER with a painful ankle after an injury while playing tennis. Your senior advise you to evaluate this patient to know the need for ankle x-ray. Which of the following points is least important when considering whether an X-ray is required?

choices.text: Inability to walk 4 steps in the ER
Cannot take weight on the ankle immediately after injury

questions.solution:
The Ottawa ankle rules provide assistance in determining the need for ankle X-ray. Of the above options swelling immediately after the injury is not mentioned and is, therefore, least important to determine whether an X-ray is needed.

The Ottawa Ankle Rules:

An ankle X-Ray series is required if there is:

  • Pain around the malleolar zone. 
  • Bone tenderness at the posterior edge or tip of the lateral/medial malleolus/base of 5th metatarsal bone. 
  • An inability to bear weight immediately after the injury.
  • Inability to walk 4 steps in the emergency department.

questions.text: You are examining the blood smear of a patient who presented with fatigue and a petechial rash for the past 4 weeks but no hepatosplenomegaly. His provisional diagnosis suggests myelodysplastic syndrome. Which of the following is incorrect about the inclusion body you have seen in this patient's blood picture?

choices.text: Can also be seen in Kawasaki disease

questions.solution:
The image shows Döhle bodies which are derived from the dilated endoplasmic reticulum. They appear as sky-blue colored cytoplasmic inclusions inside neutrophils. These inclusions may be seen in conditions such as:

  • Sepsis
  • Severe inflammatory disorders like Kawasaki disease
  • Myelodysplastic syndromes

Related Pearl: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

1. Bacterial Inclusion Bodies 

Disease/Bacteria  Inclusion bodies 
Granuloma inguinale, Klebsiella granulomatis Donovan bodies
Psittacosis, Chlamydia psittacci  Levinthal-Cole-Lille bodies (LCL bodies)
Trachoma, Chlamydia trachomatis Halberstaedter-Prowazek bodies
Lymphogranuloma venereum, Chlamydia trachomatis Miyagawa’s granulocorpusles
Diphtheria, Corynebacterium diptheriae Babes-Ernst granules

 

2. Viral Inclusion Bodies

  • Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies
Disease/Virus Inclusion bodies
Rabies Negri bodies
Vaccinia, variola (smallpox) Guarnieri bodies
Variola (smallpox) Paschen bodies
Molluscum contagiosum Henderson-Patterson bodies
Fowlpox Bollinger bodies
  • Intra-nuclear Inclusion Bodies 
  Inclusion bodies  Disease/Virus
Cowdry type A Lipschutz inclusions Herpes Virus
Torres bodies Yellow fever
Cowdry type B Basophilic inclusions Adenovirus
Acidophilic inclusions Poliovirus
  • Both Intra-nuclear and Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies 
Disease/Virus  Inclusion bodies 
Measles Virus Warthin-Finkedly giant cells
Cytomegalovirus Owl-eye inclusions (basophilic, predominantly intra-nuclear, small granular intracytoplasmic inclusions are found)

 

3. Inclusion Bodies in Parasitic Infections

4. Miscellaneous Inclusion Bodies 

Disease/Location Inclusion bodies

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis  Bunina bodies
