questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with a lacerated wound over the hand due to an accidental injury from a soiled & rusted knife. You decide to give him equine antitoxin as human antitoxin immunoglobulin was not available at the hospital. What standard dose of equine antitoxin would you use in this case?
questions.solution:
The standard dose of Equine antitoxin(anti-tetanus serum/ATS) is 1500 IU.

The standard dose of Human antitoxin(human tetanus hyper-immunoglobulin/TIG) is 250 IU. If this not available, equine antitoxin can be used.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has urinary protein (+) in dipstick and urinalysis reveals oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules, which under polarized light show a characteristic maltese cross appearance. Which of the following is not a feature of the disease that this patient is suffering from?

choices.text: Treatment with ACEI/ARB can be useful

questions.solution:
Urinalysis showing oval fat bodies and maltese cross appearance of glycolipid globules under plane polarised light are suggestive of Fabry's Disease.

Excessive intracellular (not extracellular) storage of globotriaosylceramide is seen in Fabry's disease.

Fabry's disease:

  • X-linked recessive disorder of globotriaosylceramide metabolism secondary to deficient lysosomal alpha-galactosidase A activity resulting in excessive intracellular storage of globotriaosylceramide.
  • Classically it presents in childhood with acroparathesias, angiokeratoma, and hypohidrosis. The average age of death is around 50 years of age.
  • Overtime patients develop restrictive cardiomyopathy
  • Renal biopsy reveals enlarged glomerular visceral epithelial cells packed with small clear vacuoles containing globotriaosylceramide. These vacuoles are arranged in parallel arrays known as Zebra bodies which can be easily seen on electron microscopy.
  • On urine analysis, oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarised light are seen known as maltese cross.
  • Treatment is Recombinant alpha-galactosidase A.

questions.text: During your dermatology positing, you noticed diascopy and woods lamp test were used to differentiate vitiligo from naevus anaemicus. Which of the following options represent the findings seen in the case of vitiligo?

choices.text: Lesion remains paler on diascopy and depigmented areas  completely disappears under Wood's lamp
Lesion remains paler on diascopy and depigmented areas are exaggerated  under Wood's lamp
Both lesion and normal skin appear pale on diascopy and the pallor completely disappears under Wood's lamp
Both lesion and normal skin appear pale on diascopy and depigmented areas are exaggerated  under Wood's lamp

questions.solution:
In a case of Vitiligo, lesion remains paler on diascopy and depigmented areas are exaggerated under Wood's lamp

Diascopy and Wood's lamp are used to differentiate between naevus anaemicus and vitiligo.

Diascopy is a clinical manoeuvre performed to assess superficial erythema in dermatological conditions. It involves pressing a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colourless piece of plastic onto the skin to compress blood out of small vessels, in order to allow evaluation of other colours. Vessels can be seen to blanch and fill, by varying the amount of pressure on the skin, which is different for different conditions.

Diascopy: Nevus anemicus becomes indistinguishable from the surrounding skin with diascopy i.e. in naevus anaemicus (a localized area of vasoconstriction), since other pigments are unaltered, diascopy of adjacent skin reveals an identical color to that of the ‘depigmented’ area. But in vitiligo, in which there is loss of melanin,  the vitiligo lesion remains paler.

Wood's Lamp: In vitiligo, due to loss of melanin, the depigmented areas are exaggerated under the wood's lamp. Whereas, in naevus anaemicus, due to localized dermal vasoconstriction, the pallor completely disappears under the light.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

questions.text: The encircled cells in the following image show the detached acellular ciliary tufts. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this degenerative process?

choices.text: This is associated with situs inversus and bronchiectasis
Seen in acute upper airways inflammation
Rarefaction of cilia and disappearance of the stria can be observed

questions.solution:
The cells in the image show detached acellular ciliary tufts which are known as Ciliocytophthoria. It is not associated with Kartagener syndrome ( situs inversus and bronchiectasis).

Ciliocytophthoria (CCP) defines a degeneration of the ciliated cells due to viral infections.  It is commonly seen in acute upper respiratory airways infection usually caused by viruses like viruses Rhinovirus, Myxovirus (Influenza virus), and Paramyxovirus.

Note:

(option A) Kartagener syndrome: also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia/ immotile cilia syndrome. It occurs due to a defect in the dynein arm of cilia. It is characterized by a triad: 

  • Sinusitis
  • Situs Inversus
  • Bronchiectasis

questions.text: A newly joined ASHA worker is to be instructed regarding the HBNC. Which among the following is true regarding her work?
questions.solution:
ASHA visits all newborns on proper schedule up to their 42 days of life. The number of home visits will be,

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (no visit on day 1)
  • 5 visits to those born in a facility through LSCS (no visits on day 1 and day 3)

The total incentive received by ASHA for HBNC (Home-based newborn care) is Rs.250 if she completes all her visits. In the case of twins or triplets, the incentive amount received doubles or triples respectively.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady who is a known diabetic has had right shoulder pain for the past 7 months. She had pain initially mainly on external rotation along with restricted movements. Now, her pain has gradually decreased but she still complains of a stiff shoulder. You diagnose her with adhesive capsulitis. What stage of adhesive capsulitis is this patient in?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of decrease in pain and complaints of stiffness in the shoulder joint indicate stage II of adhesive capsulitis/frozen shoulder.

Frozen shoulder is a disorder characterized by progressive pain and stiffness of the shoulder, which usually resolves spontaneously. The condition is particularly associated with diabetes, Dupuytren’s contracture, hyperlipidemia, thyroid disorders, cardiac disease, and hemiplegia. X-ray of the shoulder is usually normal, with some cases showing sclerosis on the outer edge of the greater tuberosity.

Reeves classified the frozen shoulder into three stages:

  • Stage I (Stage of pain): In this stage patients usually complain of acute pain with decreased movements (external rotation is most affected followed by the abduction and then forward flexion; internal rotation is the least affected). This stage lasts for 10-36 weeks
  • Stage II: The stage of stiffness where pain gradually decreases and patients complain of the stiff shoulder. This lasts for 4 to 12 months.
  • Stage III: The stage of recovery, the patient will have no pain and the movements have recovered except that the movements are never regained back to normal. It usually lasts for 6 months to 2 years.

questions.text: During the measurement of renal clearance of a drug, you notice that the renal clearance of the drug is less than the GFR. What would you infer regarding the renal handling of the given drug?

choices.text: Drug is secreted by the renal tubules
Drug is reabsorbed by the renal tubules
Drug is excreted in renal tubules
Drug is neither secreted nor reabsorbed in renal tubules

questions.solution:
If a drug has less renal clearance than GFR, it implies that the drug is reabsorbed in renal tubules. 

Excretion rate= (filteration rate- reabsorption rate)+ secretion rate.

The clearance of the substance:

  • Equals the GFR if there is no net tubular secretion or reabsorption.
  • Exceeds the GFR if there is net tubular secretion.
  • Less than the GFR if there is net tubular reabsorption

questions.text: You are observing fungal structures on microscopic examination of clinical specimens sent from the Infectious Disease Department. Which of the following description of fungal structures correctly match the respective organism?
questions.solution:
Options 2 and 3 are correct.

  • Sulfur granules are seen in Mycetoma.
  • Broad ribbon-like hyphae are seen in Mucormycosis.

Mycetoma:-

  • Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia, and bone, which most often affects the foot or the hand. It is, therefore, commonly known as Maduramycosis or Madura foot. Mycetoma occurs worldwide.
  • Etiology: It can be divided into three types, eumycetomas, actinomycetomas, and botryomycosis.

Pathogenesis:-

  • Triad of symptoms: Infection follows traumatic inoculation of the organism into the subcutaneous tissue from soil or vegetable sources, usually on thorns or splinters, and results in tumefactions, deformities, and draining sinuses discharging fungal colonies called grains or granules (a triad of symptoms). 
  • Subcutaneous tissues of the feet, lower extremities, hands, and exposed areas are most often involved.
  • Grains: Within host tissues, the organisms develop to form compacted colonies (grains) 0.5–2 mm in diameter, the color of which depends on the organism responsible.

Laboratory Diagnosis

  • A. Direct Examination: The presence of sulfur grains in pus collected from draining sinuses or in biopsy material is diagnostic.
  • B. Culture Samples should also be cultured, at both 25–30°C and 37°C, on brain-heart infusion agar or blood agar for actinomycetes and on Sabouraud agar (without cycloheximide) for fungi.

Treatment:-

The management of eumycetoma is difficult, involving surgical debridement or excision and chemotherapy. Actinomycetoma responds well to rifampicin in combination with sulfonamides or cotrimoxazole.

 

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection in diabetes mellitus, leukemia, lymphoma patients. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza.

The agents of zygomycosis are angioinvasive, They invade tissues of patients with reduced host defense. From there, they enter the blood vessels and proliferate in the walls of blood vessels particularly paranasal sinuses, lungs, intestines. This results in infarction and necrosis of tissues distal to blocked vessels.

Mucormycosis under a microscope is seen as broad ribbon-like hyphae with uneven thickness and irregular branching.

Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.

Other options:

Septate hyphae in skin or nail specimens are seen in Dermatophytosis.

Spherules are seen in Coccidioidomycosis.

Brownish, septate hyphae are seen in Phaeohyphomycosis—species of Bipolaris, Cladosporium, Curvularia, Exserohilum.

Hyaline septate hyphae are seen in Hyalohyphomycosis—species of Aspergillus, Fusarium, Geotrichum, Trichosporon.

questions.text: A college-going student was brought to the hospital with pain and swelling of the right hand and inability to move the fingers. The symptoms had developed after he had punched a wall during a fight. X-ray reveals a fracture as shown by the arrow. The long bone fractured in the X-Ray is of which of the following types?
questions.solution:
Given X-Ray shows the fracture of the neck of the fifth metacarpal bone. Metacarpals are miniature long bones.

Long bones are classified as follows:

  • Typical long bones (see figure) have an elongated shaft (diaphysis) and two expanded ends (epiphysis). The shaft has a central medullary cavity and a nutrient foramen directed away from the growing end. E.g., humerus, ulna, radius, femur, tibia, and fibula.
  • Miniature long bones contain only one epiphysis. E.g., metacarpals, metatarsals, and phalanges.
  • Modified long bones have a modified shaft or end, and no medullary cavity. E.g., clavicle.

Note: Extra-articular fracture of the fifth metacarpal neck is seen in Boxer's fracture. It is caused by striking an hard object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing, or occasionally by a direct injury.

questions.text: A 61-year-old with anginal symptoms is undergoing elective coronary angiography. Just when the intra-arterial radiocontrast was given through the radial artery, he developed bradycardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This pattern of response can be elicitated by all except:
questions.solution:
The explained scenario is consistent with Bezold–Jarisch reflex.

Serotonin, capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, and veratridine are responsible for Bezold–Jarisch reflex.

Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers located in the cardiopulmonary region (ex:juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, pulmonary artery) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea followed by a period of rapid shallow breathing. This response is called the Bezold-Jarisch reflex.

questions.text: A 50 -year- old female patient presents with bilateral adnexal masses and ascites. Histopathological examination of resected adnexal masses reveals sheets of mucin-producing signet ring cells as seen below.  Mutation in CDH-1 is associated with the primary tumor, which was followed by metastasis. Which of the following statements is/are correct regarding the epithelial-mesenchymal transition and metastasis genes in such tumors?
questions.solution:
Options 1, and 4 are correct.

The most likely diagnosis is a metastatic signet ring carcinoma called Krukenberg tumor. The stomach is the primary site in most Krukenberg tumor cases (70%). 

In epithelial-mesenchymal transition, carcinoma cells upregulate certain mesenchymal markers both- vimentin and smooth muscle actin.

Candidate Metastasis oncogenes are SNAIL and TWIST, which encode transcription factors whose primary function is to promote epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT). SNAIL and TWIST downregulate E-cadherin expression.

  • In EMT, carcinoma cells downregulate certain epithelial markers (e.g., E-cadherin) and upregulate certain mesenchymal markers (e.g. vimentin and smooth muscle actin).
  • This favors the development of a promigratory phenotype that is essential for metastasis.
  • Loss of E-cadherin expression seems to be a key event in EMT.
  • EMT has been documented mainly in breast carcinoma

Carcinomas of colon, appendix, and breast (mainly invasive lobular carcinoma) are the next most common primary sites for Krukenberg tumor. It is composed chiefly of mucin-laden signet ring cells with eccentric hyperchromatic nuclei.

Related Pearl: Protooncogenes, Oncogenes and Oncoproteins

Protooncogenes, Oncogenes, and Oncoproteins

  • Proto-oncogenes: normal cellular genes whose products promote cell proliferation
  • Oncogenes: mutated or overexpressed versions of proto-oncogenes that function autonomously, having lost dependence on normal growth promoting signals
  • Oncoprotein: a protein encoded by an oncogene that drives increased cell proliferation through one of the several mechanisms

questions.text: An infant presented with distension of abdomen shortly after birth with a history of not passing meconium. Subsequently, a barium enema was done and its findings are shown below. Which of the following statements are correct with respect to the condition seen in the given infant?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the barium enema showing a dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid descending colon is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. Option 1,3, and 5 are correct regarding this condition.

Hirschsprung disease:

Hirschsprung’s disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus. Boys are four times more frequently affected than girls. The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone.

Most infants present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis with failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life. Enterocolitis is the most common cause of death in patients with uncorrected Hirschsprung’s disease and may be manifested as diarrhea alternating with periods of obstipation, abdominal distention, fever, hematochezia, and peritonitis.

 Anorectal manometry shows the absence of anorectal inhibitory reflex.

A rectal biopsy is a gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung’s disease. Biopsy specimen shows,

  • Absent ganglia
  • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
  • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
  • Calretinin immunostain­ing has become more widely used and is considered superior to acetylcholinesterase staining to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to you with a nasal discharge which has the following appearance on a handkerchief.  Presence of which of the following features helps you in diagnosing the condition as CSF rhinorrhoea?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the double target sign seen in CSF rhinorrhoea. Presence of β2 transferrin is specific for CSF and the CSF rhinorrhoea patients cannot sniff back the discharge.

CSF rhinorrhoea: Leakage of CSF into the nose is called CSF rhinorrhoea

Following features helps in differentiating CSF rhinorrhoea from nasal secretions

Features CSF Fluid Nasal Secretions

History

Nasal or sinus surgery, head injury, or intracranial tumor

Sneezing, nasal stuffiness, itching in the nose, or lacrimation

Flow of discharge

A few drops or a stream of fluid gushes down with bending forward or straining

cannot be sniffed back

Continuous and no effect with bending forward or straining.

Can be sniffed back

Character of discharge

Thin, watery, and clear

Slimy (mucus) or clear (tears)

Taste

Sweet

Salty

Sugar content

More than 30 mg/dL

Less than 10 mg/dl

Presence of β2 transferrin

Always present

 Always absent

Note:

Nasal discharge stiffens the handkerchief because of the presence of mucus.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: A first-year medical student during a practical exam chooses a histological slide of the umbilical cord for discussion. The examiner focuses the slide as shown in the below image. The structure shown by the tip of the arrow develops from which of the following mesoderm?
questions.solution:
The structure shown by the tip of the arrow is Wharton’s jelly, which develops from extraembryonic mesoderm.

The extraembryonic mesoderm of the connecting stalk develops into a gelatinous substance known as Wharton’s jelly.  

When the tail fold of the embryo is formed, the connecting stalk moves towards the ventral aspect of the embryo. The connecting stalk is now attached only in the region of the umbilical opening. The extraembryonic mesoderm of the connecting stalk becomes Wharton's jelly in the umbilical cord. Wharton's jelly protects the blood vessels in the umbilical cord. 

Structures seen in the histological section of the umbilical cord are shown in the below image.

questions.text: A 50-year-old renal transplant patient presented with difficulty in vision. The fundoscopy was done and is shown below. Which of the following is false about the pathogen causing the disease?
questions.solution:
Options 1 and 3 are false.

CMV retinitis is the most probable diagnosis as the patient is immunocompromised (transplant recipient) and the fundoscopy shows patchy areas of retinal necrosis with irregular borders and overlying retinal hemorrhages.

  • The serological assay is not informative in the case of the immunocompromised patient and PCR assay is the gold standard for diagnosis.
  • CMV mostly causes infection in immunocompromised patients such as transplant recipients and AIDS. The most common infections are interstitial pneumonitis, gastroenteritis, esophagitis, and retinitis.
  • Ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet, and cidofovir are approved for treatment of CMV retinitis in patients with AIDS. 

It belongs to Beta viruses subfamily of herpesviridae family.

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with fever, abdominal discomfort, cough, and difficulty in breathing for the past 3 weeks. He has a history of pica and contact with pet dogs. Laboratory investigations show leucocytosis and high eosinophilia. The eggs of the implicated organism are shown in the given image. The most likely causative parasite is______
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the eggs of Toxocara are suggestive of visceral larva migrans, most commonly caused by Toxocara canis.

Toxocara eggs appear murky as the surface contour is pitted due to the mammilation of the protein layer of the shell.

Larva migrans is generally seen when human infection occurs with nonhuman species of nematodes. It can be classified into cutaneous or visceral types, depending on whether the larval migration takes place in the skin or deeper tissues.

Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of nematode larvae that infect by the oral route whereas cutaneous larva migrans is caused by the migration of larvae that infect by skin penetration. The most common cause is the dog ascarid Toxocara canis and, less often the cat ascarid T.cati.

Children are more likely to swallow dirt (pica) so this condition is more common in them. The infective eggs present in the soil are ingested, and the larvae hatch in the small intestine, penetrate the gut wall and migrate to the liver. From the liver, they may migrate to other organs such as the lungs, brain, or eyes. They do not develop into adults, but induce granulomatous inflammation and cause local damage.

Clinical manifestations like fever, hepatomegaly, pneumonitis, and hyperglobulinaemia are seen. A history of pica can be present. Patients can develop neurological disturbances (Neural larva migrans) or endophthalmitis (Ophthalmic larva migrans). CBC shows leucocytosis and high eosinophilia.

Serological tests like ELISA have been useful in diagnosis. Thiabendazole can be used for treatment. Deworming of household pets also helps in prevention.

questions.text: The body of an 82-year-old man has been seen for post-mortem to know the cause of death. You are examining a histopathological slide containing a section of his cardiac tissue where you notice some pigmentation. Mark the correct option/s regarding the accumulations seen in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Options 3,4 and 5 are correct.

Lipochrome or Lipofuscin (brown lipid) is seen as a yellow-brown pigment in the histopathological image which can be seen in the liver and heart of normal aging patients.

 It is also known as wear-and-tear pigment or lipofuscin, which is an insoluble, brownish yellow, granular intracellular material, which accumulates in various tissues like the heart, liver, and brain as a function of age. The brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.

Lipofuscin (brown lipid):

  • Derived through lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of subcellular membranes.
  • Not injurious to the cell or its functions.
  • Indicates free radical injury and lipid peroxidation.
  • Seen in cells undergoing slow, regressive changes.
  • Prominent in the liver and heart of aging patients, patients with severe malnutrition, and cancer cachexia.

 

 

Related Pearl: Intracellular accumulations

Substance accumulated Seen in

Cholesterol and cholesterol esters

Atherosclerosis

Xanthomas

Cholesterolosis

Niemann Pick disease type c
Mallory bodies(keratin filaments)

Alcoholic liver disease

Morbid obesity

Indian childhood cirrhosis

Wilson’s disease

Primary biliary cirrhosis
Lipofuscin Free radical injury
Immunoglobulins Russel bodies and Dutcher bodies of multiple myeloma
Melanin

Normal endocrine cells of the duodenal mucosa

Carcinoid syndrome

Alkaptonuria
Copper  Wilson disease
Hemosiderin Hemochromatosis

questions.text: Given below is a chest x-ray of a patient, who presented with a 3-week history of dry cough and dyspnea on exertion, which reveals the presence of the garland triad. Later you advised gallium 67 nuclear scan for this patient. Which of the following signs is usually seen in this nuclear scan?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray showing garland triad are suggestive of sarcoidosis. With regards to sarcoidosis, Panda sign and Lambda sign are seen in gallium 67 nuclear scan.

Radiological findings in sarcoidosis:

Panda sign: It is a gallium-67 citrate scan finding. It is due to the bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis, superimposed on the normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa.

 

 

The lambda sign is seen on gallium-67 scans in the setting of thoracic sarcoidosis. Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes are typically involved which can resemble the lambda symbol (λ).

It is the gallium equivalent of 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign.

 

Other options :

1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign is an x-ray finding, which is due to Garland triad i.e  the lymph node enlargement pattern seen in sarcoidosis:

  • Right paratracheal nodes
  • Right hilar nodes
  • Left hilar node

 

Galaxy sign, initially described as the sarcoid galaxy, is an HRCT finding which  represents a coalescent granuloma seen in a minority of patients with pulmonary sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presented to the OPD with purplish, itchy, flat-topped bumps on his shins along with a fine reticular lacy pattern on the oral mucosa as shown in the below image. Which of the following nail changes is most specific in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of purplish, itchy, flat-topped lesions on shins and white streaks forming a lacework in the buccal mucosa, Wickham's striae, shown in the image are diagnostic of Lichen planus. Among all the nail changes seen in Lichen planus, Dorsal nail pterygium is the most specific nail finding.

The most common presentation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules with interspersed lacy white lines known as Wickham's striae. This description is known as the characteristic "6 Ps" of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

The main treatment in the case of persistent lichen planus is steroids. The first line of therapy is always topical steroids. The second-line treatment is with systemic steroids, retinoids, and PUVA.

Other options:

Option B: Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon patch is a pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. 

Option C and D: Pup tent sign and thinning of the nail plate are the nail findings seen in lichen planus.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image: Trachyonychia

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text:
What is the GCS score of a road traffic accident victim who opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, makes some incomprehensible sounds, and has the following posture?

GCS - Glasgow Coma Scale
questions.solution:
The GCS score based on the given clinical scenario is 7.

It is calculated as follows:

  • Opening of the eyes to a painful stimulus - 2
  • Incomprehensible sounds - 2
  • Decorticate posturing/ abnormal flexion  - 3 

In the decorticate posture, elbows, wrists, and fingers are flexed, and the legs are extended and rotated inward, as seen in the image.

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used to assess patients with a head injury.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: You notice the following lesion in the forearm of an otherwise normal newborn. The lesion is caused because of:

choices.text: A viral infection transmitted from mother to the fetus
A bacterial infection transmitted from the mother to the fetus
Vigorous in utero sucking upon the affected part
An autoimmune condition in the newborn

questions.solution:
The image shows Sucking Blisters.
Sucking blisters are caused due to vigorous in utero sucking on the affected part.

They are usually present upon the upper-limb.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: An ophthalmology resident notices the following finding during slit-lamp examination in one of his patients and identifies it as ectopia lentis. Identify the true statements regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows ectopia lentis.

Ectopia lentis refers to a hereditary or acquired displacement of the lens from its normal position.

Causes:

Acquired

  • Trauma
  • Pseudoexfoliation
  • Inflammation, e.g. chronic cyclitis, syphilis
  • Hypermature cataract
  • Large eye, e.g. high myopia, buphthalmos
  • Anterior uveal tumours

Congenital:

  • Familial Ectopia lentis – Autosomal dominant condition characterized by B/L symmetrical superotemporal displacement.
  • Ectopia lentis et pupillae - AR inheritance, displacement of the pupil and the lens in opposite directions
  • Marfan syndrome – Superotemporal displacement
  • Weil-Marchesani syndrome – Downward, forward subluxation of the lens with spherophakia.

Other systemic conditions associated with ectopia lentis include

  • Sulfite oxidase deficiency - Ectopia lentis is a universal feature.
  • Stickler syndrome 
  • Ehlers–Danlos syndrome
  • Hyperlysinaemia

questions.text: Out of two athletes 'A' and 'B', 'A' is participating in long-distance running, and 'B' is participating in the long jump. Which of the following are the correct combination of the muscles and the type of muscle fiber that serves them best?
questions.solution:
'A' is the long-distance runner who would be best benefitting from soleus's slow-twitch fibers, and B, the long jumper would benefit from gastrocnemius's fast-twitch fibers.

Fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers

  • Fast-twitch fibers can deliver extreme amounts of power for a few seconds to a minute.
    • The enzymes that promote rapid release of energy from the phosphagen and glycogen–lactic acid energy systems are more active in fast-twitch fibers.
    • Fast-twitch fibers are about twice as large in diameter compared with slow-twitch fibers.
    • Gastrocnemius muscle has a higher preponderance of fast-twitch fibers, which gives it the capability of forceful and rapid contraction of the type used in jumping.
  • Slow-twitch fibers are mainly organized for endurance, especially for the generation of aerobic energy.
    • They have far more mitochondria than do the fast-twitch fibers.
    • They contain considerably more myoglobin. The extra myoglobin increases the rate of diffusion of oxygen throughout the fiber.
    • The enzymes of the aerobic metabolic system are considerably more active in slow-twitch fibers.
    • The number of capillaries is greater in the vicinity of slow-twitch fibers.
    • Soleus muscle has a higher preponderance of slow-twitch muscle fibers and therefore is used to a greater extent for prolonged lower leg muscle activity.

questions.text: You are conducting a meta-analysis of studies of the effects of statin drugs on the risk of developing ventricular arrhythmias in patients with cardiomyopathy. The study is presented as the following plot, which among the given statements are correct regarding the interpretation of these plots?
questions.solution:
The given plot for the meta-analysis is a forest plot. Options 1, 2 and 5 are correct about it.

Forest plots allow the results to be seen at a glance with the identification of the outliers.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles- the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle- sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side- confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line- the “line of no effect", no difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1)
  • The location of the result- whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond- the overall pooled result
  • Lateral corners of the diamond- confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.

 

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text: You notice a patient lying in the hospital compound with his attendant, to be seen by a psychiatrist. He does not react when you lend him a hand to make him stand. He doesn't move or respond to any other instruction given by the attendant. This behavior can be best described as:
questions.solution:
The behavior of not responding to instructions and external stimuli is known as negativism.

Negativism is a feature seen in catatonia. Verbal or nonverbal opposition to suggestions or advice is exhibited. There is resistance to efforts to be moved and the patient might even do the opposite of what is asked.

Catatonia is a condition seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses. It is a new diagnostic category in the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, fifth edition (DSM-5). A diagnosis of catatonia is not made if there is a primary mental disorder such as schizophrenia or psychotic depression, or if present during the course of delirium. 

Abnormal behaviors include grimacing, mutism, echolalia, stupor, and posturing. Wavy flexibility is marked by uniform resistance offered to passive positioning. Catalepsy is a passively inducted posture that is maintained against gravity by the patient. 

Some conditions that can cause catatonia include head trauma, encephalitis, and hepatic encephalopathy. Some medications such as corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, or antipsychotics can also result in the condition. It can also be seen in neuroleptic-induced parkinsonism and neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

The primary treatment for catatonia includes identifying and treating underlying medical or pharmacological causes. Any offending substances should be removed. Benzodiazepines are effective in reducing the symptoms of catatonia temporarily. Electroconvulsive therapy should be started for catatonia that is not responding to benzodiazepines and in severe cases with life-threatening conditions such as refusal to eat. 

Other options:

Option A: Mannerisms are normal movements that look odd and are involuntary. 

Option B: Stereotypy is purposeless repetitive speech or movements.

Option D: Echopraxia is characterized by mimicking an observed movement.

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

Related Pearl: Pharmacological treatment of psychosis

First-generation antipsychotics are generally not preferred due to the higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects/ tardive dyskinesia.

Second-generation antipsychotics are preferred drugs:

  • Risperidone
  • Olanzapine
  • Quetiapine
  • Aripiprazole
  • Ziprasidone
  • Paliperidone

Benzodiazepines can be added to treat associated agitation. It is the drug of choice for catatonia.

Special situations:

  • Emergency: Use a short-acting intramuscular agent such as haloperidol, fluphenazine, olanzapine, or ziprasidone.
  • Chronic compliance: Long-acting injectable is used.
  • Treatment resistance (2 failed trials): Consider Clozapine.
  • All meds ineffective: May consider ECT.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining slides of renal tissue to study glomerular pathology. Which of the following will she not observe on H & E staining or electron microscopy findings?

choices.text: Spike and dome appearance on electron microscopy is seen in membranous nephropathy
Podocyte effacement on light microscopy is seen in Minimal Change disease
Crescents and necrosis are seen on light microscopy in Goodpasture syndrome
Basket-weave appearance of GBM on electron microscopy in Alport syndrome

questions.solution:
The effacement of the foot process can only be observed on electron microscopy. Effacement of the podocyte foot processes is characteristically seen in minimal change disease (MCD), which is also called lipoid nephrosis. Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.

It is also seen in other conditions such as membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. Since the podocytes are affected in these diseases, they are also known as podocytopathies.

Other options:

Spike and dome appearance on electron microscopy is characteristically seen in membranous nephropathy. Membranous nephropathy is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. 

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Note:

  • Anionic antigens form subendothelial deposits.
  • Cationic antigens form subepithelial deposits.
  • Neutral antigens form mesangial deposits.

questions.text: Two patients have been posted for a tracheostomy procedure. The operating surgeon performs tracheostomy through the level of 2nd - 3rd tracheal rings in the first patient and  4th - 5th tracheal ring in the second patient. What is the type of tracheostomy procedure conducted in these patients respectively?

choices.text: Low tracheostomy is done in both patients

questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests that Mid tracheostomy and Low tracheostomy is performed by the surgeon in first and second patient respectively.

Mid tracheostomy is done through the 2nd and 3rd ring and Low tracheostomy is done below the level of isthmus i.e through the 4th and 5th tracheal ring.

High tracheostomy is done above the level of thyroid isthmus (Isthmus lies against II, III, and IV tracheal ring). The only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: During the neurological examination of a patient, you notice an abnormality while testing the visual field using confrontation field testing. On wiggling the index finger of one hand, the patient sees normally and reports the correct side but on wiggling fingers of both sides simultaneously, he only observes the right side and reports the left hand to be stationary. This is called ______.
questions.solution:
• The defect mentioned above is called visual inattention, also known as hemispatial neglect. It is the inability to report, respond, or orient to stimuli in one half of the space despite having no motor or sensory deficits.
  • Two bedside tests can be used to evaluate neglect: simultaneous bilateral stimulation (described above) and visual target cancellation.
  • In simultaneous bilateral stimulation, when the examiner provides unilateral or simultaneous bilateral stimulation in the visual, auditory, or tactile modalities, patients have no difficulty detecting unilateral stimuli on either side but perceive the bilaterally presented stimulus as coming only from one side. This phenomenon is known as extinction.
  • In visual target cancellation, the patient fails to detect the targets on one half of the field in target-detection tasks.

Option B: Simultanagnosia is the inability to integrate the visual information at the center of gaze with more peripheral information. These patients can only see one object at a time and sometimes only parts of an object despite having normal visual acuity. The objects seen by them cannot be located in space because they do not see anything else that can be used as a reference point.

Option C: Somatoparaphrenia is a phenomenon wherein the patient considers the paralytic hand to be a part of or belonging to someone else.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female complained of frequent change in presbyopic glasses and deterioration of vision. The intraocular pressure was raised on examination and she was started on anti-glaucoma medication. Which of the following anti-glaucoma drugs act by increasing the uveoscleral outflow?
questions.solution:
Options 1, 4 and 5 are correct. Latanoprost, dipivefrine and apraclonidine increase uveoscleral outflow.

Dipivefrine is a prodrug and is converted to adrenaline. Adrenaline lowers intraocular pressure by:

  • Increasing trabecular outflow: beta-2 receptor-mediated.
  • Increasing both trabecular and uveoscleral outflow, and decreasing aqueous production: alpha receptor-mediated. 

Latanoprost is a prostaglandin drug, which acts by increasing the uveoscleral outflow and thereby lowers the intraocular pressure. 

Mechanism of action: Latanoprost is a prodrug and gets activated during its passage through the cornea. It acts by stimulating the prostanoid receptors on the ciliary muscles. This leads to the release of matrix metalloproteinases, which increases the uveoscleral outflow.

Apraclonidine is a congener of clonidine that has primary α2 agonist action and a subsidiary α1 agonist action. It also increases uveo-scleral outflow.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient, who was diagnosed with severe ARDS  was shifted to the intensive care unit and was put on mechanical ventilation with high PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure). This ventilatory setting results in all of the following nonpulmonary effects  except
questions.solution:
Mechanical ventilation with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) setting results in all the above effects except decrease in Antidiuretic hormone level.

Positive end-expiratory pressure(PEEP)

PEEP is a mode of therapy used in conjunction with mechanical ventilation. Application of positive pressure during expiration as an adjunct to a mechanically ventilated breath is referred to as PEEP.

The principal mechanism of action appears to be the expansion of partially collapsed alveoli.

Pulmonary effects: 

  • In patients with decreased lung volume, appropriate levels of PEEP will increase FRC and tidal ventilation and thereby improving lung compliance.
  • It also helps in correcting ventilation/perfusion mismatch and aid in improving arterial oxygenation.

Nonpulmonary effects:

  • Urinary output decreases
  • Glomerular filtration decreases.
  • Circulating levels of antidiuretic hormone and angiotensin are usually elevated.
  • Central venous pressure increases
  • Progressive reductions in cardiac output
  • Decrease in both renal and hepatic blood flow.
  • Decreased free water clearance

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy has received complete immunization against tetanus 6 years ago. Now he presents with a contaminated lacerated wound sustained 6 hours ago. He should be given which of the following?

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and single dose of toxoid

questions.solution:
The boy should be given a single dose of tetanus toxoid alone.

He presented with a contaminated wound sustained 6 hours ago and he has received complete immunization against tetanus 6 years back, which comes under Category B of Tetanus Immunization.

According to the recommendations of the CDC:

Vaccination History Clean Minor Wounds All other wounds
Unknown or fewer than 3 doses Tdap/Td Tdap/TD + TIG
3 or more doses Tdap/ Td Only if > 10 years Tdap/TD Only if > 5 years

Tdap - Tetanus, Diptheria, and Pertussis

Td - Tetanus and Diptheria

TIG - Tetanus Immune Globulin

Tdap for children and Td for adults but Tdap is preferred to Td for adults who have never received Tdap.

 Categories of Tetanus immunization:

  • Category A - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within the past 5 years
  • Category B - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within the past > 5 years < 10 years.
  • Category C - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within the past >10 years
  • Category D - Not taken a complete course of TT/booster or immunity status not known.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: Evaluation of a 58-year-old patient shows features of a spinal cord tumor on the left side with functional hemisection of the spinal cord. She presents with a clinical picture of the damage to ascending sensory and descending motor pathways. Considering the suspected diagnosis, which of the following sensations are lost on the side of the motor loss, below the level of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Options 2, 4, and 5 are correct.

In the clinical scenario, the lesion in the left side of the spinal cord, can be compared to that of Brown-sequard syndrome. Hence, the female would have a loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception on the ipsilateral side of the body below the level of the lesion

Brown-sequard syndrome:

Caused due to hemisection of the Spinal cord. It can also be caused by fracture-dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumour.

Clinical features:

  • Pyramidal tract: Pyramidal weakness (ipsilateral upper motor neuron type of paralysis) below the level of the lesion on the same side as the lesion (pyramidal tract crosses in the medulla).
  • Dorsal columns: Impaired fine touch, 2 point discrimination, proprioception, vibration below the level of the lesion on the same side of the lesion (dorsal column fibres cross in the medulla).
  • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain, temperature, crude touch, pressure sensation below the level of the lesion on the contralateral side of the lesion (spinothalamic tract crosses midline after entering the cord).

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: What is the approximate blood loss in a patient with an increased pulse pressure?
questions.solution:
Increased pulse pressure can be seen in Class I hemorrhage, where the blood loss is usually less than 15% of blood volume.

The physiological effects of hemorrhage are divided into four classes, based on clinical signs, which are useful for estimating the percentage of acute blood loss.

Class I hemorrhage is characterized by <15% blood volume loss. The clinical symptoms of volume loss with class I hemorrhage are minimal.

Only in class I, pulse pressure is either increased or normal. In all other classes, it is decreased.

Related Pearl: Classification of hemorrhagic shock

Parameters Class I Class II Class III Class IV
Blood loss in % <15 15–30 30–40 >40
Pulse rate <100 100–120 120–140 >140
Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal

questions.text:
A hemodynamically stable patient developed regular, narrow complex PSVT. The patient had a history of stroke. Which of the following is best indicated for termination of arrhythmia?

PSVT- Paroxysmal supra-ventricular tachycardia
questions.solution:
Intravenous adenosine is preferred for termination of arrhythmia in this patient who is stable with regular and narrow complex PSVT (paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia).

Carotid sinus massage is provided as first-line therapy only if there is a low risk of carotid vascular disease. It is contraindicated in patients with carotid bruit and prior history of stroke as in this patient (option A).

Adenosine may precipitate atrial fibrillation. In patients with WPW syndrome, where AF may lead to hemodynamic instability, IV beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem) are used (option C).

IV Procainamide is used if the above agents fail to terminate the arrhythmia.
